PETITION.PRESENTERS: BELL; SPINDLER; BOURNE; KERNOT; MCLEAN; VALLENTINE
PETITION.TITLE: Middle East: Australian Military Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle-East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle-East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the Middle East.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bell (from 124 citizens), Spindler (from 124 citizens), Bourne (from 92 citizens), Kernot (from 120 citizens), McLean (from 123 citizens) and Vallentine (from 1,061 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned showeth that:

In the light of public concern at the operations and decisions of the Family Court, we the undersigned support a full and open enquiry into all aspects of the Family Law Act and Practises as proposed by Senator David Brownhill, NSW.
This enquiry should also cover related issues such as legal representation and the child Support Agency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Governor of Victoria has set aside 219 hectares of Reserved Forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest to be the West Barham Big Trees Flora Reserve.
We humbly pray that you consider protecting a larger area of the Otways from logging by listing it as National Estate forest so that botanical, water and tourist values may be preserved.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain electors of Queensland points out to the Senate that the 1990-91 Federal Budget stipulates that from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test. Family Allowance will be withdrawn if net assets excluding the family home and debt exceed $300,000. Furthermore the parental assets test threshold for Family Allowance Supplement, Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children has been severely slashed in the 1990-91 Federal Budget.

Considering the economic crisis facing rural communities in Australia, assets tests of such a nature are not viable because the assets are incapable of generating enough income to sustain families and send children away for schooling.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to exempt the family farm from the assets test for Austudy, Family Allowance and Family Allowance Supplement.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.5 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The petition of citizens of Australia points out:

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;
that most `X'-rated material available in Australia is imported;

that the Federal Government, by its Customs power under the Constitution, and not the Australian Capital Territory Government, is solely responsible for controlling the importation of this pornographic material;
that by continuing to allow the importation of such pornographic material, the Federal Government is neglecting its responsibility to the women, children and families of Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore, request the Senate to:
1. Ban `X'-rated pornographic material at the point of entry into Australia;
2. Exclude from the `R'-rating all gratuitously violent material.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kingsford-Smith Airport: Third Runway Decision
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively showeth that the Federal Labor Government is procrastinating over the decision on the third runway at Sydney Airport. An immediate decision to construct the third runway is essential to ensure that regional air links are maintained to Sydney Airport. Continued access by rural airlines to Sydney Airport is essential for business purposes in the Sydney Central Business District (CBD), to connect with interstate and international flights, for essential legal, health and welfare services, and to encourage decentralisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: WAR CRIMES (CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the War Crimes Amendment Act 1988.
Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:
That the following Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes that any person who has committed a War Crime should become subject to the provisions of the War Crimes Act 1988. That Act was drawn specifically to restrict its scope to war crimes alleged to have been committed in Eastern Europe between the years 1939-45. This was achieved by specific references to these years in the Preamble, and in section 5 of the Act.
This has had the effect of making the War Crimes Act more limited in its scope than the Geneva Conventions Act 1957 which deals with similar matters.

The more limited scope of the recent Act was justified for some by asserting that most alleged war criminals now resident in Australia came from the areas covered in the Amendment Act and that there are no known instances of alleged Soviet or Japanese war criminals now resident in Australia.

Nevertheless, believing that there can be no real justification for the restriction of the pursuit of war criminals to limited theatres or to limited times, this amendment Bill is designed to widen the compass of the legislation to any war crime committed by any person in any theatre at any time.
To give effect to this, the Bill proposes three simple amendments, two to remove references to Europe and to 1939-45, the third to effect a simple amendment to S9 of the Principal Act.

No one who has not committed a war crime need fear the application of the proposed amendment. It does not seek to override the so-called doctrine of military necessity, nor does it seek to invite frivolous prosecutions. On the other hand we have widened our immigration practices to include migrants from a number of countries in which war crimes are alleged to have occurred, and there is no real argument in principle to seek to quarantine anyone alleged to be a war criminal, from any country, or from any conflict, from the application of the principles agreed to in the War Crimes Act.
The present Amendment Bill will achieve the desirable effect of making the alleged perpetrator of any war crime subject to the application of the Principal Act.

The issue flows from the principle underlying the amendments to the War Crimes Act passed in 1989, namely that no Australian resident who has committed a war crime should be able to escape the consequences of that act by virtue of the effluxion of time and his or her residence in Australia.

Since 1945 there have been many wars and there is evidence of the committing of many war crimes in many of these wars. If any of the perpetrators of those crimes live in Australia, then it is desirable and necessary that they be subject to the provisions of the War Crimes Act.

While the High Court is being asked to judge the constitutionality of the Principal Act, the Parliament is still able, even while awaiting the determinations of the Court, to make declarations of principle and intent about the way we should regard war crimes and pursue war criminals.
This Amendment Bill, by removing the limitations of date and place, will permit the wider pursuit of anyone who has committed any war crime in any place.
The amendments proposed are logical and necessary and I commend them to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twenty-eighth report of the Standing Committee of Privileges, concerning a person referred to in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

This is the ninth report of the Committee concerning a matter raised by a person under Privilege Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 11 December 1990, the President, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, referred a letter from Mr C.H. Cannon relating to remarks made by Senator McLean during discussion on the banking industry on 12 November 1990 to the Committee of Privileges as a submission under Privilege Resolution 5. The Committee has considered the submission and recommends that a response agreed to by Mr Cannon and the Committee be incorporated in Hansard. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The response read as follows-
RESPONSE BY MR C.H. CANNON
AGREED TO BY MR CANNON
AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5 (7) (B) OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988
In the Senate on Monday 12th of November last I was the subject of an attack on my character which I believe was unfounded and extremely damaging to my wife and family and myself.

During an address by Senator McLean (New South Wales) on the Banking Industry, I was accused of fraud and deceptive conduct amongst other things. I found all of his remarks to be totally without substance and most offensive and since Star Television in Toowoomba used the article as the lead item in their news on Thursday 22nd November and the Toowoomba Chronicle printed articles on Friday 23rd and Tuesday 27th November my name has been blackened all over the Darling Downs, which is most disturbing since I was Manager of The National Australia Bank at 441 Ruthven Street, Toowoomba for 5 years.
The findings of the Federal Court of Australia No. G65 of 1986 and subsequent appeal G355 of 1988 show that the court totally exonerated me and my employer The National Australia Bank Ltd.

I believe that as a result of the Senator's comments my reputation, which has been faultless all my life, has suffered irreparable damage, and I request that the matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges which I understand deals with such matters. I will be happy to supply a copy of the offensive articles as well as a copy of the judgement (some 80 pages) and the appeal (some 40 pages) should this be required.
I make the submission in an endeavour to clear my name and my reputation and trust that appropriate action can be taken.
C.H. CANNON

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 November, on motion by Senator Bolkus:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill is another important piece of legislation being guillotined through this place in far too short a time to do any justice to the importance of the subject. It is yet another indictment of the contempt in which the Government is holding the Parliament in respect of the whole legislative process.

SPEECH.PARA: The Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill 1990 proposes to increase haulage charges of gas through the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline system as part of the Government's plans to sell off the pipeline next year. The coalition opposes this Bill very strongly indeed. We do not oppose it because of the proposed privatisation or sale of the pipeline; we oppose it because of the basic proposition that governments should not breach contractual obligations and that the whole approach of the Government to the sale of the assets of the pipeline is in deliberate breach of the Government's contractual arrangements.

Implicit in the whole structure and content of the Bill is the breaking of contractual obligations between a government instrumentality and a private sector firm. A large proportion of this Bill, parts 3 to 5, deals with compensation and legal issues in relation to the existing contract between the Pipeline Authority and Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL). While that deals with compensation and relates only to AGL, other people and parties will be gravely disadvantaged by this Bill. For example, the producers of the gas in the first instance, Santos Ltd, and suppliers such as municipal authorities-in particular, authorities such as the Wagga Wagga City Council-are not considered at all in the compensation arrangements in this Bill. Indeed, they would be deliberately excluded from any compensation provisions in the Bill.

There has been wide opposition to this Bill. For the first time that I can remember five of the major organisations in Australia got together recently and put out a joint press release. These were the Australian Chamber of Commerce, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Australian Mining Industry Council, the Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry. Those peak bodies in Australia said in the press release that the Government should rethink its approach to the pipeline sale because it has:
. . . attempted to deny explicit contractual rights to a contractual partner of the Pipeline Authority;
. . . attempted to abrogate a long term contract between the Pipeline Authority and its contractual partner so that it can increase haulage charges above their economic level . . .
and for other reasons. That very strong statement includes words with which the Opposition totally concurs:
The Government's behaviour is totally unacceptable.

As I said, the coalition opposes this Bill not because the assets of the Pipeline Authority are being sold but because of the inept, underhand manner in which the whole deal has been done. The Government has been rebuffed on numerous occasions now in relation to this Bill; in particular, it has been rebuffed in the courts. In relation to the legal matters surrounding the sale of the pipeline, although it is not an aspect of this Bill as such, the courts threw out a proposal by the Government that it could deny AGL the right of first refusal on the sale. In a judgment on 16 November, the Chief Justice of New South Wales, Justice Rogers, said:

It is not for me to suggest how the Government should conduct its case-or what it should do, but I think it is appropriate for a commercial court to draw attention to very serious commercial consequences of a certain line of argument. I do not think that any government would wish to put an argument which could imperil the reliability or the reliance that the commercial community can place on agreements entered into and rights extended by government instrumentalities. Those are very strong words. They were directed absolutely and totally at the way in which the Government is handling this matter because the right of first refusal, whilst not a part of the Bill before us today, is part of the total process of which this Bill is an integral part. The Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, in his second reading speech, actually acknowledged that the Government was overriding an agreed contract and went on to try to explain why the Government is deliberately breaching contractual arrangements between a government instrumentality and the contracting party.

There has been a wide range of opposition to the Bill. I mentioned the major industry organisations. A wide range of companies have also been opposed to the Bill-not just for particular vested interest reasons but also for reasons very similar to the reason we are opposing this Bill-that is, the way in which this matter is being handled.

The sale of the Pipeline Authority has been on the coalition's agenda for some time and it remains on the agenda. We differ from the Government in the way in which we would go about handling these matters. We would handle them in a way that takes full account of the normal commercial, legal and political relationships that ought to operate between government and the private sector. If governments take actions which destroy the public confidence in the word of government, the damage caused is very great indeed. I can think of no more striking example of that than this case of a government destroying its credibility and its integrity.

What would the Opposition do differently? Let me set out what the Opposition would do, how we would tackle this matter. The Government's quite scandalous suggestion that we are deliberately trying to undermine this exercise needs the fullest possible rebuttal. We would approach the matter in a logical, stepped process. We would first of all create a regulatory framework within which the privatised pipeline would operate, recognising the inherent natural monopoly that the pipeline enjoys at this stage. We would establish an agreed process of sale by negotiation with the contracted parties, not by government dictate and fiat. The haulage tariff rates would have to be included in that process of negotiation. Any outstanding legal matters flowing from those negotiations would have to be resolved. There is no reason why they should not be.

Finally, the agreed sale process should proceed with all information as to future revenues, ongoing legal obligations, if any, and other commercially necessary information being made available to all bidders. There are many other points that if time permitted I would wish to reiterate, but I think the coalition has made the points that it considers important in this matter over a lengthy period-from the day last month that it was decided that the coalition would oppose this Bill.

We feel very strongly about this matter because it goes to the whole process of the operation of government, the credibility of government, the integrity of government and, therefore, the role of government in relation to the community. If the community does not have confidence in the word of government then the whole parliamentary process, the whole democratic process, is put under severe threat. We will be opposing this Bill at both the second and third reading stages as an indication of the strength of feeling that we have about this Bill. I absolutely condemn the Government for the approach it has adopted in this process. I did not believe that I would see a government act in a way that would so undermine its integrity as it has with this operation.

It is about time the Government went back to the drawing board and rethought this whole process. If it does it correctly it will have the support of the coalition. But there is no way that the Government's approach to this process even starts to get towards the bounds of normal acceptable commercial relationships between government and the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also will oppose the Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill, and for two reasons. One of the reasons coincides with that enunciated by Senator Short. I shall not go into detail and repeat the arguments he has advanced, except to say that, firstly, the Democrats do not believe that a government should use its position to vary contractual obligations vis-a-vis a commercial entity in the community which does not have the same powers. The Government has been rebuffed in the courts and, as a result, if this Bill were to proceed it would face legal action for considerable compensation. Secondly, a particularly important reason is that this is a crucial facility that should remain in public hands. If it went into private hands it would be quite clearly a private monopoly in an area where public control is imperative, namely, the distribution of energy resources throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that we cannot afford as a community to put future potential, as well as the current reality, in terms of providing energy to both domestic and industrial consumers, into the hands of a private monopoly. Whilst we acknowledge that the Opposition would probably not subscribe to that particular reason, seeing that it has enthusiastically embraced the privatisation principle, on this occasion I am glad that it is supporting opposition to this Bill.

The Government announced in the August 1989 Budget that it wished to sell the Sydney-Moomba gas pipeline owned by the Pipeline Authority. The sale did not proceed because the existing contractual arrangements, which were negotiated by the Whitlam Government, do not allow the Authority to earn any overall profit until the year 2006. In fact, the arrangements provide for charges to be made on a cost recovery basis; in other words, only those costs which go towards the maintenance of the pipeline may be recovered by any increases in charges. This completely eliminates the possibility of a commercially based pricing system for gas haulage, and thus makes the value of the pipeline to a prospective purchaser much lower than it otherwise would be.

The Government announced in the 1990 Budget that it would press on with the privatisation regardless of these existing contractual arrangements, and that it proposed to increase by this legislation the existing haulage tariffs which are charged to the owners of the gas, Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL). The proposed increases are 25 per cent from 1 January 1991 and a further 25 per cent from 1 January 1992. This will flow through to a rise of approximately 9 per cent over the two year period for domestic consumers.

AGL claims to have a pre-emptive right over the pipeline, and the Government has recently confirmed that. This, and a possible loss of sales of gas, may lead to compensation claims of quite large proportions, amounting to several hundred million dollars. The Federal Government has announced an intention to appeal such a decision, although it is difficult to see what grounds it would have. The Government should have withdrawn the legislation, given that both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have stated from the outset that they would oppose this legislation; the time of the Senate could have been saved on this particular Bill.

Although it relates to gas haulage charges, the purpose of the Bill clearly is to facilitate the privatisation of the pipeline. Apart from the increased gas costs that would occur, the longer term structural implications of private sector control over energy conveyancing systems must be considered. This is especially so given the possible future connection of the pipeline to the North West Shelf project, interconnection to other States, and to future hydrogen fuel utilisation.

I am sure that my colleague, Senator Coulter, will address this particular question in much more detail because I believe it is of considerable importance for the community at large. Mr Willis, in his second reading speech, said:

Without adjustments to the haulage tariff of this order the Government would withdraw the pipeline system from sale and not support a future sale until the current haulage agreements are appropriately modified.

Hopefully, this commitment will be honoured after the Bill is rejected by the Senate, because a sale under the current conditions would not obtain anywhere near the value of the pipeline. The Government should reverse its crazy assets stripping policy and build the current system into a national pipeline system to help to satisfy Australia's energy needs in the twenty-first century in a sustainable manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, because of the provisions of the guillotine applying, by agreement I have but five minutes to put a few points concerning the sale of the pipeline. Specific points that I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate came out of Estimates Committee A hearings which were complementary to the hearings which took place in Estimates Committee F. I think the thing that was central to many of the questions asked in Committee A was why the task force, charged with the responsibility of selling the pipeline, had not firstly put a cost on the pipeline if it had to take into account honouring the heads of agreement, which were clearly in evidence at the time that it was making its calculation, and which the court has subsequently upheld.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing it did not do was make any proper provision for compensation because it very arrogantly asserted that it was not its problem, that the Government would pass some other form of legislation and that it would not have to be taken out of the proceeds of the pipeline sale. Two elements came through very strongly in those hearings: one was arrogance; one was cynicism. It was a very cynical exercise simply to introduce legislation to sell a pipeline and abrogate the legal liabilities which it had under previous agreements. Fortunately, the court of Mr Justice Rogers upheld that proposition.

At the time of the discussion and at the time the Opposition made it quite clear we would be opposing this legislation, it was quite evident that litigation was going to ensue and that any calculations that the Government had made about the proposed benefits that would flow from the manner in which it was handling the sale of the pipeline would indeed be quite small in the wash-up. But, worse than that, because of the proposed increase in the charges, the consumer would be paying more for the product, and inflationary effects of the increase would be felt right across the board.

When I specifically asked Mr Heinrich about the manner in which he had gone about seeking a price that he might expect and asked very specifically why he had not costed the option of honouring the heads of agreement, he replied to me:

We did not think it was relevant to the process that we embarked upon. As I said before, we do not consider the Commonwealth Government is bound by the express provisions of the 1985 heads of agreement.

That was a pretty arrogant statement, and one that has been held to be incorrect. The reason that my colleague Senator Short stated that we are opposing the Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill is a straightforward one: very simply, the action of a government in attempting to abrogate contractual obligations is simply reprehensible and, accordingly, we are pleased to see that this legislation will be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Spindler pointed out, I will be addressing our opposition to the sale of what was originally conceived to be, and is on the way to becoming, a national pipeline grid which will serve a very important long term interest in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Rex Connor, who had a lot to do with the Pipeline Authority, had a dream of which there were two components: one was that we should buy back the farm and own the land and resources of this country ourselves. Part of that dream was that one of the resources we should own was a national pipeline grid-that it should be in public ownership. Indeed, it is a great pity that the present Government does not have such visionary attitudes.
In the seventeenth annual report, 1989-90, of the Pipeline Authority one reads that Rex Connor, the then Minister for Minerals and Energy in 1973, introduced the Pipeline Authority Act establishing:
. . . an authority with adequate powers to construct and operate a major public utility having the responsibility of making one of Australia's natural resources available to the Australian people.

The original concept provided for a national pipeline system and took account of long term issues-we should note the phrase `long term issues'-such as defence, decentralisation, population growth, national development, interconnected supplies, emergency situations, exhaustion of particular regional energy resources, and possible future export of liquid natural gas.

We know today that we could add to that the exigencies of greenhouse and the demands which that will place on us to develop alternative energy strategies in the very near future. Indeed, even in this 1990 annual report, one finds the statement that the next five to 10 years are expected to see a fundamental change in the balance of Australia's petroleum resources, with natural gas taking over the dominant position now enjoyed by oil.

The very best evidence that we have available at the present time is that, by early in the next century, Australia will need to look at reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 92 per cent. In that connection, we are a world leader in the development of photovoltaic technology. We were a world leader in the development of ideas in relation to a hydrogen economy-a mechanism by which we could store and transmit photovoltaically generated electricity to remote areas through the electrolysis of water and the transmission of hydrogen through a national pipeline grid.

We are also a world leader, with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's developments in Victoria, in the technology of turning the energy in hydrogen back into electricity through the development of the solid oxide fuel cell. It needs to be stressed that those technologies are not being adequately supported by this Government because it lacks the vision to see where we need to go in the future. Fundamentally, the Australian Democrats are opposed to this legislation because we believe that in the very near future it will be absolutely vital that we have a publicly owned national pipeline system in this country which will be able to transmit the energy exchange material of the future, namely, hydrogen, from remote areas in Australia, where photovoltaic arrays will be erected, to those centres of population where that hydrogen can be used directly as a source of fuel for transport, cooking and for all those things for which we currently use petroleum or natural gas and for conversion back into electricity in our centres of population.

For that reason, as well as the reasons advanced by Senator Spindler and initially by Senator Short in relation to the breaking of contractual arrangements, we will oppose this legislation. I point out to Senator Short that we will vote with the Opposition and that he will not need to vote against the third reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. I do not think we need prolong this matter because the views of honourable senators are clear. Senator Spindler opposes this legislation, first of all, in relation to the Government's alleged interference in contractual obligations and, secondly, because of his longstanding commitment to uneconomic public ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short, on the other hand, in a speech which varied between a sort of horror video and the dreamland, made a number of points of more detail relating to the legislation. The burden of Senator Short's remarks was that this was quite an easy matter and that, if the Opposition had the handling of it, it would take account of-as he put it-the proper legal and political relationships. I want to say something about that in the course of my remarks.

I might just turn to the essential purpose of this legislation, which may have been somewhat lost sight of in the discussion which has transpired to date. First of all, the Pipeline Authority (Charges) Bill is the first step in the implementation of the Government's decision to commercialise and sell the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline system. As Senator Short acknowledged, court cases relating to other steps in that process, with the greatest respect, are not relevant to the debate on this particular Bill.

The sale, as has been said in other places, is an essential component of the Government's program of major asset sales. The rejection of the possibility of this sale taking place-because it will not take place unless this legislation is passed-flies in the face of utterances by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and others. Indeed, it was implicit in a question to me from Senator Short yesterday that the Government should have a tougher fiscal policy than it currently has, which flies in the face of that.

Quite apart from being a component of the Government's fiscal policy, it is also an important component of the Government's micro-economic reform program. The opposition to it must place a question mark over the Opposition's commitment to rationalise the Commonwealth's assets holdings and to micro-economic reform in general, because there are some difficult decisions which have to be made about this sort of thing. One cannot wish all the difficult problems away by saying, `We will consult with various people about all these issues' and somehow the problems will go away. That was the dreamtime section of Senator Short's speech.

I referred to this particular Bill and the scheme of things relating to the sale of the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline. Under the current arrangements-and Senator Spindler should be aware of this-the Australian taxpayers will effectively continue to subsidise the consumption of gas in New South Wales, unless the current haulage charges are increased. The purpose of this Bill is to provide scope for that.

The rationale for the proposed increase in haulage charges is to put the Pipeline Authority's operations on a commercial footing. Under the current arrangements, the Authority is unable to earn any overall profit on the bulk of its business until 2006. That might be nice for the Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL) and for some consumers in New South Wales, but it is a burden imposed on the Australian taxpayers as a whole. Even after the year 2006, unless legislation of this kind is passed and appropriate charges introduced, the Authority will not be able to earn anything like reasonable profits for 10 years.

The Authority is a significant community asset. It has a total replacement value of approximately $1.3 billion. The Government's view is that it would be an abrogation of its responsibilities to the major equity holders, namely the Australian community, were it to let this situation continue. Putting the Authority on a commercial basis would enable taxpayers to earn a fair and reasonable return on their investment in the pipeline system, valued at its current worth.

I will say a brief word about overriding existing contractual obligations, which was adverted to by Senator Short and by Senator Spindler in his opening remarks. There is no question that overriding the present totally unsatisfactory pricing provisions in the existing contractual arrangements between AGL and the Pipeline Authority is a big step for a government to take. We have admitted that right from the beginning. It is not a step which was taken lightly. In normal circumstances the Government would be very reluctant to alter contractual arrangements of this kind.

I make the point to Senator Short that the imperative of achieving economic reform means that difficult decisions have to be made. It is no good indulging in windy rhetoric about these things; when one finally has to face up to the problems, difficult decisions have to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there is a proper way of going about that.

—It is all very well to say that there are proper ways of going about it, but Senator Short did not mention those, except to say that he would negotiate everything to his satisfaction. When one has, rather than a can of worms, a basket of tiger snakes, which one has to negotiate with-and I am not referring to any particular persons or institutions in saying that--
—What are you referring to?

— I was looking in Senator Bishop's direction when the analogy came to my mind. Apart from that, it is difficult to negotiate some of these matters when there are many vested interests involved. As I say, it is just rhetoric to say that these things can be negotiated with everybody being happy and satisfied. The tariff adjustments proposed by this Bill are the only feasible way to ensure that the economic efficiency of the gas marketing arrangements are improved. That makes for a proper basis for a sale which is fair to the taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition has claimed that if it were in office it would go ahead with the sale of the pipeline. He has to say that because the born-again privatisers on the Opposition side have to continue with that rhetoric irrespective of the difficulties which they might encounter.

I ask rhetorically: is it seriously claimed that it is possible that, instead of pursuing an increase in haulage tariffs by legislation, a voluntary agreement be negotiated for an increase in tariffs? Or should the asset, the Pipeline Authority, be sold under the current totally uneconomic contractual arrangements, which are a burden on taxpayers and do not give them an adequate return on their investment, for a price well below its true worth? These are some of the hard questions which governments have to address; oppositions do not, and particularly Democrats do not-Democrats, who are essentially given to `green cliches over the chardonnay'. The Australian Democrats do not have to address these sorts of questions-they are all care and no responsibility. They never have to exercise any responsibility about anything, even in respect of what they say.

The Opposition is in a position where, theoretically at least, it might have to exercise some responsibility in these matters. These hard questions have to be addressed. If responsibility is to be exercised, the hard questions have to be addressed. We cannot waffle about them; we cannot indulge in cliches.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you consider yourself above the law?

—We cannot indulge in the sort of rhetoric that Senator Bishop indulges in by interjecting. It is all right to be tough in opposition. Sometimes we have to make hard decisions which are a little more than the rhetoric. An asset such as this has to be sold for something like a fair price to the Australian taxpayers. We cannot sell it below its true worth if we have any sense of responsibility at all. This legislation pursuing an increase in haulage tariffs is absolutely necessary. On the basis of experience, we do not believe that a voluntary agreement of the kind referred to can be negotiated.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other issue which has been very much blown up in this debate, and that is the question of tariff charges for New South Wales consumers. In view of the time available, I will not go into all the figures on that issue. We are confronted with a proposition by the Government to get a proper return for the sale of a taxpayers' asset, and the argument put is: that will be unfair to some consumers in New South Wales-a relatively small section of Australian taxpayers-because they have had the benefit of a totally subeconomic activity for a very long period. That is what the Opposition is saying and what the Democrats, by implication, are saying.

I want to put that into perspective. The effects of the proposed haulage rates on a domestic consumer in New South Wales have been calculated as meaning an average 9 per cent increase by 1992. This would amount to 40c a week for a domestic consumer or less than the cost of a daily newspaper and, I think -not being a drinking man-about a third of the cost of a glass of beer in Sydney. Or does a glass of beer cost more than that? Perhaps Mr Clerk would know, or Senator Bjelke-Petersen-a well known bar fly in Sydney-might be able to help me! It would amount to probably a quarter of the cost of a glass of beer per week. That is the estimate of the cost to the domestic consumer. There is ample capacity within the system to negotiate appropriate and proper rates for industrial consumers. I mention that issue because it has been vastly overblown in the public debate.

As I said at the beginning, this relates very much to government fiscal policy; it is an important part of government micro-economic reform. It involves the obligation of a government to sell a taxpayers' asset, if it has made the decision to sell it, at a fair price to Australian taxpayers. It involves that as the prime obligation as distinct from any other obligations to sections of the Australian taxpaying community who, as consumers, have been beneficiaries.

This legislation is essential to get the Pipeline Authority on a proper commercial basis so that taxpayers can get a fair return from its sale. I do not want to sound like Senator Short-I do not want to sound horrified by what the Opposition is saying about this matter. Horror comes to me only late at night. I think what we have heard is just irresponsible in terms of an important piece of legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate for the reasons which I have given.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INCOME) BILL 1990TAXATION (INTEREST ON NON-RESIDENT TRUST DISTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1990TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October and 13 November, on motions by Senator Collins and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today we are debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990, the Taxation (Interest on Non-resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (International Agreements) Bill 1990. Whilst the Opposition will not be opposing these Bills, the legislation is very complex. My colleague Senator Watson will be raising later in this debate a series of specific issues which he raised last week during consideration of the legislation by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment (International Agreements) Bill 1990 aims to give legislative authority to comprehensive double tax agreements which Australia has already signed with China, Sri Lanka and Fiji respectively. The irony of this legislation is that, through the tax sparing concessions, it effectively overrides the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill which we are also debating today. However, we support the reasons for extending tax sparing to these countries, particularly because this will allow Australian investors to compete in these countries on equal terms. Therefore, we fully support the Bill.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill aims to introduce an accrual system of taxing foreign source income that has been derived in low tax countries by Australian controlled entities and that has been accumulated offshore, thus avoiding Australian tax. The Taxation (Interest on Non-resident Trust Distributions) Bill introduces measures to achieve parity between the tax treatment of resident and non-resident trust distributions. The Bill will ensure that the net income of non-resident trusts will be liable to tax either in the hands of the trustee or the beneficiaries in the income year in which it is derived.

The Bills aim to support the foreign tax credit system by closing off the leakage which could have occurred through foreign source income derived in low tax countries being diverted and accumulated offshore in foreign companies and trusts. The Bills set out to tax foreign income and capital gains derived by Australians through foreign companies at a rate of at least 25 per cent when derived. Foreign companies satisfying the active income exemption will be exempted so that Australians carrying on genuine business activities in low tax countries will not be disadvantaged.

The main features of the Bill relate to controlled foreign corporations (CFC's). A foreign company is defined as a CFC if it is controlled by Australian residents. An attributable taxpayer is, broadly, an Australian resident who alone or with associates directly or indirectly holds an interest of 10 per cent or more in the CFC as at the end of the CFC's accounting year. For the purposes of the Bill, countries have been divided into listed and non-listed countries. Effects vary depending on whether countries are listed or non-listed.

Whilst the Opposition has no qualms about the intentions of the Bill, I am not nearly so confident that the approach adopted in this Bill will meet the desired outcome. For example, in trying to ensure that tax is paid on income which has been held in such a way as to avoid tax there is a danger that people will be required to pay tax on income which is not their income and to which they will never have any rights. They may also be restricted in their access to information about that income if it is necessary to dispute an assessment. However, I understand the difficulties in trying to cast a tax net so wide as to cover all the income it is intended to cover but not so wide as to cover income which it should not. This is not a new problem in the field of taxation. The old chestnuts of residence and source will remain in dispute as long as tax is payable, and the complexities of this legislation revolve around conceptually similar problems.

In the time available today it is difficult to present even an effective overview of the Bill. However, there are a couple of broad areas to which I would particularly like to draw attention. The issue of information which must be provided to the Commissioner of Taxation on request is one area of concern. The Bill authorises the Commissioner to issue an offshore information notice in respect of information held offshore. Where the information is not made available to the Commissioner within the time required-generally 90 days, though there is scope for the Commissioner to vary the time limit-any information which is not supplied cannot be used by the taxpayer as evidence to dispute the assessment. This restriction on receiving evidence has been copied from overseas countries such as the United States of America. However, it is notable that the taxpayer protections available in the USA, such as guarantees of due process and prohibitions against searches and seizures, have not been copied in our legislation, and that could leave taxpayers unfairly exposed. That is a matter that the coalition will be monitoring carefully.

I repeat the comments made in the other place by my colleague the honourable member for Curtin, Mr Rocher, when this legislation was being debated-that this is pretty heavy-handed stuff. It potentially denies taxpayers natural justice and goes to the very heart of the separation of government and the judiciary-in this case, the separation of a government agency, the Australian Taxation Office, from the law courts. I also have some concern about the Commissioner's powers to call for multiple assessments. The Commissioner is under no obligation to limit the amount taxed to 100 per cent of a foreign entity's income. Again, this is a factor that we will watch closely once the legislation becomes effective.

The coalition has no quarrels with the aims and intentions of these Bills, but we have serious concerns about the way in which the legislation has been handled, or in some respects mishandled, and the manner in which this Government has chosen again to try to circumvent proper parliamentary scrutiny of its tax legislation. In essence, these Bills carry on a number of traditions which have become hallmarks of the way in which this Government has come to mismanage tax legislation.

The Bills are extremely complex and very lengthy. The explanatory memoranda alone run to over 400 pages, and the Bills themselves to over 230 pages. This is on top of the already greatly overburdened tax system with which Australia is saddled. It is yet another addition to the 26,000 pages of Acts, regulations and court rulings which have been added to taxation material in the last few years. The complexities of our taxation system defy even the highest qualified and best tax experts in the land. Of course, one way of doing away with much of this paperwork in the tax area would be to abolish the anomaly-ridden wholesale sales tax system, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions and fails to tax the services sector.

The coalition has pledged to do just that on its return to office. A broad-based, single rate tax will remove the need for many of the tax rulings and regulations which cannot be avoided under our current ramshackle, indirect tax system. At least on this foreign income Bill the Government has consulted with interested parties before bulldozing ahead with ill-considered proposals. Changes to the tax treatment of foreign source income were first announced in the economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 12 April 1989. The changes were then modified by press release on 17 December, a year ago almost to the day, and further modified by press release on 3 June this year. The draft Bill was released on 29 June-whilst Parliament was in recess, I point out-and it contained still further changes to the 3 June press release. In the Budget on 21 August, further changes to the proposed legislation were announced. Finally, we have these Bills before us today.

This consultation process has had the advantage of highlighting areas in which the June 1990 draft legislation had to be altered. Those consultations led to changes to ensure that opportunities for tax avoidance were closed off and to provide relief in certain circumstances where double taxation would have occurred. This consultation is very welcome, and I hope very much that the Government, through the Tax Office and the Treasury, continues with effective consultation in the future.

In this instance, though, it is not only the consultative process which has slowed finalisation of the legislation; the time it has taken to produce this tortured piece of legislation raises questions about just how necessary it was to make it so complex. There is a question to be looked at and answered. I am not sure what the answer is, but the obvious question is whether we have in fact produced here a sledge-hammer to crack a nut.

As has occurred with so much other tax legislation introduced by this Government, even taxpayers with the best of intentions will have difficulty complying with the law because not all of the changes announced to the draft Bill of June 1990 have been included in this Bill. As has so often occurred in the past, taxpayers will be forced to operate on the basis of announced changes which have not yet been put into the legislation. We are seeing, yet again, the abhorrent practice of legislating by press release; a practice which has become the rule rather than the exception under this Government, particularly under Treasurer Keating.

A number of issues are also still under consideration. They are not minor issues which businesses can disregard in making important decisions about their operations and investment strategies. For example, the Treasurer still has to decide on the application of the trading stock and depreciation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act to a controlled foreign company. He has also to decide on whether the special deductions for capital expenditure associated with domestic mining activities should apply to foreign mining activities that generate assessable income.

How long will it be before Australian businesses can operate in an environment of certainty? The Treasurer, in trying to remove the inequities and inefficiencies caused by a tax system which did not effectively address foreign source income, has created inefficiencies and possible in- equities of his own by leaving so much still undecided. I am concerned that the complexities of this legislation may well lead some businesses to re-incorporate outside Australia or hive off their international operations. This legislation could well distort the locational choices of some businesses. Of course, that ought to be anathema to a country, such as Australia, needing to produce more. It is also contrary to the requirements of an efficient tax system.

I also quickly draw attention to a number of issues of serious concern with have been raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. A number of provisions in the Bill effectively reverse the onus of proof, requiring the taxpayer to prove matters which would normally be considered to be matters for the prosecuting party to prove. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee quite correctly drew attention to these provisions because of the possible implications in terms of trespass on personal rights and liberties.

I also note, as did the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, that the Bill contains a series of provisions which give varied proposed amendments retrospective effect. Importantly, the retrospectivity appears to have the potential to operate prejudicially on taxpayers. This is not the first time, by any means, that the Treasurer has been brought to task by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee for serious breaches of personal rights and liberties in tax legislation, for which he is responsible. The fact that the Treasurer has failed to take account of the legitimate concerns of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is just one more piece of evidence showing his neglect and disregard for the normal parliamentary process.

I would like to conclude with a quote which, I think, sums up the major concerns that the coalition has with the way that this Treasurer has handled changes to the tax system. Many of these problems are, again, evident in the legislation that we are debating today. I quote from a Sydney practitioner who is a member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants. He wrote as follows:

Regrettably the Treasurer has no idea whatsoever or chooses to ignore the time frame necessary to implement complex taxation measures efficiently and effectively. He legislates by proclamation and expects the bureaucracy to write the law, establish departments and draft and print forms and information sheets in wholly unrealistic time constraints. Moreover he expects all accountants and taxpayers to be instantly aware of all ramifications of the law, most of which are mind boggling in their complexity . . . . Unless all concerned are given a breathing space, inside three years, the system will be wholly unintelligible to any one other than those who devote all their time to reading and digesting new legislation and tax rulings and attending seminars.
As I said earlier, even people who do that find it almost impossible to keep up with and comprehend the complexities of the current tax system. He went on as follows:
Errors must occur in the compilation of returns which creates a serious situation, particularly in light of the unforgiving imposition of penalties.
I think that is a very important quote. It sums up the feelings and understanding that a lot of us receive from not only tax practitioners but also the general community.

The tax law is a very difficult area. It is very complex. We ought to be looking at ways to overcome that. The tax simplification document that was produced last week does not even start to look at the issues involved in really making a meaningful attack on the complexities of the tax law. It almost seems that the Government has run out of thoughts as to where it can possibly go with tax simplification. It is a matter of great urgency that all parties need to address.
While we do not seek to oppose the Bills, we certainly hope that, where problems such as I have just mentioned surface, they will be dealt with expeditiously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990, the Taxation (Interest on Non-resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990 and the Taxation Laws Amendment (International Agreements) Bill 1990. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill. We will be moving one amendment which seeks to strengthen this tax havens legislation. We will be opposing the three amendments which the Opposition moved in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and which I understand it may move again in this chamber as widening the anti-tax avoidance provision in this tax havens legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This tax havens legislation has been developed since the Government's original announcement in its May 1988 economic statement. Draft legislation was issued in December 1989 to elicit further public comment. A further draft was issued in June 1990 which was amended substantially before the current legislation was introduced. While I agree with Senator Short that the Bill is extremely voluminous, far-reaching and complex, the Government has made some attempt at consultation. Many issues remain unresolved. Further substantial legislation will be introduced by way of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) and I expect we will see further amendments next year.

The current system of taxing foreign source income earned by Australian residents is quite comprehensive. All business and investment income is taxable, with a credit granted for any foreign tax paid. However, one loophole exists: it is possible to interpose a foreign entity-for instance, a company or trust-between the Australian resident and the income earning activity. For example, if Telecom Australia won a contract to install a telephone network in Oman, its profit would be taxable in Australia. Any tax paid in Oman would be allowed as a credit against the Australian tax. However, if Telecom created a subsidiary-for instance, Telecom Oman Limited-which performed the contract and earned the profit, no Australian tax would be payable on that income until it was remitted to Australia as a dividend. Consequently, there is a positive disincentive to remit overseas profits, and a concomitant advantage in sourcing income into low tax jurisdictions.

Needless to say, such a tax structure-especially when it is reinforced by a low withholding tax rate on income remitted from Australia-tends to promote a large net income deficit. Currently, the net income deficit is the major component of our current account deficit. It represents 70 per cent. The legislation proposes to introduce an accruals system of taxing foreign source income that has been earned in low tax countries by Australian controlled entities. That is, the tax applies whether or not income is remitted to Australia, and so it should. This is achieved by attributing to the Australian resident shareholders their proportionate share of the income earned by the controlled foreign entity.

The legislation has been painstakingly designed not to interfere with the legitimate business activities of Australian controlled businesses operating overseas. Consequently, only certain income, known as tainted income, is liable to attribution to the Australian shareholders. However, attribution is not automatic. It occurs only when the controlled foreign company fails the active income tax exemption test. Attribution occurs only when the tainted income is 5 per cent or more of total turnover.

In our view, this is a very generous ratio; indeed, too generous a ratio. For example, it means that a company with a turnover of $1 billion will be able to derive $50m profit or interest without risking attribution. Whilst being a small amount of turnover, this may represent a very large proportion of the profit of the business.

The 5 per cent figure was chosen when the proposed attribution related to all of the income of the controlled foreign company, not just the tainted income which is now the case. Consequently, in the Democrats view there is scope to reduce the ratio. I will be moving an amendment during the Committee stage of the debate to reduce the ratio down to 2 per cent.

A further companion amendment will impose a dollar ceiling amount of $5m over which all tainted income is automatically attributed. Given the recent Committee hearing, I do not think that these amendments will be accepted by the Government. However, the Government has said that it will keep the ratio under review, which does offer some hope for future action in this area. It leaves the question open: what is the rationale for the 5 per cent that the Government wishes to use as against 2 per cent, which would give a substantial increase to revenue which otherwise Australian taxpayers have to find? It seems to us that where there is doubt, the doubt should be resolved in favour of the Australian taxpayer.

The answer the Minister gave in the Committee was that we do not wish to undermine companies currently operating overseas. I do not think that really holds water. If we wish to support the activities of companies which contribute to our export income, then we should do so in a targeted and direct manner rather than in a broad based manner which disadvantages the Australian taxpayer as a whole.

A much tougher regime is proposed by the Government for controlled foreign trusts as against controlled foreign companies, with which I have been dealing. This is reasonable given that, as a rule, companies are necessary for legitimate business purposes, whereas trusts are invariably chosen to avoid tax or other regulations. A transferor trust regime is to be established. The unspoken but obvious intention is to totally discourage the use of offshore discretionary trusts. From an anti-tax avoidance perspective, this seems reasonable. Limited exemptions are granted in respect of some family arrangements. It is accepted that such exceptions are necessary.

Senator Watson will not move the amendments, but he will deal with them in his address to the Senate. The Australian Democrats made it quite clear during the Committee hearings that they would not support these amendments.

The regime proposes to attribute the attributable income of a non-resident discretionary trust to the Australian resident who transferred property to the trust. Basically the trust is ignored and the Australian resident is taxed on the income as if it were derived by the resident. This is a severe measure, yet the tax avoidance opportunities of foreign trusts warrant such a response in the Democrats view.

In keeping with this harsh treatment, no active income exemption is allowed for controlled foreign trusts. Basically any income which is not taxed in a comparable country will be attributed to the transferor unless it is otherwise taxable in Australia.

As an additional measure, where a resident beneficiary earns income from a controlled foreign trust which has not been attributed nor taxed on a current basis in Australia, then additional tax in the nature of an interest charge will be payable in certain circumstances. The sole purpose of the Taxation (Interest on Non-Resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990 is to impose this interest charge. Constitutional provisions require a separate Act of Parliament. This measure simply negates any advantage that deferring distribution of income and hence tax liability would otherwise provide.

I have already dealt briefly with our position regarding the Opposition's amendments. I simply conclude by saying that the Australian Democrats believe there are too many loose ends to this legislation. No doubt we will be amending it for the next year at least, but this is best dealt with by the Government than through attempts on our behalf.

We accept one point made in Senator Watson's third amendment, which deals with the possibility of double taxation. We understand that that is a problem. However, it seems to us that rather than remove the liability from the company in anticipation of the possible event that the company may become liable to tax in the foreign country, we should ask the Government to provide an opportunity to allow subsequent credit once it is found that a company has, indeed, been fixed with a foreign tax liability in the other country.

I also draw the Senate's attention to a recent article by Colleen Ryan which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 8 December 1990. The article is entitled `Half News Corp Profit earned in the Caribbean Tax Havens'. This is the sort of result that this Bill is intended to overcome. In general terms, I commend the Government for bringing in these provisions.

I will briefly turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment (International Agreements) Bill 1990. This Bill will insert three new schedules to the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953. The schedules are comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and China, Sri Lanka and Fiji respectively. The agreements follow the general provisions of Australia's existing double taxation agreements and provide taxation certainty which enhances trade, investment and broader relations between Australia and the other parties to the agreements. In general terms, we are supportive of these agreements. I simply ask: is this the time to advance relations between Australia, on the one hand, and China and Fiji in particular, on the other, in view of the international human rights record of those countries? I commend the package of Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity of congratulating you, Senator Calvert, on the capable manner in which you have presided over the affairs of the Senate during this session.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before, and I will say it again today, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill is one of the most complex sets of amendments ever to find their way into taxation law, masking even the capital gains changes which the courts have described as unintelligible at times, confusing, badly drafted and a nightmare of interpretation. We need to get a better mechanism or linkage between the court system and the Parliament in order to overcome the concerns of the courts in their interpretation. We should have a mechanism to implement legislation that picks up judiciary concerns.

This legislation runs counter to all the very high principles of tax simplification that I strongly endorsed during the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration last Friday. For example, many of the attribution tests are too draconian, particularly for innocent shareholders. This is particularly so in circumstances where Australian residents are unaware that foreign companies are controlled by other Australians. People who might be listening to this debate, or readers of this debate, should be aware that the whole purpose of the Bill is to correct certain perceived tax avoidance measures. The Opposition is concerned about the draconian way in which some of these issues are handled.

The technical aspects of the legislation were reviewed in a detailed way in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I refer people who have an interest in this matter to the Committee debate on 14 December where the technical aspects were discussed. I also remind the Senate that during the Committee hearing the Liberal-National Party coalition moved five significant amendments, which were lost. In accordance with the agreement we made in setting up the hearing by that Committee, the Opposition will not be putting those amendments for a vote today. Readers of this debate should be aware of the issues that were raised and that the amendments were lost.

I take this opportunity to thank all those people who were associated with the hurriedly convened meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Friday, 14 December. That gave us a valuable opportunity to discuss this legislation, despite the application of the guillotine arrangements applying to Bills within this chamber. I thank the Committee Chairman, Senator Coates, Senator McMullan, and also officers of the Australian Taxation Office for coming along, answering our questions and agreeing to take so many of the others on notice. We look forward to their responses later on.

I would also like to state that not all overseas businesses are involved in the tax avoidance industry, which so often seems to be implied in debates on tax avoidance. For example, it has come to my attention that the National Australia Bank has rejected lucrative proposals for certain tax effective forms of lending because the schemes were outside the spirit of the law. So not everybody is associated with tax avoidance.

Unfortunately, there are anomalies in this legislation, some of which we addressed during the committee stage of the debate last Friday. I think further anomalies will emerge after the enactment of this legislation, when industry has had a full opportunity to evaluate the ramifications of this wide-ranging legislation. There has been over two years of extensive consultation on this legislation.

This legislation is set apart from most other legislation in that there has been wide community input. That is reflected in the fact that this is the third or perhaps fourth draft of this legislation. I note the cooperation of all the parties that have been involved in trying to get this legislation as correct as possible, having regard to the need to minimise opportunities for tax avoidance. Of course, this has not been done without cost. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that it has cost the Treasury at least $33,000 in outside consultants' fees alone.

Some Australian corporations operating overseas will be adversely affected. Those that particularly come to mind that I have some concern about are those in the resource area. We call on the Government adequately to address such issues in subsequent legislation in order to-and I continually refer to this-enhance the integrity of tax law. I think we have to acknowledge that this legislation is but the first in a series of Bills which cover foreign companies.

It is interesting to note that a Bill has already been introduced in the other House, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6), which addresses a number of issues in relation to the foreign income area. Over the past 18 months we have seen this legislation change and expand. It has grown from 119 pages of proposed legislation plus explanatory memoranda, to 221 pages in June and 236 pages before us now. Unfortunately, the regulations have not yet been determined and one can only hazard a guess as to what the extent of the regulations will be when we consider that the explanatory memoranda now exceed 416 pages. I must explain that draft regulations were included in the explanatory memoranda of the earlier draft, but unfortunately they have not been included in the Bill before the Senate. The Liberal-National Party coalition therefore calls on the Government for the early release of those regulations to apply and be backdated to 1 July, which is the commencement date of this Bill.

While a degree of complexity in legislation may be essential in the interests of maintaining certainty and equity in the tax regime, I think this Bill has created the reverse situation. This present legislation builds complexity on complexity. The result is that even the simplest amendments give rise to almost unending consequential changes, which is a sure recipe for uncertainty and confusion. I acknowledge that there has been widespread consultation-and that is good and I encourage it for the future-resulting in major improvements compared with the original draft Bill. However, I draw the Senate's attention to an unfortunate comment that appears in the second reading speech-that complexity is the price taxpayers and their advisers must pay for the consultation process. Such an attitude to taxpayers is, I think, unfortunately more reminiscent of despotism than democracy.

Since interpretation is not easy or straightforward, complex legislation of this kind will merely enlarge the coffers of tax lawyers and accountants. While these are honourable professions, the creation of a forced market for their services adds nothing to Australia's real economic output. Further, complex legal, penal legislation has the unfortunate effect of undermining not only respect for the Parliament, but also, more seriously, respect for the law. The law comes to be despised by those who do not understand it because they are presumed to understand the incomprehensible and are subject to its penalties, and by those who do understand it because they see it as an overreaching intrusion into their personal affairs.

In order for legislation to be fully effective, an appropriate public education campaign or program must be conducted by the Australian Taxation Office. Without such an understanding of the provisions of legislation and their practical effect, particularly in a self-assessment environment, the effect of the provisions will be fairly limited. Even with knowledge of the law, how many taxpayers can be sure, for example, that they will never be deemed to be transferors to or beneficiaries of foreign trusts whose existence they remain totally unaware of? I think that is a real problem with the legislation that we have before us.

Another matter that I see as being of great concern is the unintended consequences in the area of capital gains. It may now be necessary to obtain variations of offshore assets held on 1 July 1990, as all offshore assets now come within the capital gains tax for controlled foreign companies. Previously, only assets acquired after 19 September 1985 were subject to tax on disposal. To be consistent with the general capital gains tax philosophy of non-retrospectivity, the Bill should apply only to assets acquired after July 1990. In certain quarters, this Bill has been viewed not only as an attack on certain avoidance transactions, but as outright aggression by the Government against large companies. To the extent that that view is prevalent, I think it is unfortunate.
