I would also like to refer honourable senators to a submission on this Bill by Mr Terrence Dwyer, a former senior adviser in the taxation and income security section of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. He made a submission to the Selection of Bills Committee. He stated forcefully that he does not see this Bill as advancing Australia's long term interests. I think that is an important point of view. In fact, it is a point of view that is shared by the Business Council of Australia.

However, the coalition believes that to further delay this legislation will be counterproductive, given that the decision has been made that Australia requires such complex provisions and those provisions have been largely operating from 1 July 1990. The coalition asks that this legislation be placed on the statute books before Christmas. There is a need to establish some certainty before the law, and this process will help ensure that, rather than further delay the matter. Nevertheless, there are a number of very clear anomalies which mean that certain sections of Australian industry could be adversely affected. I call on the Government to recognise these problems as they occur and to introduce legislation or support amendments promptly as these problems arise.

The legislation before us presents specific problems for the banking industry. Previous foreign tax exemption regimes treated overseas branches and subsidiaries of Australian corporations in the same manner. This foreign source legislation distinguishes between branches and subsidiaries. Australian resident banks operating overseas generally operate through a branch network because it enables them to raise their funds more cheaply and overcomes the necessity of Australian banks to establish substantial capital in various overseas centres where the subsidiaries or corporations operate.

The solution is to give the banks an income exemption. The Government alleges that the banks should not be worse off under the foreign tax credit system. However, not to be worse off, the banks will need to incorporate their branches. Possible disadvantages for the banks will stem from this requirement, because some overseas countries will not allow foreign banks to incorporate for prudential reasons. Secondly, it will result in an unnecessarily arduous administrative burden for the banks. Overall, it appears that the legislation will not mean a lot of additional tax for the banks, but they will be required to change their normal commercial, non-tax avoiding arrangements, and this will make them less competitive and will raise the cost of finance to them.

Some of the banks have small subsidiary arrangements in centres such as Singapore, Hong Kong and Jersey. Generally they are not there for tax avoidance purposes but for deposit taking and fund raising. The problem seems to be that the Government and the Australian Taxation Office, and certainly some committees of this Parliament, do not really understand what is going on. The concern is that such transactions will become open areas of manipulation. Consultation has occurred with the banks resulting in some concessions-and I thank the Government for that. However, the point is that these concessions are not working and do not appear to work. Hopefully, the Government will be called upon to address these issues in the next amending Bill, which will probably come into the Parliament during the autumn session next year.

I believe that the Government's preoccupation with the Bill has arisen as a result of the tremendous outflow of funds arising from deregulation. Perhaps this has warped the thinking to some extent, because I think it was wrongly perceived that most of this money or outflow was actually tax avoidance money. In many cases, it was merely a case of companies, having outgrown the scope of the Australian market, seeking investment opportunities overseas.

Another matter of concern is that this Bill is retrospective. I believe that not enough time has been given since 13 September, when this present Bill was introduced, for businesses to comprehend what is now being introduced. In fact, one of our amendments lost at the committee stage last Friday sought to overcome one of the retrospective provisions. The legislation before us proposes that the Bill become law as from 1 July 1990. The second draft, with its extra 100 pages or so, was issued on 27 June. Three days, including a weekend, is certainly not long enough for a business with overseas interests to read, digest and put its house in order. I regard as even more horrific the fact that the September version of the Bill introduced changes on which no warning whatsoever was given, in particular the changes that occurred in relation to the non-resident trust provisions.

Senator McMullan, who is the Government Minister overseeing this Bill, stated in a reported interview in the Taxation in Australia magazine that given the earlier wider debate plenty of notice has been given about the new provisions and that it is not appropriate to announce a commencement date, even if that date precedes parliamentary approval. But I reiterate that three days notice-and we now have further changes, with further changes still to come-is not regarded as plenty of notice.

The retrospective aspect of the Bill does not stop with the 1 July commencement date. The provisions of the Bill with regard to the trust transfer tax measures apply to transfers made at any time before the Bill becomes law and can even apply theoretically to transactions which occurred before Federation or outside Australia. A tax adviser has indicated to me that the Bill casts its net so wide that it catches transactions which cannot possibly be regarded as resulting in any avoidance of Australian tax.

I give honourable senators a couple of examples. An Australian-born United Kingdom resident has dual UK-Australian tax residence by virtue of maintaining a pastoral property and residence which he visits annually. This person, who is regarded as a UK resident under the UK-Australian tax treaty because his home is in the UK, created a trust in Jersey in 1936. The income of that trust will now be subject to Australian transferor tax measures. It is irrelevant that the money which comprised the trust was never in Australia and that the trust is dealt with under UK law or that the person may not be regarded as an Australian tax resident because of the tax treaty.

My second example concerns a business migrant who comes to Australia from Hong Kong, where he set up a family trust in 1949. On the migrant taking up residence in Australia, the Bill could deem the income of that family trust to be part of his taxable income in Australia, even though he has no rights to it, notwithstanding that the trust funds never came to Australia and that the trust was set up before he came to Australia, before Australia had such legislation and even before he, as a migrant, thought that he might ultimately reside here. It has been intimated to me that, for clarity to be obtained in this area, appeals to the High Court of Australia will certainly occur. Unfortunately, how many taxpayers can really afford to do that.

While on the topic of family trusts, I mention another aspect that was in the June draft. The Bill gave an exemption for transfers to non-resident family trusts whose only beneficiaries were non-resident family members. That exemption was narrow enough but has been removed in the Bill before the Parliament.

Another problem is that the Commissioner of Taxation must be satisfied that indigent relatives are not being given too much money. I believe it is morally offensive that, on the one hand, a government gives millions of dollars in foreign aid but, on the other hand, someone wanting to help overseas relatives is limited in so doing by the Commissioner and has to prove that the relatives need help. The Bill allows an amnesty in the area of a non-resident family trust.There is a tax concession in the area of resident trust to encourage people to come forward. In the first instance, the amnesty applies not only to the income but also to the capital component. The second problem is that there could be an application of part IVA of the Act, the general anti-avoidance provisions. The tax amnesty providing a reduced tax rate of 10 per cent is unlikely to bring forth a significant flow of funds. In fact, it could even initiate a Taxation Office investigation going back as far as the original shifting of the funds offshore.

Another objectionable aspect of the Bill is its evidentiary rule regarding offshore information notices. The coalition sought to remove this provision because it believed that there were other adequate provisions in the Act to cope with section 264a. The Opposition does not believe in giving draconian powers to a government when there are adequate measures elsewhere in the Act, especially in view of the constitutional and other issues that proposed section 264a raises.

Given that the onus of proof is already heavily on the taxpayer in dispute over tax assessment, why should the courts be prevented from examining all the evidence? Parliament has in fact amended the Acts Interpretation Act to enable the courts to look at extrinsic aids to interpretation of legislation. Why should we now seek to prevent the courts from reading all that relevant information? The doctrine of the separation of legislative and judicial powers does appear in this legislation to be going at something of a discount. I mentioned at the committee stage how I felt this undermined respect for the law.

This legislation in many aspects is really an adoption of what operates in the United States. However, in the United States the rights of US taxpayers are protected. Australia has not incorporated the protections given to taxpayers as the US has done. For example, the US Constitution prohibits retrospective legislation, guarantees due process of law and imposes strict requirements on searches and seizures. A taxpayer's Bill of rights has also been adopted recently in response to perceived abuses by the US inland reven- ue system.

The Bill also raises problems for Australia's foreign relations and trade as well as other areas of international cooperation. In fact, the Bill lists countries as being either acceptable or unacceptable tax havens. Originally, there was a long list of countries which related roughly to tax haven status. After representations by the business community regarding legitimate business activities, we now have tainted and active income.

The listing of countries as acceptable or unacceptable tax havens raises concerns and problems in my mind with regard to Australia's relations in trade as well as others areas of international cooperation, such as mutual legal assistance, extradition and so on. Australia basically is telling over 150 countries that they are unacceptable tax havens; of the remaining 60 or so, most have unacceptable tax haven features in their law, including several of Australia's tax treaty partners. I think that is an unfortunate approach, which can rightly be inferred from this legislation.

Australia is proposing that whenever such identified tax havens exist, it will assert the right to tax tainted income of entities in those countries which are owned, controlled or associated directly or indirectly with Australians. Thus Australia will impose tax on the foreign income of foreign entities and collect it by formally imposing the liability on Australians deemed to be in receipt of income from those entities.

One can expect that foreign countries may well resent such a high-handed approach to taxation income arising within their borders or from entities in their jurisdiction. This idea has not received wide international acceptance, notwithstanding the fact that it was adopted by a few capital exporting countries. Australia is basically therefore placing a black ban on Australian passive investment in most of the rest of the world. Consequently, Australia should not expect those countries to assist when we seek help in such matters as tariff reductions, extradition, access to evidentiary information, et cetera. These countries can be expected to resent this Bill's de facto extraterritorial taxation of income arising within their borders to entities under their jurisdiction. That resentment may translate into non-cooperation on a wide range of issues; for example, it could endanger Australia's attempt to secure modern extradition treaties or to enforce legislation in respect of insider trading where there is a foreign nexus.

Honourable senators may well ask whether Australia's best long term interests are being served by such extraterritorial legislation, which seeks to assert taxing rights over the foreign income of foreign entities. We should also remember that basically this country is a capital importing country. At the same time-to counteract this-we are encouraging Australian companies to expand overseas, but this Bill will impose a large, arduous administrative burden on them. The overall effect will be to discourage overseas investment by Australian companies and foreign entities investing in Australia.

Further, the unilateral attempt by Australia to override its tax treaties with other countries should be of concern. I noticed today-and I will not have time to comment-that Australia is implementing tax treaties with a number of other countries. The legislation before us will, in part, override some of those tax treaties. I understand that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development recently expressed objection to the unilateral use of domestic legislation to override tax treaties; again that is an unfortunate aspect of this legislation.

If Australia feels that tax treaties are not to its advantage, it is free to give notice of termination to other countries as prescribed in the particular treaties and unilaterally override a different proposition. The Australian Parliament can abrogate its international treaty obligation if it wishes to do so, but one would have thought that such legislation belonged to other, less civilised places. I refer specifically to page 157, subdivision (b), where the double tax arrangements are to be disregarded.

I would like to add my voice to the fact that this Bill, like so many other tax Bills before us, gives a large amount of discretionary power to the Commissioner of Taxation. That is an issue that should quickly be rectified in the tax simplification process. I hope the Government will take on board the need for legislative backing for this tax simplification process during the autumn session before June 1991. I find the use of discretionary power in this Bill unfortunate. I think it is fundamentally wrong that Parliament should abrogate such power to an unelected and personally unaccountable official, given the nature of the discretions provided in this Bill.

Other opportunities exist for multiple assessments, which could be raised as a result of the unfettered discretion of the Commissioner, and I believe that is unfortunate. Time precludes a more thorough evaluation of this, but I would like to finish by asking: why, as a capital importing country, is Australia adopting a Fortress Australia mentality? Why is Australia constructing a tax regime which does not encourage Australians to invest overseas? At present there is not enough incentive for Australians with accumulations in lowly taxed foreign countries to remit money to Australia. Why in some instances are Australians being penalised more harshly for investing overseas than in home-based operations? Are there not too many new discretions in this legislation, given the Government's move to remove them from the Act? Why is it necessary to have a predisposition to collect the last cent of every dollar, creating an unnecessary complex Act? Why not a simpler approach; for example, even adopting such things as a high integrity clearing certification system? The Bill has a number of defects, but despite those, and because the business community in this country which operates overseas wishes to get something in place, we do not oppose these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — I thought in responding to this debate I should start by outlining what the legislation is about, otherwise anybody listening might not be fully cognisant because a lot of the debate has been about peripheral matters. I will then respond to some of these matters without unduly duplicating the extensive discussion that took place last Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in particular to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill because that is the principal Bill before us and the one which has been the subject of most discussion. It has to be seen in the context of an ongoing program of reform of the tax system. It is a very important piece in the Government's long term program of reform of the tax system. It has a fundamental objective and the detail of it cannot properly be assessed without consideration of that objective. That is, it is a question of ensuring that honest taxpayers in Australia do not have to pay a higher level of tax to deliver the services that Australians require of their government because others who should be paying are improperly avoiding their responsibilities through the use of artificial devices, some of which relate to questions of foreign income and issues that are generally called tax havens.

When one talks about taxpayers' rights and the need to protect those rights-I do not denigrate that concept-it is important to realise that the fundamental right of taxpayers which this Bill is designed to protect is that of the overwhelmingly majority of the Australian taxpayers not to have to subsidise almost inevitably more wealthy people who are avoiding their proper responsibilities and transferring them to the rest of the honest, ordinary Australian working men and women paying their pay as you earn tax every fortnight.

That is fundamentally what this Bill is about and it has not had much mention. Until one takes that into account, one cannot assess the details of what I acknowledge is a very complex piece of legislation. There are a number of issues that will need ongoing debate and some that will need to be reviewed over the years as this Bill develops, is implemented and administered and as we see its practical outcomes.

I refer to the claim that in some way this has not been a properly considered matter. Senator Short, in summing up his remarks, quoted a New South Wales accountant. I would love to debate some of the issues to which that accountant referred in another debate because we do not have time now.

The overall intention of that summation, which obviously did not refer to this bit of the legislation-nor did very much else that Senator Short said; I will come back to that in a moment-gave the impression that it had all been too quick and that no-one had had enough time to adjust. The proposals which we are implementing now were first announced in April 1989. It is true that there have been changes of important detail since that time, but the fundamental principles are unchanged. There has been a number of subsequent press statements, draft Bills and, I would contend, the most comprehensive consultation ever seen in Australia on taxation legislation.

The Bill, as has been said, introduces an accrual system of taxing foreign source income that has been derived in low tax countries by Australian controlled entities and has been accumulated offshore. To divert to Senator Watson's conclusion, it is not an attack upon those countries. Those countries are entitled to structure their tax system as they choose. It is saying that Australians who avoid through artificial means the laws of Australia by misusing the laws of those countries will not be given the opportunity artificially thereby to transfer their responsibility to other Australians. It is not a piece of extraterritorial legislation at all.

The consultative process has led to a number of significant changes; for example, the control rule and active income tests were not features of the first consultative document at all. But those who leap in and condemn the complexity of the legislation have to take into account that some of that complexity arises not simply from the process of consultation. I do not think it is fair to say that we are criticising people and saying, `This is the price you have to pay for consultation'. We do say, quite accurately, that a number of people came forward and sought changes, sought compromises, in the way the legislation operated in their interests and in what they perceived as the broader interests of the Australian economy.

In the negotiation of those compromises, inevitably the Bill became more complex; in many ways I think better, and that indicates simple is not always best. The total misunderstanding of the concept of simplification that seems to be around is that somehow or other we can magically have a simple tax system. We will not have that. At the end of the simplification process, we will still have a complicated tax system. The simplification process is about taking out the unnecessary complications and complexities and reducing the burdens of compliance cost.

Those consultative processes are continuing. They are suggesting further improvements and areas of concern, and we are continuing to examine them. As Senator Watson said, some of those concerns are dealt with in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.6), which the Senate will be dealing with early next year, and some others were dealt with in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearing, including one raised by Senator Watson and referred to today by Senator Spindler concerning the possibility of a problem with double tax, which is a question with which we will have to deal in the future. I acknowledged that at the time.

I wanted to put those broad questions of the underlying principles on the table first before I dealt with the comments of the speakers in the second reading debate. First of all, I should thank all the speakers for the fact that they supported the legislation. I think that is important. It is also important for all Australian taxpayers affected to know, whatever reservations individuals have about details-the Australian Democrats have different reservations from those of the coalition, but reservations nonetheless-that what the Bill is trying to achieve has the unanimous support of this Parliament. That is an important point for people to remember.

I will not spend so much time responding to what I thought were actually the more substantial contributions from Senator Spindler and Senator Watson, because we have had a substantial opportunity already to have that discussion. If people want to refer to that detail, the Hansard of Friday's Committee hearing is available to them. I will deal with some of those important questions, but not in such length as I did on Friday.

I do want to deal with some of the things Senator Short said in what I thought was a masterful display of ignorance about the tax system as a whole and this Bill in particular. I really think that he needs someone else to write his speeches on tax matters because he got some things wrong and some things were entirely gratuitously offensive. Obviously, he made some points that were accurate, and I broadly put those under the heading of `the need to watch closely the development of this legislation'. I think that is correct. I think we all share that view.

He then want on to wax eloquent about how this legislation has been mishandled, how there were attempts to circumvent parliamentary scrutiny, et cetera. I have to say that that is entirely untrue and ill-founded. I am not actually sure of what he was talking about, unless it refers to the point he came back to later about the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills about which he is fundamentally wrong. If he is saying that in some way the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not respond to the concerns of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, he is wrong. He just has insulted the Senate by failing to do the most fundamental homework, such as looking at what the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has said. We have had correspondence with members of the Committee. It is true that we have not agreed with everything the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has put to us-and if it expects that it is praying for miracles-but there has been substantial consultation and it has in fact thanked us for the consultative process which we have undertaken with regard to this matter. What Senator Short said was just one of those throw away jibes that people think they can get away with. Sometimes they can, because nobody who knows the truth is listening. His misfortune is that this time we were listening, and he might need to give a bit more consideration to what he says.

He then went on about how complex and lengthy the whole tax system is and quoted from sources saying that it was getting more voluminous. I have heard those quotes before, because he is reading from the same source as a lot of other people. But at the very same time the Opposition is saying that the tax system is getting more voluminous and that we are getting extra legislation, court determinations and more rulings, we are getting proper, sensible requests from a lot of people for more rulings. It is said that we need to expedite the process and provide more resources so that we can give more rulings. Senator Watson has been raising that point; he is quite right. But we cannot have it both ways; we cannot have more rulings and less output. It does not work like that. The rules of arithmetic still apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never said that.

—I am not saying that Senator Watson did. He is consistent. He just needs to advise this ignoramus who has walked in that the outcome cannot be like that. If we want more rulings-and that is a sensible thing to request-we will not wind up with the whole thing being shorter.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think that the terminology that Senator McMullan used towards Senator Short is quite unparliamentary, and I ask him to withdraw it.
—Senator McMullan, it might help proceedings if you withdraw that.

—It never occurred to me that the word `ignoramus' was unparliamentary, but if it is I will withdraw it. The fact of the matter is that this is necessarily complex legislation, because we are dealing with a fundamentally complex issue. We are dealing with a situation where a diverse range of taxpayers have gone about doing two things, both of which need to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: We should remember the objectives of the Bill-that is, to make sure that all income is taxed once and none of it is taxed twice; and to parallel that to ensure that those Australian companies which are seeking to go about legitimate business in unlisted countries can do that on an equal basis with companies based in all other countries in the world, and that they can compete equally with countries of other origin operating under other tax systems.

Therefore, we are trying to achieve a difficult balance between competing demands to ensure that we crack down on tax avoidance, to ensure that we do not do so in a way that is unfair to Australians by taxing them twice and to ensure that we do so in a way that does not preclude Australian business from efficiently and competitively carrying out its responsibilities and rights in overseas countries.

That is why it is complex. I do not apologise for the complexity. It is legislation that will continue to be reviewed but it will not, as a consequence, become simpler. It may become better but it will not become simpler. Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) will certainly not make the system simpler, although I think it will make it better.

Let me refer to two things that Senator Spindler said. We properly debated the other matters last week. One is not related to this Bill but it is related to his assertion about economic policy overall and about the net income deficit. Anybody who imagines that the Australian net income deficit is driven by the tax system fails to understand that the net income deficit arises inevitably and inexorably from the fact that we have something called debt and, therefore, we pay interest. It is not a tax-driven outcome; it is the inevitable consequence of other economic factors and quite separate. It is not, I regret to say, likely to be affected by this legislation. This legislation has many virtues but that is not one of them.

The second important point which Senator Spindler made and which I need to respond to now or in the committee stage-I will do it now to save time-is his proposed amendment to deal with the definition of tainted income. It is a bit disappointing that we find ourselves in the position of dealing with this amendment. I thought that we went through that valuable but lengthy and difficult-in terms of organisation of people's schedules-committee stage on Friday so that we would not have to take up the limited time available today in dealing with those amendments. Nevertheless, let me respond to Senator Spindler's point.

In the Committee last Friday I said-and I repeat it now-that the 5 per cent limit that has been established does not have some magical quality which says, `Here is the overwhelming objective evidence that says 5 per cent is the perfect rate'. Nobody can say that in advance. I suspect that, even after the evidence is in over several years, nobody will be able to say that there is a perfect level-and whether it is 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 or 7 per cent everybody will have his or her view. But what one can say is that 2 per cent is too low, that 7 per cent would be too high, and that somewhere in the middle is about right.

We are balancing the two factors I mentioned before-the need to have the level set sufficiently low that avoidance is properly caught, and also set at a sufficient level that Australian companies trying to carry out bona fide businesses can operate in these areas, particularly in their early years when they may have a larger element of tainted income than would be the case in later years because of the necessary capital requirements in the early stages of conducting a business.

We will not be accepting the amendment. Two per cent is too low to achieve the second of those objectives and, therefore, we think that 5 per cent is as good a balance as can be struck. I do not want to give it any higher justification than that. We have balanced competing pressures and we have come to what is generally regarded as a fair compromise. I think we should stick to it.

Senator Watson raised a lot of detailed points. If I took up my full half-hour I could deal with them all, but that would not allow Senator Spindler sufficient time to deal with his amendment in the committee stage, et cetera. I do not want to take all that time and virtually close the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you be incorporating some answers today from the committee stage?

—I did want to refer to that question of answers. I will not be incorporating them today, but I will be making them available by the end of the week to Senator Watson. If subsequently Senator Watson wants them incorporated, then I am happy to do that and we can deal with that later. I will certainly make the answers substantially available by the end of the week, and then others as they become available.
—Would it be possible for you to incorporate them yourself, because I think the answers are part and parcel of this debate and this package?

—Let us deal with that subsequently. I am happy to look at what the procedural options are on that. It is hard to know to which of the points that Senator Watson raised I should respond in the time available. It might be better if I deal with some of those that did not come up so much on Friday. For example, there is concern about the innocent shareholder who may be caught without knowing whether the company with which he or she is associated is a controlled foreign company. The mechanism in the Bill that is designed to ensure that minor contributors are not caught is that shareholders either alone or with associates must hold 10 per cent of a company for attribution to occur. It is commonly regarded, and I think appropriately, that it would be very unusual for a person to have a holding of this magnitude without having some level of knowledge of the nature and operations of the company in which he or she was investing. So we have endeavoured to address that. Time may show that the mechanism is not appropriate. On the evidence, I think it is, and we will continue to support it until we get further information.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about capital gains because there is a potential for misunderstanding, although I doubt that Senator Watson misunderstands. The Bill applies to all assets, but only to movements in value after 30 June 1990. I think it strikes the appropriate balance once again. It would be either very complex or very discriminatory to try to move towards some other proposal. The original proposal was to apply capital gains tax only to assets acquired after 19 September 1985 and not have a valuation date. However, in the process of consultation the clear view was that that form of grandfathering was not the preferred mechanism, and the Government was not prepared to look at alternative grandfathering mechanisms. Therefore, the valuation date mechanism seems to be an effective one and deals with the concerns that otherwise might properly have been raised.

I do not regard the Bill as one that has elements of retrospectivity that should cause concern. We debated that mainly in the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Senator Watson made a comment and moved an amendment at the Committee hearing relating to non-resident family trusts. This Bill certainly deals with non-resident family trusts in a different way from the draft Bill. The evidence that became available after the release of the draft Bill was that, firstly, there was a loophole in the June Bill and, secondly, people were assiduously trying to re-arrange their affairs such that they would exploit that loophole. We have closed it. I make absolutely no apologies for acting in that way. We would obviously do the same again in similar circumstances. I have the same view about the issue of the offshore notice amendment, which was another matter debated extensively on Friday and the subject of an Opposition amendment. We stand by the proposed section 264a, the offshore notice amendment. I do not regard it as either retrospective or as seeking to prevent the court from having access to documents. It is not retrospective in so far as it operates from today. It is like any other law enforcement mechanism. The analogy I used on Friday was the search warrant. If we changed the Crimes Act to change the way in which the Australian Federal Police could get access to a search warrant, that search warrant would apply to offences committed before that date; it could not be used retrospectively. A search warrant cannot be used yesterday; it is not retrospective.

The understanding of the mechanism is not apparent from either the amendments or the comments made in support of it. It is also not seeking to prevent the court having access to the documents. Our real objective is that the court should have access to documents. What we do not want is selective access to documents-that is, while the Australian Taxation Office is conducting its investigation these documents are unable to be provided and, when we get to court, having been denied access to them, some of them magically appear and the problems are overcome, with no way to judge whether they are all the documents.

We now have the situation in which, if people choose not to provide the information in the early stages and seek to introduce it in the court and the Commissioner denies the right to introduce it, that is a reviewable decision by the Commissioner and appealable in the courts. That is appropriate and that is what this Bill says. I do not hold the view that it is unconstitutional. I assume that will be tested. At this stage, on the basis of advice taken, I do not take that as a very serious issue, but I understand that others do and get very excited about it.

In conclusion, I want to do two things: firstly, to reiterate the significance that the Government places on this Bill as a question of principle and, secondly, to give my thanks to the Senate for its support. Certainly on behalf of the Government, and I suspect on behalf of the Senate as a whole, I thank the officers who have put so much assiduous work into the development of this very important and difficult piece of legislation and who continue to work on it. Their work is reflected in the amendments that are already before the Parliament and the other issues that continue to be raised, including in the course of this debate. They have done Australia a service. I thank them for their work and I thank the Senate for its support of the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1990CHILD SUPPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 and 14 November, on motions by Senator Collins and Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1990 and the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I wish to confine my remarks to the second Bill. I will leave it to my colleague Senator Watson to deal with the first. I am sure that he will withstand any pressure that might be directed at him.

SPEECH.PARA: The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 sets out a number of relatively minor changes which are not opposed by the Opposition. Indeed, we take the general view that they strengthen the provisions. I suppose it is just as well that any intelligent member of the public does not rely on a Minister's second reading speech in order to attempt to gauge the success of an exercise. This is probably a classic case study in that regard. All that the second reading speech tells us is that the child support scheme has been operating for just over two years and that in that time we have seen a substantial turnaround in the payment of maintenance for children who are living in single parent families. We then get a bland statistic about how collection rates have risen.

That second reading speech very much disguises what has been a very good concept-one which we have supported from the outset but which has had a number of very significant difficulties attached to its implementation. Perhaps the most glaring of these has been the question of delays. This has been a matter of particular concern to me because even prior to accepting shadow responsibility in this area I had a number of complaints directed to my office from people who were in the extraordinary situation of never having had any problems in regard to the collection of maintenance. They were able to rely on regular payments from, in most instances, the father of the child. However, they had been told by the Child Support Agency that, henceforth, moneys had to be paid through it.

In one celebrated instance I had a case of a wife who had always received her money on time. She was told that there would be a delay on the part of the Agency in terms of collection. When she told her ex-husband about this, he agreed to continue to make direct payments and in fact gave her a lump sum to tide her over the expected four- to six-week gap. When the Agency discovered that, it roundly abused him and told him that he immediately had to withdraw the payment and direct all further payments through it.

That, I think, was probably the high-water mark, but we still have very significant difficulties. Despite the fact that, according to a recent paper, some of these delays have been largely overcome, as recently as 29 May 1990 Senator Richardson admitted that processing delays of up to five months were continuing to occur. I have recently had correspondence from people for whom these sorts of difficulties continue. In some instances they did not get a reply after some months; in others they got token replies only. It seems to me still to be an intolerable situation. I do not understand how the Government can receive money from a non-custodial parent, pocket the money, obtain interest on it and then have delays which it explains away by saying that there is only a monthly cycle and that somehow parents are expected to meet the convenience of the Department or the Agency. That is an outrageous situation and I hope that at long last we will see something done about delays. There should not be any reason for any delay at all. Bureaucratic inconvenience is surely the worst possible excuse for such a situation, and I hope we will be given some proper explanations.

The projected savings from the scheme when it was first announced were in the order of $120m in 1988-89 and $190m in 1989-90. In fact, we have seen savings of $19m and $37m respectively in those periods. The publicly advanced major reasons for the shortfall due to the slower than expected take-up rates include modification to the scheme as originally planned and legislative and administrative delays. It demonstrates an unduly optimistic approach from the outset and a less than adequate recognition of the inevitable teething problems.

There continue to be a number of difficulties in terms of fairness of the formulas, work disincentives, accessibility of the appeals process and a particularly vexing question, the use of the previous year's taxable income as the basis for assessing a reasonable figure, which does not really take account of what the Agency regards as minor variations. I think the figure is about 20 or 25 per cent before it is taken into account. Quite clearly even a variation of 10 or 15 per cent can make a very significant difference to the non-custodial parent, yet these mechanical formulas simply ignore those difficulties. Quite a degree of publicity has attached to people-particularly the self-employed-who are able to artificially minimise their income for the purposes of the scheme.

In conclusion, there still remains a lot of work to be done. It is unfortunate that the second reading speech is typical of the attempt to gloss over these difficulties. I look forward to the Government making a full explanation of just what it proposes to do in response to the difficulties to date. I do not regard the Institute of Family Studies interim report-which the Institute goes out of its way to say is not meant to be even an initial valuation-as in any way a satisfactory Government response. The commissioning of that study, which was essentially a longitudinal study, is not any consolation at all to the many hundreds of people, based on my own experience, who seem to be still complaining about inordinate delays. I hope that the Government will act with a much greater degree of expedition than it has shown to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate Senator Lees will discuss the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, whereas I will concentrate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1990. The latter Bill proposes to alter the thin capitalisation rules-in other words, the rules which prescribe the maximum gearing of certain foreign investment into Australia for tax deductibility purposes; to modify the gold tax in relation to the capital gains tax provisions; to amend the dividend imputation rules to deal with situations arising under the new company tax payment arrangements; to alter the rules for taxation of quarrying operations; to increase certain aspects of the zone rebate; to alter the tax treatment of disposals of contaminated livestock; and to alter the names of organisations currently entitled to tax deductible status where these names have changed.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the heading of thin capitalisation the Bill seeks to deal with international transactions of financial institutions which are cleared through nostro and vostro accounts. Under the existing thin capitalisation rules, anomalies arise in the treatment of amounts in these accounts. The amendments are severely retrospective in operation but arise because of industry requests. The thin capitalisation provisions provide a maximum amount of interest which qualifies as a tax deduction for an Australian business which is at least 15 per cent controlled by non-residents.

Further amendments concern the structure of business group and the change from day to day to weighted average measure of foreign debt. These will result in the loosening of the provisions which disallow excessive interest payments. However, it is unclear whether this will cost any revenue. It is an indictment of the Government that during a recession it is bringing before us legislation which can only have the effect of lessening the tax paid by foreign controlled financial institutions.

I turn to goldmining. To coincide with the commencement of the taxation of goldmining income, capital gains which accrue after 1 January 1991 will be subject to tax when the assets are subsequently sold. However, the existing legislation which is repealed by this Bill and the wider provision being inserted by this Bill propose to maintain the existing grandfathering of assets acquired before 20 September 1985. Now that the Sex Discrimination Act applies to taxation laws, perhaps we should talk about grandparenting provisions instead of grandfathering provisions. The Government's proposal means that assets acquired after 19 September 1985 will be valued on 31 December 1990. This value will then form the cost base of the asset for tax purposes. All future real increases in value will be taxed, whereas assets held before 20 September 1985 can go on earning capital gains which are exempt from tax. The Australian Democrats do not agree with this provision. It is submitted that it is inequitable and inserts yet another complexity and unnecessary distortion into our tax laws.

Furthermore, when tax was extended to superannuation funds all assets were valued as at 1 July 1988 and are now subject to tax as they appreciate. If it is good enough for the Government to tax the four million members of superannuation funds on shares, real estate and so on which were purchased before 20 September 1985, then surely assets owned by goldmining companies which have never paid any tax should all be treated in an equivalent way. Therefore, I shall be moving an amendment in the committee stage to eliminate grandparenting and to subject all assets to a valuation date of 31 December 1990. Apart from the equity considerations, the identical treatment of assets will eliminate the distortions which tax bias would otherwise introduce.

Similarly, a value must be assigned to existing trading stock for the commencement of income tax on 1 January 1991. Trading stock provisions are easily manipulable and hence anti-avoidance provisions are included. We support these provisions.

On the question of imputation, last year the Government ended the deferral enjoyed by companies in paying income tax. Whilst we supported the proposal to end the unwarranted tax deferral which companies obtained from the previous quarterly system, we thought the Government's proposals were too tough on small business. Former Senator Haines moved an amendment which would have had the effect of exempting from next July's D-Day all companies which earned less than $200,000. The Opposition would not support that amendment, and small business will bear the brunt of that decision; in fact, it is currently doing so.

This legislation has had the unintended consequence of creating some anomalies in the imputation system which, if left unchecked, would allow certain profits to be distributed by companies tax free. The Bill proposes to adjust these anomalies. An additional problem arises for companies which did not take advantage of the loophole, possibly because of anticipation of this amendment. A special provision ensures that these companies are not disadvantaged.

In the area of quarrying operations, the Government broadly aligned the tax treatment of mining and quarrying operations in last year's Budget. An anomaly with respect to the recoupment of exploration and prospecting expenditure was included in that legislation. The amendment proposed here simply aligns the treatment between the mining and quarrying industries and is supported.

The tax system recognises the additional costs of living in extremely isolated areas by granting a zone rebate. This rebate was reviewed and the review recommended aligning the amount of rebate available for residents of the two most isolated of the four zones.
Sitting suspended from 1.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the attempt of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia (BWIU) to gain legal aid from the New South Wales Government under false pretences by concealing the existence of a $1m slush fund. Is this unethical and unprincipled union the one the Minister proposes to be the predominant union in the building and construction industry throughout Australia as a result of his union amalgamation legislation? Does the Minister believe that this union is a more principled and ethical organisation than the Western Australian branch of the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF), led by Kevin Reynolds, the federal registration of which may be prevented by the Minister's Builders Labourers Federation deregistration legislation?

—I did not quite hear the last part of that question. Although the question does not merit a reply, I wonder whether Senator Chapman might give me the last tag line he had to the end of that question?

—Yes, Minister. The last part of the question was: does the Minister believe that this union-that is, the Building Workers Industrial Union-is a more principled and ethical organisation than the Western Australian branch of the Builders Labourers Federation, led by Kevin Reynolds, the federal registration of which may be prevented by his BLF deregistration legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fairly tawdry effort to try to massage discontent in the building industry. But let me take the questions seriatim. On the question of legal aid, the New South Wales Greiner Government has decided to conduct a royal commission into the building industry in that State. That is a perfect right of that Government-I acknowledge that-and it has proceeded to do that. I might say in passing that thus far the evidence that has been adduced from the proceedings of that Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales has reflected extraordinarily badly on employers rather than on unions. But we are yet to hear all of the evidence. When we have, and when we have the recommendations of the Royal Commission, we can make a judgment.

ANSWER.PARA: The reference to a $1m slush fund is one that escapes me because I know of no such slush fund. What I do know of is an allegation that a slush fund exists; but I am not one in the field of industrial relations to take allegations as facts and then act on them. I want to be careful, because to be careful means that one might do the right thing and resolve a problem rather than create one, which would happen if one simply accepted allegations at face value. I am aware that the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, which is proceeding to negotiate-and hopefully, bring off-a series of amalgamations, is developing a fund in order that all of the new participating unions can join an amalgamation on an equal financial footing. If that is described as a slush fund, I guess that is the description that the namers of that fund give it. But, in my parlance, it is an amalgamation fund and a fund for that purpose.

Do I regard the BWIU as the principal union? In the process of union rationalisations, the existing unions will lose their identities. I do not see union rationalisation as meaning that existing unions accrete to themselves more and more coverage; I see a transformation of existing unions into new entities when they amalgamate with other existing unions to create a third and different organisation.

So, in terms of the BWIU, I also recognise that the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its strategic amalgamation plans identifies the BWIU as the principal union in the building industry and identifies other unions, including the registered State branches of the Builders Labourers Federation, as significant unions in the building industry. Under their scheme for amalgamation, it is possible that they all may emerge as one union or emerge as a principal and a group of significant unions.

In terms of being more principled and ethical, frankly that is just a try on, and I am not going to be bated by Senator Chapman over that. In terms of the question of the BLF in Western Australia-I have a high regard for the BLF in Western Australia and its leader, Kevin Reynolds, but as a Government we have proceeded on a principled course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, ha, ha!

—That is a foreign word to Senator Kemp, I know. He does not understand principle. As a Government we have proceeded on a principled course to try to bring about an amalgamation by agreement and commitment of the two organisations. Those talks are proceeding. If those talks fail, there are other processes that those unions will be free to follow. While I have a high regard for Kevin Reynolds, I do not necessarily mean by that remark that there is a lesser regard for any other figure in the building industry.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he, together with ministerial colleagues, met building industry executives this morning to discuss a reform strategy for the industry? If so, were the discussions successful and, if so, can he advise the Senate what the reform strategy entails and how it will operate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This term of the Hawke Labor Government is significant as it is the term of micro-economic reform as we attend to making the economy more efficient by reforming major industry sectors in it. Today I and my colleagues the Honourable Simon Crean, in absentia the Honourable John Dawkins, and my Senate colleague, Senator Nick Bolkus, presided as a ministerial task force at a meeting of all the major players in the building industry, being construction companies, builders, the Building Owners and Managers Association and the organisations representing specialist contractors as well as building unions.

ANSWER.PARA: At that meeting, we announced a strategy for the reform of the building industry in Australia to make it more efficient, to lower the level of lost time, to ensure that it comes out of the current oversupply of office accommodation in central business districts as a more lean, more efficient and more productive industry. All of the major players at that conference today endorsed the Government's strategy.

Let me tell Senator Devereux who those parties are: the Master Builders-Construction and Housing Association of Australia offered words of endorsement and support and will follow through the reform package with the Government; the Metal Trades Industry Association did the same; the National President of the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors did the same; the National Director of the Building Owners and Managers Association supported the package as well and committed its efforts to the realisation of these goals; and the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Association has supported and endorsed the Government's package, as has the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The Government's package, in brief, enables significant reform on industrial relations, contractual, industry and training fronts and uses, as a way of stimulating change, the promotion of model building sites to trial new practices, to obtain more multi-skilling and to test ways in which we can make this industry more efficient. We now have a mandate from the industry to proceed. It will be a significant reform when it is realised. There is much to be achieved and I am heartened, on behalf of the Government, by the support we have. I believe that we can succeed in making important changes in this industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the $1m Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU) slush fund to be used to engineer the BWIU union amalgamations, which was reported in the West Australian in November, and to the BWIU's decision:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to make it clear to some of those elements over there (WA) that we are going to exert the full national authority and influence of those unions in Western Australian politics.

I ask: does the Minister support the proposed actions of the BWIU in isolating the BLF in Western Australia and in particular its endeavour to make Kevin Reynolds look, as described by Tom McDonald, like a `pimple on a pumpkin'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given the Senate my view about this allegation of a slush fund. Now that it has been trotted out a second time, Opposition senators may well be shocked but I have to tell them that my view has not changed in the last 30 seconds; it is the same view. The purpose of a fund being developed by the BWIU is to encourage and support union amalgamation. Senator Crane in his question quoted from the West Australian, which I understand in turn was quoting from a transcript provided of a meeting of a national council of the BWIU. It is not surprising that people, in the privacy of their own organisations-privacy, by and large, of meetings of national organisations ought to be respected-express themselves about external parties in colourful language; that is not at all surprising. I would not mind having a bug in the Liberal Party room to hear how those opposite talk about unions and then trotting it out in a transcript and saying, `Isn't this shocking?'.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not intend to comment on what the BWIU says or thinks in private, other than to say that at the moment it is publicly pursuing a legal action through the Commission, as is its right, in order to obtain constitutional coverage for builders' labourers in Western Australia, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania. A cross-action has been filed to obtain national registration for the Builders Labourers Federation in Western Australia. A lively legal battle is being fought out. While that is being fought out, I should abstain from commenting on the relative merit of the various parties. To do so would be to interfere unnecessarily and improperly with a proper legal proceeding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of industry views that the dividend imputation scheme is having an adverse effect on the 150 per cent research and development taxation concession, negating its effectiveness? Will increased demands for fully franked dividends further weaken the incentive value of the concession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue has been about for some time; indeed, since the tax concession and the imputation system were introduced. Some months ago the Industry Research and Development Board, in response to these sorts of allegations, commissioned Ernst &Young to investigate the claims by some industry representatives that dividend imputation may have an adverse effect on the tax concession. The report of Ernst &Young is now available. I am pleased to say that it concluded that the introduction of dividend imputation has not had a significant impact on the effectiveness of the concession. Over 93 per cent of companies registered for the concession reported that its value to the company was unaffected by dividend imputation. Over 90 per cent reported that the value to shareholders was unaffected.

ANSWER.PARA: The report supports the view that theoretically dividend imputation can have an impact on the value of the concession, but only in circumstances where the proportion of profits paid out of dividends is very high. Notwithstanding these theoretical effects of dividend imputation, the report found that research and development spending was rarely linked to profit levels. Fewer than one in 10 respondents set their research and development budgets as a proportion of profit, though one in five respondents fund research and development out of retained profit. The ability to pay cash dividends and the ability to pay fully franked dividends were the least important factors in setting research and development budgets. The most important factor influencing the size of the research and development budget is the availability of the research and development tax concession and the expected after tax return.

I should add that institutional investors and stockbrokers-who have had something to say about this issue-who were interviewed concluded that the vast majority of investors had not perceived the introduction of dividend imputation as having an effect on the value of the concession. Therefore, I do not believe that dividend imputation will have a significant impact on investment in research and development. Imputation has more than offset the 15 per cent earnings tax imposed on superannuation funds, contrary to the expectations of critics.

TALK.START.PARA: — I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by referring the Minister to the widening gap between the banks' cost of funds of between 11 per cent and 12 per cent and the rates charged to consumers by Australian banks, namely 15 per cent to home buyers, 20 per cent on personal loans and 24 per cent on credit cards. I ask the Minister: is the Government willing to take any measures to stop the banks recouping the losses caused by their own bad decisions by profiteering in this way at the expense of Australian families; and, if so, how?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler gave me some short notice of this question, which I have referred to the Treasurer's office in order to obtain a detailed answer. I must say that even Senator Spindler might understand that the business of banking is about the business of making a profit as a result of borrowing money and then lending it.
—But is that the case?

—I was not sure whether that understanding was inherent in Senator Spindler's question. I shall take a charitable interpretation of his question and say that it is directed to the margin of profit which is made on various transactions. I would not have thought that the margin, which Senator Spindler referred to in respect of home buyers at this point in time, was a huge one. I think that some of the other margins seem larger but, as I am not familiar with the details of the business of banking, I am not able to comment on that.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know whether this question was provoked by reports in today's newspapers about the further reduction of one per cent in interest rates. There was some speculation in the papers as to whether, following two banks having announced their intention of passing on the reduction straight away, other banks would do the same: because they have incurred big losses as a result of-how shall I put it-imprudent lending to so-called entrepreneurs, those banks might try to recompense themselves for that imprudent lending by not passing on the interest rate cut immediately. On that issue I would say that what is good for those banks which immediately passed on the interest rate cut ought to be good enough for the others. I hope that would be the case. I will obtain a more detailed answer from the Treasurer and provide it as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister representing the Treasurer could take a couple of additional points to the Treasurer: first, that the margin of the banks has doubled in the last 2 1/2 years and, secondly, that the Treasurer is able to refer the matter to the Prices Surveillance Authority if he so wishes.
—Order! That is a statement.

—I will take those extra points to the Treasurer. In addition to any possibility of a reference to the Prices Surveillance Authority, an inquiry into banking practice is being conducted by a House of Representatives committee which may well address these issues.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of recent reports that Brazil and Argentina have agreed to cooperate more closely on nuclear issues, including nuclear safeguards? What is the significance of this development to the international non-proliferation regime and to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that at the end of last month, on 28 November, the Presidents of Brazil and Argentina announced that the two countries had agreed to cooperate more closely on nuclear issues through, among other things, the establishment of a system of mutual inspections and the negotiation of a nuclear safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and also to consider bringing the Treaty of Tlatelolco into full effect as far as they are concerned. Brazil has also announced recently that it will not allow peaceful nuclear explosions, so called, to be carried out on Brazilian soil.

ANSWER.PARA: As a very strong supporter over many years of efforts to strengthen the international non-proliferation regime and the IAEA's safeguards system, Australia naturally very warmly welcomes these announcements by the two presidents. We look forward to an early start to the negotiation of the proposed safeguards agreement with the IAEA. We hope that the proposed agreement will permit IAEA inspection of all Brazilian and Argentine nuclear facilities; that is to say that it will be a full scope safeguards agreement. We also hope that the two countries will bring the treaty of Tlatelolco into force, as far as they are concerned, as soon as possible.

Fulfilment of the two presidents' pledges could open up an area of cooperation in non-fuel cycle nuclear research and applications that have previously been closed between Australia and both those countries. Again I say that, as a long time supporter of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, Australia hopes that it will not be very long before the two presidents announce the next logical step flowing from this development and say that they will join the nuclear non-proliferation treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. It relates to reports in yesterday's Australian regarding the failure of the Government's waterfront reform program. Firstly, is the Minister aware that the memorandum of agreement in relation to the Cairns port which has been negotiated between the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour (AEWL) and three waterfront unions provides inter alia for in the order of 16 waterfront workers to do a job which users indicate requires only five workers? Is he aware that agreement has not been approved or even discussed with the users of the Cairns port, the stevedoring company or the Cairns Port Authority? Secondly, is the Minister aware that if the agreement is approved by the Water Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) the cost of stevedoring ships in Cairns will almost treble on today's charge-out rates? Thirdly, is the Minister further aware that in that event the two major users of the Cairns port, namely Freeport Indonesia and Incitech, would not economically be able to continue to use the Cairns port? Fourthly, is the Minister aware that one of those two major users has spent, this calender year, in the order of $34m in the Cairns community, generating in excess of 300 jobs which will be lost to the Cairns area if the current proposal is forced upon the Cairns port? Finally, will the Minister ensure that the agreement described earlier in this question is referred to the port users, the port stevedores and the Port Authority for approval before being implemented? It is a long question. I seek a serious answer, and on that basis I have given Senator Collins a copy of this question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that, with the usual tolerance exhibited by the Opposition, I have 30 seconds to answer. I did, in fact, give an answer substantially to this question a few days ago when it was asked. The last three, four or five parts of Senator Macdonald's question referred to the current utilisation of the port by the existing stevedores and companies. I agree completely with Senator Macdonald's assessment of the contribution to the port made by those users, which makes, I must say with regret, the current attitude of Northern Shipping and Stevedoring Pty Ltd very difficult for me personally to understand.

ANSWER.PARA: As I indicated earlier in the Senate, the company, for whatever reason-and this is its own business-has taken an attitude towards resolving the situation in Cairns quite different from the attitude expressed not just to me personally but to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority in earlier negotiations. In respect of Cairns, the Commonwealth has indicated that it is anxious, by using the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority package, to remove from the port-as urgently as possible; immediately if an agreement can be reached-that excess labour which qualifies for the WIRA package, that is, some 10 to 13 workers who can be taken out of the port immediately, pending an evaluation of the real labour requirements of the port, not simply the assessment of the users as to that, according to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority.

I would have thought-and I personally put this to a principal of the company last week-that consistent with its previous attitude the company would have been minded, in its own interests as well as those of the port of Cairns, to assist the Commonwealth to put cheques into the hands of those who are willing to leave, in terms of redundancy packages, and get them out of the port.

For whatever reason, the company has chosen not only to reject that-as I have said, I find it incomprehensible that it has taken this position-but also to communicate this rejection in a piece of correspondence that I saw yesterday couched in the most inflammatory and provocative language possible. I understand there has been a further piece of communication today from the company to AEWL-and I am not at liberty to discuss it in detail because it is not correspondence to me-which has proposed an even more extreme solution for the port.

I have to say, in concluding this answer, that I am anxious to get an agreement for the port of Cairns-and I thought we almost had one-that will allow us, through the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, to get a very large number of redundant workers out of the port immediately pending an evaluation of the real labour requirements of the port and the negotiation of an enterprise agreement for that port. I urge all parties that are currently negotiating over this arrangement to support such a proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is Senator Collins blaming NSS simply because it refuses to endorse an agreement which requires about 16 workers, when five workers are all that is needed to do the job that this agreement wants 16 workers to do? Is that why he is blaming NSS?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not blaming NSS. Unfortunately, this is symptomatic of the kind of attitude that Opposition senators take to the whole question of industrial relations and which causes a great deal of these problems. A few days ago Senator Macdonald issued a very mischievous press release headlined, `Minister blames employers in dispute'. I decided to assist the process by simply ignoring the statement, which I did. It is not a question of blaming NSS. It is simply putting the facts on the public record.

ANSWER.PARA: The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, which has been criticised trenchantly by Senator Macdonald and others, in fact prepared a resolution to the problems at the port of Cairns based, not surprisingly, on the results of prolonged negotiations with all of the parties. It did not give everyone what they wanted, but it was largely in accordance with positions that were indicated-not just to WIRA but to me personally-would be accepted by the parties.

Suddenly, a matter of weeks ago the company, for whatever reason, changed the personnel who had brought that position about-they are no longer working for the company-and took a radical shift in attitude. All I am saying, as a matter of fact, is that that sudden shift has complicated what I thought was very close to a resolution. I simply say again that I urge all of the parties to assist us to remove a substantial portion of the idle time from the port of Cairns by allowing WIRA immediately, on an interim basis, to remove from the port people who are willing to go, pending the negotiation of an enterprise agreement for the port.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the success, as has been acknowledged by the Opposition, of the Government's shipping reform program. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether there is any evidence that the reforms have resulted in a real increase in competitiveness for the Australian shipping industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that John Sharp cannot be all bad because recently he did, in fact acknowledge, grudgingly, that there has been significant success in the Government's shipping reform program.

—The Opposition senator can take him to task if he likes. The most tangible evidence of confidence in the Government's shipping reform program is the investment of significant capital in new ships. I am pleased to say that Howard Smith Industries Pty Ltd has spent a significant amount of money on a new ship, the Express, which came on to the Australian shipping register last month and has started to trade. This new vessel is a technologically advanced, self-discharging vessel that operates with a crew of 18 as opposed to the average crew size of 35 that existed on Australian ships at the beginning of the Government's reform program.

ANSWER.PARA: That ship is operating successfully. I am pleased to say that CSR Ltd has just been able to negotiate a substantial contract with New Zealand for the supply of Australian gypsum using this self-discharging vessel, replacing the supply of gypsum from Mexico and in open competition with Mexican shipping companies and gypsum suppliers. It is a welcome indication of the confidence the shipping industry has in the success of the Government's reform program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister has been quoted as having said today or yesterday:

QUESTION.PARA: At times such as this when there is a bit of a recession on, a bit of unemployment, there may be some need for companies to negotiate a more preferable arrangement . . . but they have to be done through the system.

I ask: how high does unemployment have to be before he ceases to flippantly refer to it as a bit of unemployment? Given that the Government has played a part in engineering this recession, what is a bit of a recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Vanstone would know the answer to that question because her Party is the world's leading expert in this country in engineering recessions. Under the previous Government there was double digit unemployment, double digit inflation, negative economic growth and the wages outcome blew right out. Those opposite know all about recessions.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is uncomfortable with the current level of unemployment and is unhappy about any new person becoming unemployed. After all, this Government has pushed the fight for employment, which has been one of our key economic thrusts during our period in Government. While all of those things are true, if we were to measure the current level of unemployment in this country with the participation rate those opposite had, then unemployment would be at 2.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I might be a bit thick, but I did not divine a clear answer to the question. The question was: how high does unemployment have to be before the Minister ceases to flippantly refer to it as a bit of unemployment? Given that the Government played a part in engineering this recession, what is a bit of a recession? Do we understand from the Minister's answer that we have a full recession when we get to double digit unemployment next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Vanstone says that we will get to double digit unemployment next year. At present in the economy we have a participation rate-that is, people between the ages of 16 and 60 in the work force-which is at a higher level than at any time during the whole period of the Fraser Government. Indeed, more Australians are working now as a percentage of the population than at any time under a Liberal government since Federation.

ANSWER.PARA: We are talking about unemployment against a background of more people working than ever before. When I say that the level of unemployment would be 2.9 per cent, if we take the last period of the Fraser Government and measure the size of the work force and the participation rate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has now had two opportunities to answer a very specific question about what is meant by a bit of unemployment. I ask you to direct him to be relevant instead of indulging in self-congratulation which is more to do with ancient history than current politics.
—Order! There is no point of order.

— I will conclude my answer. Measured against the previous Government's record of the participation rate, the unemployment level in Australia now would be 2.9 per cent. Yesterday Senator Vanstone made a real goose of herself when her pin-up girl, Margaret Thatcher, was exposed. If I were her, I would just keep my head down.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that the Australian Bureau of Statistics has today released figures showing a dramatic rise in the number of people receiving award-based superannuation since the Hawke Government won office in 1983? Is the Minister in a position to advise honourable senators how this magnificent result for Australian workers was achieved? Has the spread of award-based superannuation been a central objective in the accord between the Government and the trade union movement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
