TALK.START.PARA: —Award based superannuation, given its achievement during the period of the Hawke Government, has been a historic breakthrough for ordinary workers in this country and it is one of the Government's greatest achievements.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I would ask you to rule that question out of order under Standing Order No. 73, which says clearly that a question shall not ask for a statement on government policy, and that question clearly did. As such, it ought to be ruled out of order.

—On the point of order, I know the subcommittee opposite has decided on tactics to interrupt a lot of questions, but if you really want to rule that way, Mr President, we are happy to support Senator Bishop and therefore that is the end of Question Time. There is one overriding rule in Question Time, and that is commonsense, which is not often observed here.
—I think the question asked for the Minister to comment on the success of the Government policy and I will allow the question.

—In 1983, about 2.1 million or 39 per cent of employees received occupational superannuation. According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released today, the number of employees belonging to employer sponsored superannuation schemes is now 3.4 million. The proportion of all employees receiving superannuation benefits increased to 52 per cent in August 1990. This compares with 47 per cent in 1989 and 42 per cent in 1988. If we go back to the period of the Fraser Government, there was a much lower participation level then. In other words, 345,900 additional employees are receiving superannuation benefits this year compared with last year. However, there is still--

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. As you have ruled that the question was properly in order, I would draw your attention to the Standing Orders with regard to the answer. Clearly we are hearing a ministerial statement given in the guise of an answer to a question without notice which means, in turn, it may not be debated. If the Minister has a statement to make, please ask him to put it on the Notice Paper in the proper way so that a proper response in debate may take place.

—On the point of order, there is a very thin line between when a Minister is making a statement and answering a question. If one went by the objections those opposite have, we would be having ministerial statements morning, noon and night. In the past 50 years, nothing has changed in this chamber with regard to the type of answers we are hearing today. The only thing that has changed is the ineptness of the subcommittee on tactics formed opposite.

—Order! In reply to Senator Bishop, I point out that this matter was discussed by the Standing Committee on Procedure last week. I face the same problem my predecessors had in determining when a ministerial answer or an argument becomes a debate. There is really only one solution and that is an unofficial time limit, which I am implementing. I ask the Minister to take note of the complaints that have been made about time.

—I point out that I am dealing with a publication of the ABS that came out today. Therefore, this is new information and new information ought to be supplied in answer to a question which relates to labor market activity. I go on to say, however, that there is still a lot of non-compliance in business, especially among smaller firms. For businesses with fewer than 10 employees, the proportion receiving superannuation benefits was 42 per cent compared with 52 per cent in firms of 10 to 19 employees and 71 per cent in firms with more than 100 employees. Only about 75 per cent of employees who have an entitlement actually have superannuation cover.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, in consultation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry, has developed a national strategy to deal with non-compliance with Federal award-based occupational superannuation provisions, including targeting of specific industries. That will continue to be the case. We will monitor the situation. Superannuation is another part of the social wage under the accord and I do not need to go into other elements of the social wage. It essentially means that workers in this country can now look forward to a better and a more productive retirement because of the superannuation policies of this Government than otherwise would have been the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to four separately paid advertisements placed in today's Adelaide Advertiser advertising the services of the Parliamentary and Ministerial Services Group, Comcar, Australian Archives, and the Department of Administrative Services (DAS)-our business-with comments that they provide services to State and local governments and Commonwealth departments. How can the Minister possibly justify this gross and extraordinary waste of taxpayers' money?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have a continuation of these sorts of questions. I ask the Senate to take into account-and it is something that the Opposition finds very hard to understand-that the Department of Administrative Services is now an organisation which has been geared up to act commercially. As a consequence, we have within the Department a trust fund operation and, as I say, organisations operating commercially. There has been a massive cultural change within the organisation. I do not need to bore the Senate with a whole range of evidence to that effect, other than to quote Mr Henry Bosch, who quite often has been quoted by Opposition senators in this place in a whole range of debates. He is now a member of the board of the Department of Administrative Services. Very soon after joining the board, he made some very pertinent points about the transition of this particular Department. In one particular paragraph of the Australian of 9 November, Henry Bosch says:

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time remarkable progress has been made within the general government sector which has received very little notice and which deserves approbation and encouragement.
have generated formidable pressures on the DAS and have produced a dynamic response.
Here is evidence, attestation, by Henry Bosch that we have an organisation which is changing its culture--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think the Minister is answering a question that he anticipated but did not in fact get. He was asked how he justified the Commonwealth advertising at public expense for services that are available to the Commonwealth. That is the question he was asked, and I ask you, Mr President, to ask him to answer that question.
—Order! Senator Bolkus was asked a question about the administration of his Department. He is answering that question. I remind him to try to keep his answer brief.

—Mr President, that would be possible if the reception on the other side markedly improved. The point I am making and which is not understood is that we have here an organisation which, in most arms, is moving very much to a commercial basis. As a consequence, there appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser this morning a supplement from the Department of Administrative Services. Within that supplement a whole range of services were advertised, some of which are obviously available in the commercial market and some not. In terms of presentation of the Department, it has changed commercial activity, and because it is a player in the marketplace I found that supplement this morning very useful. It not only raises the recognition of the new departmental culture in the community but also promotes a whole range of services that are available to the private sector.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I note the Minister's remarks about the commercialisation of DAS, of which we are all aware. But what are the commercial realities of an advertisement for parliamentary and ministerial services which quite clearly states that DAS provides services to Ministers, Opposition, parliamentary office holders, senators and members, ministerial Opposition and electoral staff, and then at the bottom says, `For further information ring 2132001'? What on earth is the relevance of that paid advertisement in the Adelaide Advertiser?
—If I were a small business in Adelaide supplying paper, typewriters, stationery and office space-a whole range of services-to government, I would find that quite useful.
— I do not think the Opposition really wants an answer and, as a consequence, I sit down.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I draw the attention of the Minister and the Senate to the decision handed down by Justice Spender in the Federal Court on 4 May 1990, which amended the period of allotment for duty of a former member of the Royal Australian Navy involved in the Logistic Support Group in Vietnam. This decision brought the period of service into conformity with that issued to all other personnel involved in the Vietnam conflict, `from the last port of call in Australia to the first port of call upon return', as per the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. In light of this decision, what action has been taken by the Navy to extend this precedent to those personnel who served on HMAS Sydney and other ships involved with the duty of logistic support during the Vietnam conflict? What is the anticipated time frame for this corrective action to be carried out so that these personnel are brought into line with all other personnel involved in that theatre of war, as well as those now serving in the Gulf crisis? Will the extension of the Federal Court decision to the members of all three Services involved in the Logistic Support Group in Vietnam result in their being eligible for the South Vietnamese Campaign Medal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the first part of Senator McLean's question, the Government has no intention of retrospectively varying the dates of allotment for sailors who served on HMAS Sydney during the Vietnam War. The amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, which were recently approved by the Parliament, provide that decisions similar to that of Doessel cannot be made. All claims and applications lodged after 8 November 1990 will be determined on the basis of the amended legislation. Claims lodged prior to 8 November 1990 will have to be considered with the Doessel decision in mind. In respect of the second part of the question, therefore, no corrective action is required.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the third part of the question, the answer is no. The qualifying period of six months was set by the South Vietnamese Government of the day to recognise personnel rendering operational service in Vietnam. It is not within the power of the Australian Government to change that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware that Australia has lost five of its six canned ham companies and that the Australian canned ham industry now consists of only one company that produces local canned ham? Is the Minister also aware that the remaining company is in his own State of Victoria and is having grave difficulties in surviving because of the effect of dumped and subsidised canned ham exports from the European Community (EC) to Australia? Is the Minister also aware that canned ham companies in the EC sell one per cent of their product domestically at an artificially low price and export nearly 99 per cent of their production, which benefits from export restitution amounting to 25 per cent of their export price? Does the Minister agree with the view that to export at normal value is to export at a price which is neither dumped nor affected by subsidies, even when the product is subsidised by 25 per cent? If the Minister believes that dumping products on the Australian market by subterfuge is unfair, will he act to protect the threatened jobs of 200 meat workers in his own State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell gave me notice of this question in big print copy so that I could read it. I would like to comment on a number of allegations in the question. Firstly, it is true that there has been a restructuring-as we call it euphemistically-of the canned ham industry in Australia and some five companies have withdrawn from the market over a period. One company-Castle Bacon Pty Ltd-remains and is located in Victoria. I will come to the allegation of dumping and subsidisation contained in the question in a minute. Senator Boswell also raised the point that there is a high level of subsidisation of these companies in the European Community and significant export subsidies are provided under the common agricultural policy for companies involved in this industry in Europe.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the question on which I will comment was: will I act to prevent the threatened jobs of 200 members of the meat workers union in my State? I take it that Senator Boswell means the people at Castle Bacon. It is not in my hands-it might be in their own hands-to protect the jobs of hundreds of thousands of meat workers in the State of Victoria, but that is the subject of a special inquiry into the meat industry in that State.

The matter of imported canned ham has been examined by the Australian Customs Service and is now being dealt with by the Anti-Dumping Authority. That Authority has to report and make a recommendation to the Minister by 9 January 1991-that is, next month.

There seems to be some confusion in Senator Boswell's question on the issues of dumping and subsidisation, and I ought to comment on that. Dumping occurs when a product is exported at a price which is below the normal price obtained in the domestic market of the country of export. If these exports cause or threaten injury to the Australian industry producing such a product, the Government will act quickly to stop the injury being caused by dumping. That is consistent with our rights and obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

Similarly, under GATT certain types of subsidies are frowned on, and if these subsidies harm an Australian industry appropriate countervailing action is taken. So if either dumping or subsidisation are found-and these matters are before the Authority at the moment-the Government can move quickly to ensure that fair trade is restored.

Senator Boswell will be aware of the broader context of this relating to the European Economic Community's farm subsidisation and the current failure-if that is not too strong a word-of the Uruguay Round, largely because of the reluctance or refusal of the European Community to make significant changes to its common agricultural policy. That is the general umbrella under which these things are considered. If there is a subsidy in this case, it can be dealt with once the inquiry is completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware that, under the policy announced last month, the Western Australian Government will allow mining to proceed in five national parks? In his statement on the environment in July last year the Prime Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Where the legislative capacity exists, the Commonwealth will continue to protect environmentally valuable areas from mining where it is deemed in the national interest.

He cited the Government's action to protect Shelburne Bay and Moreton and Fraser islands as examples of this protection. In view of that, I ask whether the Minister is prepared to use these same powers to prevent the mining and export of mineral sands from D'Entrecasteaux, of iron ore from the Hamersley Range and of uranium from the Rudall River National Park in Western Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few years, I have answered a number of questions on uranium. I am happy to answer that part of Senator Vallentine's question first. Any further uranium mines are contrary to Labor policy, and if any uranium mine were to open up contrary to that policy this Government would not be giving permission for its produce to be exported. It is that simple.
—What is the logic of that?
—Yes, explain the logic of that, Graham.
— It is not my responsibility to explain the logic of that. That would be for the Minister for Resources.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I should also comment on the rest of Senator Vallentine's question. The Western Australian Government has agreed to allow mineral exploration, as I understand it, and possible mine development in three national parks in Western Australia and the excision of areas for mining in two other parks. It is disappointing that this would happen at any time, but that it would happen right at the time of the triennial general assembly of the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources in Perth is particularly disappointing.

The Commonwealth Government does not support mining in national parks and never has. It is contrary to our national platform, and our position in that will be maintained. But obviously the responsibility for national parks exists at a State level. State legislation creates them, and the States are responsible for their management.

While the Commonwealth legislation does not preclude exploration or mining in national parks, the plans for parks and reserves declared under State legislation are just not something we can affect. Where World Heritage areas are concerned, of course, that changes, and the Commonwealth will live up to its responsibilities, as it has repeatedly shown. Unfortunately, there is no power for us to prevent that mining. If it were to take place, obviously the Government will consider the export permits as they come in.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. It has now been nine months since the Government received the Sheridan report-an independent review of the Australian National Audit Office. Can the Minister explain why, despite repeated calls for its release, we have not seen this report? A weekend media report detailing that the Audit Office had found that half the Federal Government's $12 billion specific purpose payments to the States were not being checked adequately to ensure the money was correctly spent signifies the crucial importance of an efficient Audit Office. How can the Minister justify the time delay on a report that includes recommendations for productivity gains that would release more than 60 full time staff for efficiency audits?
—I do not know the answer to that question. I will find out for Senator Olsen as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer to reports of plans to launch space satellites from the Woomera rocket range for the communications giant Motorola Corporation. Can the Minister please advise as to the current status of these plans and of any other planned uses of the Woomera rocket range?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall going to a briefing with several other Ministers on this subject some weeks ago at which the Transfield company acquainted us with its plans in regard to this project. Briefly, it is a revolutionary communications system that relies on satellites orbiting at 300 to 500 kilometres rather than geostationary orbits. The plan is to put up 77 such satellites, which will enable people to ring any part of the world via those satellites without necessarily having to go through the current complications. It is a revolutionary scheme. About 60 worldwide companies have applied to be part of the consortium. I understand that an Australian company has been short-listed down to the last 10, and it is only one of two overseas companies, apart from American ones, that have been so listed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has yet to be approached by Transfield for specific discussions on the subject but, quite clearly, Woomera is ideal for this purpose. For some time the Department of Defence has wanted to commercialise a lot of activities out of Woomera, and therefore it would welcome this project. The issue is not without complications and one really has to wait until early in the New Year when the Motorola Corporation gets down to the last three firms left.

The Australian bid is very competitive and Woomera is ideally suited for the project. In fact, it is probably the only spot in the Southern Hemisphere suited for this particular purpose. In conclusion, people may ask why the space port in Queensland is not considered. This project is to send up a different type of satellite. Queensland is not suitable for that type of satellite whereas it is suitable for others. In general, the Government has indicated that it encourages this particular project, without at this stage making any commitments towards it-other than that Woomera is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you speak up, please?
—I was a bit worried about hangovers, Senator Bishop.
—I don't have that problem.
—I was really only on DEFCON-1 at the moment.
—You are not embarrassed, are you?
—No, the Opposition never embarrasses me. Once February comes, I will have a much clearer idea of the viability of the project.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer explain to the Senate why the rate of mortgagees taking possession of houses after defaulted home loans in 1989-90 is double the previous year's rate? Is the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation correct in its stated belief that no reversal of this trend is likely in the near future? Does the Government have any forecasts of the rate for the current financial year? Is it the view of the Government that thousands of young Australian families losing their homes is an acceptable price to pay as part of the Treasurer's engineered recession that Australia had to have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only assume that the rate of repossession of houses by mortgagees in 1989-90 was higher because interest rates were very high and people, as we have acknowledged on various occasions in Question Time in the Senate, may not have been able to meet those rates. I have not seen the views of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation on this issue but I will certainly have a look at that report to see in what context that comment was allegedly made.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as forecasting is concerned, forecasting in respect of interest rates and other factors which bear on these matters is a difficult enough art form in itself. The rate of resumption of mortgaged homes will depend very much on such questions as levels of interest rates and levels of unemployment. As I understand it, there are no mechanisms for particularly forecasting what is likely to happen in a whole range of individual situations, so I am unable to comment on that part of the question. I refer the honourable senator to answers given by Government Ministers on those general economic parameters which bear on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to speak very briefly to the Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) report for 1989-90. The exporting situation in Australia is more desperate now than it has ever been. It is more necessary now than it has ever been that we should do whatever is possible to encourage more people into the exporting field. We have to make inroads into this country's debt. The only way to do that is to export more and to export on a better value added basis.

Contrary to the recent amendments that have gone through, I still believe it is absolutely essential that we should extend the scheme to cover more people, not fewer, and to include the newer and smaller manufacturers and producers of all types. The fact that the export market development grants were paid to 3,740 people in the last year is satisfactory, but I would like to see that increased by a further 1,000 if we are going to make real inroads into the debt. I notice that the requests for advice have increased from 40,000 in the previous year to 46,000 in the current year. This indicates how much reliance the market places on being able to get good, solid, accurate information.

The offices of Austrade are working well. I believe that around the world they have done the best they possibly can within the limits placed on them. But we have to keep abreast of what is happening in each of those areas with a view to changing them as it becomes necessary or desirable. The special categories which are listed again this year and are currently operating include education and training services, fresh fruit and vegetables, popular music, aerospace, railway industry, communications equipment, computer software, scientific and medical equipment, agricultural systems, health services, automotive industries, mining systems and processed food. That is all very well, but people who are not in those categories have come to me and said that they cannot get the assistance they would like to have from Austrade because they do not happen to fit into the winner picking list that is currently before us.

I would urge the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to consider the economic circumstances of the country and what we ought to be doing to extend our exports in all sorts of additional ways. The Government has to come to grips with and ensure that more rather than less money is made available. Australia has to compete with countries that adopt a much more red-blooded approach to trading than we do, and our export market is not going to happen unless we make it happen.

I urge the Government to give fresh consideration to meeting the increasing pressures of the strains on our financial resources and the increasing pressures, on the international market, of dealing with people who are probably better equipped and better motivated than we appear to be to go into the hurly-burly of international trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on the annual report of the Australian Trade Commission. The overall export performance of Australia is summarised on page 21 of that report. Despite all the gloom and doom in the community, the talk of recession and, in some quarters, the talking down of the economy, the report makes refreshing reading because it records very real growth in Australia's exports. For example, in the financial year 1988-89 real growth in exports was one per cent. By comparison, last financial year, 1989-90, Australia recorded a real growth in exports of 6.1 per cent-quite a respectable figure in world terms and certainly a large boost to this nation's trading activity.

SPEECH.PARA: Further data in the report enables us to look at the composition of exports. I refer specifically to the export of manufactured products with a value-added component. While the overall growth in export volume was 6.1 per cent, the growth in manufactured exports was 16 per cent-more than double the overall average growth. That is certainly a very respectable figure indeed. With regard to the more elaborately transformed manufactured products-those with the highest-value added component-there were high rates of export growth. For example, in that field there was a 15.8 per cent growth in total export volume last year compared with a growth of 6 to 7 per cent in the year before. Despite the talk of recession, the gloom and doom in the Australian community and the talking down of the economy in some quarters, respectable growth is still occurring in our exports.

Two areas that have been targeted by Austrade have shown enormous growth in exports and foreign exchange earnings for this country. I refer firstly to energy systems-that sector of the economy producing and selling power generation equipment. The growth in exports in that field was over 100 per cent-in fact 102.9 per cent-in the last year of record. I also instance the high tech field of telecommunications and telecommunications equipment. While the overall export growth in telecommunications last year was 6.1 per cent, our exports grew by 85 per cent-many, many times the overall rate of growth in exports.

The elaborately transformed manufactured products are being targeted on the South East Asian countries particularly, where last year there was a massive growth of 78 per cent in the export of those value-added manufactured products to Indonesia and a 40 per cent growth in exports to Malaysia; and Australian firms in this value-added field of manufacturing are starting to break into the European market. For example, according to the Austrade report there was a 36.8 per cent growth in these exports to the United Kingdom-perhaps reversing historic trade flows over two centuries.

Page 50 of the report documents some major successes for Australian producers in the communications sector. Major contracts have been won as follows: Telecom Australia has won an $86m contract to manage telecommunications in Saudi Arabia. There is vital public sector activity in government ownership. Also, in conjunction with Olex, Telecom has won a $35m contract to supply optical fibre cables in the Pakistan market. Some great success has been recorded by manufacturing enterprises in the Australian community, thereby strongly contributing to export growth.

I was also surprised at the reference on page 50 to our successes in marketing computer software overseas. Exports of Australian designed computer software have burgeoned in recent years. I was surprised to learn that our exports of this key service now comprise over $300m a year-a figure I would not have imagined. This represents 18 per cent growth over the previous financial year. Australia certainly is at the leading edge in the world in terms of designing software to make computer processes work. We are doing very well indeed in designing and exporting software to the overseas market. Despite the downturn in the economy, in the last 12 months we have seen an 8 per cent growth in exports in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to speak on the Australian Trade Commission annual report. Having listened to Senator Maguire, I cannot help but feel that he was giving us a Pollyanna report-that we were having a little bit of a boom time-as distinct from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) during Question Time saying that we were having a little bit of a recession. The fact is that our exports are still way behind our imports. All the attempts by this Government, with the policies it has espoused and stuck by and said were fantastic, have resulted in this country going further into debt.

SPEECH.PARA: The report by Austrade simply shows that in those areas where there has been growth it simply has not been enough. The salient point made in various parts of the report is that in many sectors our share of world trade is below that which we had in the 1970s. So there is a very serious problem to be addressed.

I refer particularly to the timing of this report's release. It comes very speedily after the report that we had on the thirteenth of this month announcing that the Managing Director of Austrade, Mr Lindsay MacAlister, had in fact resigned. This resignation seems to have coincided with the delivery to the Austrade board of the interim report by McKinsey and Co. dealing with new directions that Austrade is to take. A press report says that the McKinsey review is expected to make some far-reaching recommendations about how Austrade can improve its role in helping Australian companies get into export markets.

We already have a precedent in the area of trade and trade policy, again directly related to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce-the notorious Pappas Carter Evans and Koop report, a sort of apology for strategic trade theory, which came down in two parts. We had the interim report and then the final report. In light of the fact that our export record is still so poor and the fact that we are still going further into debt, this interim report, which has been delivered to the board of Austrade and has presumably had something to do with the resignation of the Managing Director, ought to be made available to the Parliament. I formally ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to seek to have that interim report tabled in the Parliament so that we can see the sorts of recommendation that McKinsey is making in this far-reaching report. Perhaps we can then have an insight earlier in the piece as to the sorts of actions that need to be taken to improve our export performance rather than wait for the final report, which I understand is not due until the first quarter to first half of next year.

It is an important issue. The report contains some useful information. Indeed, many officers concerned with Austrade are people with considerable dedication. The bottom line is that we are not doing well enough. Until we turn around our performance from the old `near enough is good enough' syndrome, we will not see our international plight begin to turn around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not detain the Senate long and I shall not repeat the isolated success stories Senator Maguire has quoted from the annual report of the Australian Trade Commission. We must say that, overall, our position is not good enough. Clearly, our overseas balance of payments continues to decline. Unless we want to accept a continuing monetary policy which squeezes Australian families within an inch of their lives, we will have to gear up our export efforts. In this context there are a number of areas where the Australian Democrats would like the Government to take action to address many opportunities which have been missed.

SPEECH.PARA: As the debate on the export market development grants scheme has shown, we regret very much that the Government has seen fit to exclude a number of small companies from participating in the scheme. On the figures available, the scheme will cut out some 150 small businesses from export related activities. Similarly, we are disappointed that so far the Government has not seen fit to pick up the suggestion that large-scale projects should be given the benefit of accelerated depreciation to the extent that they are contributing to export income.

Finally, we need to realise that simply promoting exports is not the total answer. We must support our scientific community. In this area our expenditure on research and development is lamentably low. The Australian Democrats have recommended, and will continue to press for, an increase of $100m per annum in the budget of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). There is a second stage: once organisations such as CSIRO have provided unique inventions which show value and are accepted as valuable by overseas countries, Australia rather than those overseas countries should pick up the development of those inventions and turn them into marketable products. That represents a gap in our overall effort in science and research and development. The Australian Democrats will be pressing the Government to fill that gap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall talk briefly about a number of points in the annual report of the Australian Trade Commission. I refer par- ticularly to the importance of having economic policies, especially monetary policies, in place that allow our dollar to reflect its true value much more closely. I have noticed some reports in the press in recent times about talking the dollar down.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at this report and go through the various issues, we find that some areas are quite encouraging while others are not so encouraging. With the collapse of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks recently, in terms of lifting our export performance it is absolutely imperative that, if we are to get our current account under control, we at least be in a competitive position with overseas operators. In recent times we have not been competitive.

I draw attention to page 46 of the report, referring to Australian fresh fruit and vegetable exports, which are quite disastrous. That industry has been hit very hard relative to the value of our dollar. At this time when we see the growth that exists in Asia, it is very important that we maximise the opportunities that exist in our horticultural industries. Unless we have in place an overall economic management plan that allows us to compete with the other producers of these products around the world, we will find it very difficult to overcome some of that trade imbalance and the lack of competitiveness that has existed for our producers of raw materials. This is particularly reflected in areas such as wheat, wool and meat. In terms of those industries and this report, one also has to emphasise the importance of getting on top of the current problems in the meat industry, where we have lost significant export opportunities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF DEFENCE EXPLOSIVES FACTORY, MARIBYRNONG

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I ask the Senate to note that the factory is moving towards closure at the end of this year. In accordance with section 41d of the Audit Act, the Department of Defence has submitted the 1989-90 financial statements for this factory. I think we should note that, although several lines of production of activity progressively were wound down, a low level of development activity continued in relation to sub- marines. The factory made a profit of $2.689m largely because of an increased appropriation of $8.5m to $18.525m.

I draw the Senate's attention to a comment that it was not feasible to perform a stocktake of work in progress as at balance date. As an accountant and a former factory manager I believe that this is complete nonsense and is completely unacceptable. Naturally, inventories are the sum total of raw materials, work in progress and finished goods. How can a proper statement of profit and loss be prepared without determining the accuracy of the various components of the work in progress? I think it is worth noting the comments of the Acting Executive Director of the Australian National Audit Office when he says:

Work in progress was not subject to stocktake or other suitable verification procedures. Consequently I have been unable to determine whether the closing balance of this item accurately reflects the true balance.
I wonder how the financial statements could really have met the requirements under section 41d, because it is to this extent that the statements are inadequate and, therefore, should not be accepted.
In relation to the accounts, there are a number of problems which are not really satisfactory. The report says:
. . . the accrual basis was applied in preparing the Financial Statements

The factory does not comply with the general disclosure requirements of Department of Finance on disposal of assets (other than trading stock) in that profits/losses are not reflected in the statements as the proceeds from sales are paid directly into Consolidated Revenue.

We have a very incomplete picture which I believe does not reflect the true state of the explosives factory at Maribyrnong. In view of the fact that it is being wound down, I will not take further issue, but I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that as a member of the Public Accounts Committee I find it a most unsatisfactory document.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATION OF THE OZONE PROTECTION ACT 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak to this document because it raises a very important issue. It reports the operation of the Ozone Protection Act 1989 and the regulations under the Act which were enacted in March last year to give effect to both the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and to reduce the emissions of ozone depleting substances, particularly chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons, in conformity with those conventions, and if possible to go beyond those requirements. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) on several occasions has said that this Government has, indeed, through regulations under this Act, gone further. The concern about these substances extends well beyond the question of ozone depletion. This is the issue to which I direct the Senate's attention.

Most of these substances, and indeed the substitutes to which we are now looking, have considerable greenhouse potential-particularly HFC-134a as a drop in substitute for CFC-12. HFC-134a has approximately 10 per cent of the greenhouse potential of CFC-12. This means that everything else remaining the same and if current practices continue-namely, the release of these substances into the atmosphere when refrigerators are serviced-it is very easy to imagine at least a tenfold increase in the consumption of these materials around the world, and we would be right back where we are now with respect to the greenhouse effect of these substances.

The problem is a very important one. Dr Manzer is one of the authors of a paper on CFC and ozone issues and is with the Central Research and Development Department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company Experimental Station. I do not have figures for Australia, but regarding the United States of America Dr Manzer states:
. . . $135 billion worth of equipment . . . that depends on CFCs has an expected lifetime of 20 to 40 years.
So the decisions we make now regarding the substitute substances, particularly in refrigeration, have very long term consequences. Indeed, Dr Manzer concludes his paper by saying:

Policymakers need to provide clear and prompt signals to industry and the consumer. If HCFCs and HFCs are deemed acceptable alternatives, a strong statement to that effect will speed their development and the transition from CFCs. If they are deemed unacceptable, industry may focus its resources elsewhere, which will likely mean continued use of CFCs until other viable technologies are identified.

The point I wish to stress is that we do have a perfectly viable and adequate alternative. Prior to 1928, when CFCs were developed by the General Motors company, we had a flourishing refrigeration industry worldwide that was substantially based on the use of ammonia. Ammonia is certainly a more toxic gas than either CFCs or hydrofluorocarbons, but in terms of its environmental damage it is not in any way comparable with either CFCs or HFCs.

I believe that we need to make a decision very rapidly, as a country and as the world, as to whether we are going to substitute the CFCs with these HFCs-particularly 134a which, as I have pointed out, has 10 per cent of the greenhouse potential of CFC-12, the substance it seeks to substitute-and lock ourselves into a massive expenditure on a technology which has a lifetime of 30 or 40 years or whether we make the decision now to go back to that proven technology, namely, the use of ammonia, which has none of those consequences but would impose on those handling the material, as it does with electricians, the requirement to handle it with a degree of safety which is not necessary with CFCs. I believe it is a very important decision and I enjoin the Government to look very seriously at that and to do it as promptly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to speak to the annual report 1989-90 on the operation of the Ozone Protection Act 1989. I want to raise the fact that in October this year the Government adopted the so-called Toronto goal of reducing the emission of greenhouse gases by 20 per cent by the year 2005. However, on 13 December 1990 the Australian stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet, four months before this decision, a report became available that not only showed the Toronto goal to be an arbitrary and counter-productive political dictate but dismantled the scientific assumptions upon which it was shakily built. After two years' work, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, formed jointly by the United Nations Environment Program and the World Meteorological Organisation, concluded its scientific assessment, the most exhaustive yet made. The panel predicted the seas might rise 20cm by 2030-close enough to the Toronto prediction-but a rise of 150cm-
which is what was said could happen-
might not arrive until 2250 . . .
That is 150 years after the worst case scenario predicted by Toronto. The article continues as follows:
. . . this November the Second World Climate Conference did not adopt the 20 per cent Toronto goal.
Dr O'Brien, who has personally been criticised by Senator Coulter, quite improperly I believe, said:
The worst fears about the worst effects of climate change voiced in 1988 are now known to be postponed by a century or more.

Overall, this clearly shows Cabinet's decision of October 1990 to reduce emission of greenhouse gases by 20 per cent a year by the year 2006. It is a classic case study of emotional responses to ill-informed activist pressure. That does not mean that we should not be taking action to diminish the impact of ozone depleting gases. What it does mean, though, to follow what Dr O'Brien suggests-I think an editorial in the Australian of 13 December outlined this very clearly-is that Australia should pit its natural resources against the greenhouse effect. The editorial concludes:

While the Toronto ethos remains obsessed with the misleading measure of per capita output of greenhouse gases, Australia could serve both its own economy and the world environment by using energy efficiently and processing minerals here. Our per capita output of greenhouse gases would rise, but sending fewer bulk transports overseas could bring a greater decline in the world output of gases.

In other words, Australia has a world role to play and should be playing it. It should not be succumbing to the ill-informed and now scientifically demonstrated nonsense that tends to come from well meaning but emotionally involved activists, supported by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of Government documents has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twenty-ninth report of the Committee of Privileges, concerning a person referred to in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

This is the tenth report of the Committee concerning a matter raised by a person under privilege resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 17 December 1990, the President, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, referred a letter from the Hon. Tom Uren relating to remarks made by Senator Robert Ray during Question Time on 12 December 1990 to the Committee of Privileges as a submission under privilege resolution 5. The Committee has considered the submission and recommends that a response agreed to by Mr Uren and the Committee be incorporated in Hansard. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The response read as follows-
RESPONSE BY THE HONOURABLE TOM UREN
AGREED TO BY MR UREN
AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7) (B) OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988

I ask pursuant to Privilege Resolution 5(1) (b) of the Senate of 25 February 1988 that the Senate allow me to respond to comments made in the Senate by Senator Ray on 12 December 1990 (Hansard, pp 5507-8). Might I draw your attention to the wide publicity in press, radio and television of Senator Ray's comments.

Senator Ray said, ``It is a long-standing principle that Australians travelling overseas, particularly those who have held high office, do not disparage their own country or necessarily their own Government while they are overseas. ``Let me make it quite clear. I do not disparage our country-to the contrary; my stand in war and peace is for the love of our country and its people.

Senator Ray chides me about what I should have said to the Iraqis. I was on a mission to seek the release of the Australian hostages-so that they could return to Australia to their loved ones. My record of fighting for democratic and human rights is on the record in the Australian Parliament-the streets and gaols of Queensland and in the records of the Inter-Parliamentary Union.

Finally, I wish to deal with the statement that hurt most and deeply: ``Maybe some of that leadership of the Left will look back to the era when Mr Uren regularly briefed former Prime Minister Fraser on internal divisions within the Labor Party.'' This is not correct.
In relation to the Fraser incident I wrote the following in a letter to a friend, which I commenced on the night of 29 June 1982:

Then, out of the blue I received a telephone call from our dear old Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. . . It was Monday night 28 June, Malcolm said, ``Tom you don't have to talk to me.'' . . . I said, ``What is it Malcolm?''. He replied, ``Have you still got the numbers for Bill?''. I replied, ``Yes''. ``Are you still supporting him?'' I said ``Yes, but with certain conditions attached to it, but Malcolm that is as far as I am prepared to discuss it.''. He said ``OK Tom''.

For the record apart from that telephone call from Malcolm Fraser-the only other time he has phoned me was on two occasions relating to my going as an Australian representative to Lord Louis Mountbatten's funeral in 1979. I understand from press reports that Mr Fraser was contacted in Tokyo and that he has denied the statements made by Senator Ray relating to me.
In conclusion-I have served the Australian Labor Party and Labor Movement for over 30 years. I would never be a traitor to the ideals of our party and our movement.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the twelfth report of 1990 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1990CHILD SUPPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, I was discussing the zone rebate, which is one amendment the Bill is seeking to introduce. The tax system certainly recognises the additional costs of living in extremely isolated areas by granting a zone rebate. This rebate was reviewed and the review recommended aligning the amount of rebate available for residents of the two most isolated of the four zones. It also recommended reclassifying the zones into which various island groups and remote towns fall. No-one will be worse off by these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has accepted the recommendations and these amendments reflect those recommendations. The measures are supported by the Australian Democrats, but they are only token measures and in no way address any of the fundamental problems faced by our rural population.

The naive free trade policies which encourage foreign governments to subsidise dumping in Australia are really hurting those in our rural industries, especially our citrus fruit and vegetable growers. The States have recently called for a massive increase in funding to the rural adjustment scheme, yet the Government has not yet responded to this need and we express some regret at that.

A further minor matter addressed in the Bill concerns the tax treatment of contaminated livestock disposals. A drafting deficiency is remedied by altering the word `destroyed' to `disposed'. This will extend the favourable treatment to situations other than where the beasts are destroyed.

On the matter of gifts, two organisations which qualify for tax deductible status have changed their names. These amendments merely reflect those changes. One of the name changes apparently occurred on 23 June 1970. The amendment is retrospective by more than 20 years yet, in these circumstances, we do not oppose the measure. As usual, we examine each amendment on its merits. In this case the amendment fixes up a technicality and we have no problem with it.

One additional matter that I need to advert to is the amendment that the Government will move to remedy the defects in the substantiation provisions of the taxation Act. This matter had its beginnings with a private member's Bill moved by Senator Watson, which the Australian Democrats supported in principle but felt was somewhat deficient in its detailed provisions. I subsequently circulated and provided the Minister with a copy of an amendment which sought to address some of the details that we found to be wanting in Senator Watson's private member's Bill. The Government asked me to defer my amendment until its amendment was available and I bow to the more extensive draftsmanship resources that are available to the Government. I believe that the amendment the Minister has circulated manages to overcome most of the difficulties in that particular area. The Democrats will be pleased to support it and we will monitor its effects during the coming 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Government on its quick response, which I welcome, to my private members' substantiation Bill. The amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) now before the Senate accept the thrust of that Bill, but they go about implementing it in a slightly different way. The Senate might recall that the earlier Bill provided a legislative discretion in examining the substantiation issues under the Income Tax Assessment Act. It was envisaged that such a discretion would have to be backed up by income tax rulings to explain how and in what circumstances the discretion would be administered. That action would be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). I think it was the AAT's lack of ability to review which was of concern to so many in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has chosen to put what amounts to be a discretion together with circumstances in appropriate legislative form. Senator McMullan had indicated in earlier responses that this was his preferred approach and I congratulate him for acting so quickly and for the manner in which he has introduced this Bill.

Unfortunately, the Bill is not quite as simple as we all would have wished. It does tend to run a little bit counter to the principles of simplification which were enunciated so clearly last week. Unfortunately, paragraph 4 tends to favour late lodgers, including even those who incur a late penalty, over taxpayers who have done the right thing and lodged early. That is only a small thing but, given the nature of the amendment, it could perhaps have had an operative date of 1 July.

I welcome the Government's response. Last week's statement on tax simplification was a first step in the right direction of restructuring a taxation Act that would enhance taxpayers' rights. This amendment currently before the Senate is a second and very welcome step.

Not surprisingly, an opposition is seldom 100 per cent happy with the way a government goes about accepting its proposals. But the thrust is 100 per cent right, the legislation appears to be 100 per cent right, apart from the problem of clause 4, but perhaps not 100 per cent can be given for simplification and presentation. I have raised a number of matters-I intend to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard those documents to which I referred during the committee stage of the debate-and I hope that those issues will be addressed later.

I thank the many people who have supported this change to lessen the previously unrealistic rigours of the substantiation requirements of section 82kt. In particular, I thank Mr Peter Roach, a former senior member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; the Australian Taxpayers Association, which is always a vigorous defender of fair taxation and taxpayers' rights; Senator McMullan, for what he has done in instituting these changes; and the former President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, Mr Richard Buchanan. I also give a creditable mention to Mr Boucher, to whom I suppose I should offer some form of apology for pushing this issue perhaps excessively vigorously. But, from the point of view of the Parliament, I believe that this issue did have to be pursued in order to resolve what appeared to many people to be an unsatisfactory position.

An important issue has arisen from a wide evaluation of the substantiation debate, both within and outside the Parliament. Apart from the Government's acknowledgment of rectifying the problem, I would also like to see the Parliament, especially this Senate, establish a line of communication with the appeals system so that the Senate can automatically pick up what members of tax tribunals and judges within the court system perceive to be deficiencies in the laws passed by this Parliament. I hope that both the Government and the Opposition parties in the Senate-and I extend this challenge to the clerks and officers of the Senate-try to establish a mechanism which focuses on the comments that come from the court system to ensure that this Senate can pick up such issues of concern and so enhance the integrity of our tax laws.

It is perhaps a coincidence that, despite all the complaints, including those from State Labor Party personnel, about the impact of the new company tax collection due on 17 December, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) actually amends the collection provisions relating to companies in the Income Tax Assessment Act to clarify that an initial payment of tax, due 28 days after the year of income, is due and payable on the relevant day. Given that the deadline for corporations which have tax commitments under $400,000 seems to be quite intolerable for many, in light of recent events, I ask the Government to look at this 28 day rule which will apply to companies balancing on 30 June and consider whether there could be a modification and perhaps even sliding scale quarterly instalments, which might overcome some of the other problems.

The major thrust of this Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is to give concessions to the banking industry, which is experiencing difficulties arising from the complex thin capitalisation legislation that was introduced in 1987. The changes that have been necessary once again add to my oft repeated argument in this chamber that there is a need to simplify taxation laws. This Government has tended to introduce more and more tax legislation which is so complex that subsequent amendments are required. I know it is difficult, and I think we have to give due acknowledgment to the Government for the problems it is facing in its attempt to wind back on anti-avoidance.

Back in 1987, the legislation introducing thin capitalisation was regarded by many as the most difficult to understand at that time. Since 1987, there has been an abundance of complex, uncertain and far-reaching tax law, all of which has taken tax law far beyond what a lot of people believe was necessary to achieve the stated or apparent purposes of the Government in tax avoiding measures. There is a desperate need to reduce the uncertainty that prevails within the business community. I acknowledge that this Bill is part of that arrangement to try to simplify the complexity of tax legislation in order to make it much more coherent.

The changes introduced in this Bill were first announced in March 1989 and many of them were made retrospective to June-July 1987. As it will confer a benefit, the Opposition will not raise an objection in accordance with its longstanding policy. However, the Opposition deplores the fact that once again the intention to legislate was the subject of an announcement by press release, issued as long ago as 30 March 1989. Approximately 19 months have elapsed between the announcement of the intention and the presentation of this Bill to the Parliament. In addition, to my surprise, some provisions of the Bill are in conflict with the information provided in the press release. This is regrettable, although it is not the first time it has occurred. This is apparently after several meetings between the banking industry and the Australian Taxation Office. If we are to be governed by press release, there should at least be consistency.

The Bill contains a number of discrepancies when compared with the press release. I refer particularly to the amendments proposed in relation to onshore holding companies, that is, the provisions to be implemented by proposed new section 159gzla. Proposed new section 159gzla (i) (c) specifies a number of conditions which must be satisfied at all times during the year of income. In particular, subparagraph (ii) requires that-and I quote:
. . . there is no amount owing by the resident holding company.
I emphasise those words because this appears to constitute a significant change from press release No. 24 of 30 March 1989, which stated:
. . . it will be a precondition to application of the amended provision that the holding company does not itself have-
and this is the difference-
any interest bearing debt to the foreign parent bank or foreign associates.

The emphasis is on `interest bearing debt' rather than the amount owing by a resident holding company. I understand that one of the basic principles of thin capitalisation legislation is that it applies only to interest bearing debt. I have been informed that negotiations are under way to try to solve this problem and I hope there will be a solution in the near future. I certainly look forward to it.

However, bouquets should also be given where they are deserved. I commend the Government for consulting with the industry and being prepared to advance amending legislation to change the structure and the operational difficulties which have arisen from the thin capitalisation legislation. The legislation proposed and now under discussion will affect the banking industry. Broadly, the thin capitalisation changes deny a deduction for interest paid by certain taxpayers on debt-related offshore entities to the extent that the ratio of foreign debt to foreign equity exceeds 3:1; obviously, for financial institutions the ratio is 6:1. These rules were originally introduced to prevent foreign investors having a free rein to use Australian tax to advantage their local operations. I fully concur with the thrust of that ideal.

The first proposed change is to exempt from the thin capitalisation rules certain balances in what are known as nostro and vostro accounts. These are essentially clearing accounts; that is, amounts owed to and by the organisation. These are offshore clearing accounts for international transactions such as foreign exchange settlements and payment or receipt of loan advances. It is normal for the account to be slightly in surplus and it is current practice that interest is not earned on a positive balance. Nostro accounts are usually in surplus for reasons such as uncertainty as to the date on which a draft issued in Australia will be presented at the foreign bank. Human error may cause a deposit in a nostro account to be late so that an overdraft advance by the offshore bank is needed to settle a debt to a third party.

Australian dollar accounts held by overseas banks with Australian banks are vostro accounts; from the point of view of the foreign bank they are nostro accounts. Under the legislation, foreign debt will exclude any amount owing by an Australian financial institution in respect of an offshore nostro account and the foreign equity calculations will exclude the amounts owing to the Australian financial institution in vostro accounts held in Australia while the accounts in the Australian institution in a nostro account are held offshore. Amounts to be excluded from the foreign equity calculation would otherwise be treated as an equity loan-back. Equity loan-backs reduce the value of foreign equity and increase the risk of a breach in the debt-equity ratio. Somewhat anomalously, credits in vostro accounts, being amounts owed by the Australian financial institution to the offshore institution, are not dealt with in this legislation, and I wonder why. Under current practice, interest is not paid on vostro balances in credit so they would not be included in the foreign debt. That is the subject of a matter which I have asked to be put on notice for the committee stage. Again, I have been informed that negotiations are under way and the Australian Bankers Association is looking forward to a reasonable solution.

Given the time constraints, I will omit some of the detail and mention that the March press release did not advise that the exclusion would be limited to foreign equity; rather, I would like to point out that a statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), dated 19 February 1990, on the draft legislation prescribes a 1 July 1987 commencement date. It would appear that this has not been incorporated in the transitional provisions of proposed new section 18 of the draft Bill.

Moving to another provision, I must say that I do welcome the inclusion of King Island, Flinders Island and other islands in the Furneaux Group in the zone B rebate for income tax purposes. The income tax paying residents of King and Flinders islands will now be allowed an extra rebate of $45 plus another 20 per cent of total dependants allowances. Again, these are standard zone B rebates. It is good to see. I think it is time that the taxation advantages that have already been given to other isolated residents within Australia were extended to this group, because it is remote and the residents do suffer significant cost disadvantages.

I would also like to point out to this chamber the significant cost disadvantages for our Australian citizens who live in the remote areas of Australia. My comments, naturally, are very pertinent to the Furneaux Group which is part of my constituency. A recent study conducted by the municipality of Flinders which examined the extra costs sustained by families on this island has estimated that it costs approximately an extra $1,200 per family just to cover marine board charges, air fares, electricity and other local government costs. It is quite a considerable extra burden.

The other provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) recognise the change from the exempt status of the goldmining industry from 1 January 1991, which necessitates a number of transitional arrangements such as those applicable to trading stock. Obviously, trading stock will have to be accounted for as at 31 December 1990 for the purpose of determining a taxable income. This can be done at either cost, market or replacement value. There are appropriate anti-avoidance measures to ensure that there is no manipulation of the inventory figures on the commencement date.

The Bill provides an alternative method of calculating residual goldmining expenditure and extends the application of the capital gains tax provisions. Again, it makes a welcome minor technical amendment to subsection 36aaa (4) in circumstances of contamination to allow an election for a year of income to be made when livestock is disposed of rather than destroyed. I commend the Bill and the necessary amendments that the Government has introduced to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place on record the Australian Democrats support for the main changes contained in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. We agree that it is appropriate that custodial parents are informed about the progress being made to recover maintenance owing to them, and we note that the Privacy Commissioner has indeed approved of this change. Family Court of Australia councillors should certainly be able to report cases of suspected child abuse to State child welfare authorities. In fact, it is reasonable that they should be alert to the possibility of child abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: It is reasonable that a period for payment should be other than annual-this would be left up to the parties concerned-so long as the agreements are clearly set out and also, as the Bill allows, the total annual payment is very clear.

A major measure in the Bill involves the enforcement provisions. Now, the enforcement provisions for the Family Law Act are extended to any court making an order under the child support scheme legislation. In other words, parents can move freely from State to State confident that maintenance orders will be enforced.

We must note however that the scheme was not set up primarily to benefit sole parents, but to transfer financial responsibility for the children of single parents from the taxpayer to the non-custodial parent. The Democrats certainly support this principle, but note that the Government has consistently failed to recognise the need for adequate direct financial assistance for sole parents. The existence of this scheme does not let the Government off the hook regarding its responsibilities to those parents and their children. There is no recognition in any Budget legislation of the poverty traps faced by single parents.

Janine Haines, when she first entered the Senate, saw the need for a change to maintenance collection and campaigned strongly for change. However, the support payment is tested differently from and more harshly than earnings. Sole supporting parents are allowed only $15 for one child and $5 for each additional child before their pension is reduced. If a sole parent is relying just on the pension and the support payment, he or she will be worse off than when maintenance was treated like any other income.

In-kind payments are also included. Obviously, those who drafted the legislation were aware of the problems and tried to limit the damage. The support payment does not reduce a pension or benefit by more than 25 per cent of the maximum rate for in-kind or imputed capital maintenance during the first six months after separation where in-kind maintenance is paid by the marital home or alternate housing and where money is paid for the special needs of a child, such as a handicap. I quote from the Institute of Family Studies assessment:

. . . when the recipient household is dependent on public support, child maintenance payments are immediately deducted from the supporting parent benefit. Thus, although the scheme doubtless improves the material circumstances of many children whose mothers are not on public support, it may not do so for those who are receiving the SPBN. In the latter case, the new scheme will have altered the public-private balance of responsibility without improving the child's circumstances.

Both parents remain responsible for the economic support of their children according to their capacity. For this reason, the level of maintenance paid under the formula relates to the income of the non-custodial parent and will not vary with the actual cost of caring for the child or children for whom it is paid.

I briefly refer to a chart published in Family Matters, the newsletter of the Australian Institute of Family Studies, in October 1987. It clearly sets out the costs of raising children and shows very clearly the differences between raising a two-year-old, a five-year-old, an eight-year-old, an 11-year-old and a teenager, the amount more than doubling between the age of two and the teenage years.

Normal maintenance is usually not varied with the circumstances of the custodial parent, although it will be reduced when a custodial parent earns more than average weekly earnings. Custodial mothers will continue to pay for at least half the direct costs of their children, probably much more if they have teenagers. At the same time they are likely to earn less and to have less favourable opportunities in the job market than non-custodial fathers. The mothers will bear the burden of the indirect costs of having children.
In closing, I stress that this Bill does nothing to alleviate the hardships being experienced by the many sole parents, mostly women, who are living in abject poverty.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill because I have spoken so frequently in this chamber about the Child Support Agency since it was established. As Senator Alston said, the second reading speech does not really tell us a great deal about it. We support the amendments, one of which will enable the Child Support Agency to inform custodial parents of the progress of recovery of amounts due to them. I have had frequent complaints to my office and have referred before in this chamber to the inability of supporting parents to get any information concerning the progress of the Agency's efforts to recover maintenance entitlements. It has been very frustrating for those involved and it has contributed significantly to the fact that the Agency has been seen or thought to be not doing everything it possibly could to assist. I understand that the staff have been constrained until now, but I would be critical of the way the explanations and requests for information have been dealt with on occasions. Things could have been explained in a much better fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had women contact me and say that, when they have inquired as to how a recovery is progressing, they have been told, `It is none of your business any more, as the debt was owing to the Commonwealth'. While it is technically true that the debt was owing to the Commonwealth, it is an appalling suggestion to say to a supporting parent that the collection of the maintenance that he or she is owed is none of his or her business. So I welcome this development, which I believe will significantly reduce the frustration of clients of the Agency who simply seek information about what is happening.

While the Government is in the process of reviewing the current legislation and making changes, I suggest that another issue needs urgent attention. It affects some of the Agency's clients. There is no doubt that the Agency has collected money and people are now paying maintenance who have not paid it previously and should have been. We supported the legislation when it came into the Parliament and we support the concept. However, I refer to the situation of parents who, prior to getting involved with the Agency, had a totally satisfactory arrangement with their former spouse in operation in relation to the payment of maintenance.

Cases have come to my attention where totally regular payments of the proper amount of maintenance have been made, this in many instances having gone on for years. Once parents register with the Agency, the payments are totally disrupted, causing financial hardship to those involved. They are not entitled to any greater amount of maintenance by virtue of registering with the Agency. No social security savings are involved, yet the parents are put to the inconvenience of having to miss payments for up to eight weeks and frequently longer while the Agency gets the records onto its computer and functioning. Anyone who thinks that eight weeks without the money that is needed for the support of children is not significant does not know much about running a family.

To use one example, I was contacted by a woman whose husband had been divorced from her for many years. He had paid the maintenance to her bank account directly from his salary over those many years, and never once had there been the slightest problem. The woman had never had a late payment and never suffered a non-payment. She was working herself, was able to budget and knew exactly what her financial situation was. When her young son became ill, she was forced to resign from her employment and go onto the supporting parent's benefit. Because she did that, she was required to register with the Agency, and that is when she got into financial difficulties. As a consequence, she missed two months maintenance. There was no suggestion that her former husband had not continued to pay the money due, precisely as he had done for many years. But in no time the payments were two months in arrears and she was trying to cope with that. Then, of course, she was paid only once a month instead of every fortnight, even though her former husband continued to make his payments as he had always done.

During the two months that she was without this money she had to borrow. She ran up credit on her credit cards. She had to pay credit charges and other expenses, all of which put her into a difficult financial situation. She proposes to return to work when her son has recovered. Then, hopefully, she will be free to resume the former good relationship she had and have the money paid directly into her account. In the meantime, she has been caused substantial financial hardship.

The purpose of the supporting parent's benefit ought to be to assist parents in a situation like this where it is necessary that they give up work for a time to look after a sick child. This woman was required to register with the Agency even though she had proof positive that the father of the child had made payments without any difficulty for a number of years. In cases like that, any subsequent lapse of payment would have to be registered. No-one is denying that. But in a case where the record shows quite clearly that the payments have been made regularly over many years, there should be no need for anyone to have to get involved with the Agency and get into financial difficulties as a consequence of the enormous delays that occur and the length of time it takes to become registered.

I have spoken before of the outrageous way the Agency behaves in taking enforcement action. It makes the decision that until maintenance is $1,500 in arrears, a case is not worth pursuing. Some honourable senators may not think being $1,500 short on housekeeping money is highly significant but I suggest that it is. Arrears of $500 or even $200 in maintenance are highly significant. Yet somebody makes an arbitrary decision that it does not matter. The scheme cannot be allowed to continue in this fashion, even though in other respects more money is being paid for the support of children. We must see that these anomalies are wiped out.

In the case where it is clear that maintenance has been paid properly over a number of years, it should not be necessary for a woman to get involved with the Agency and suffer trauma and expense as a consequence. It should be possible to allow her to go on to the supporting parent's benefit and let the proper arrangement continue.
