If that breaks down, I acknowledge that we would need to take the other steps that I have referred to. While something is being done to make the system work more efficiently, other arrangements still need to be put in place.
Time does not allow me to mention a number of other matters concerning the Agency and the support and maintenance of children. I have raised two points today and I shall leave it at that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the limited time in which we have to deal with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1990 and the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, I will not traverse everything that honourable senators have said. Although in many ways the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is an important Bill to many individuals and their tax arrangements, it has not aroused great controversy here today. Therefore, I will be brief in summing up the second reading debate. However, I want to put on the record some comments about the Child Support Agency which was referred to in the context of the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I want to deal with Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4). I think the description of the legislation has been traversed by Senator Watson and Senator Spindler. In particular, they dealt with thin capitalisation, which is the major element of the amendment. The Bill is designed to modify a scheme which limits interest deductions for Australian companies on borrowings from related foreign sources.

We are seeing the outcome of a lengthy consultative process which was foreshadowed in March 1989. It is important that we give the opportunity for that sort of consultation. People may be frustrated that they do not have certainty in terms of outcome during the period. But it is impossible to have a consultative process and an immediate outcome-the two things are contradictory. We could arbitrarily have proceeded to legislate without consultation-it would have been quicker-but we would have had very understandable cries of concern from people that the consultation had not been adequate and that we had moved too quickly.

I understand that people would like the best of both worlds but I regret to say that the realities of government are the realities of life: we cannot have both and we have to choose. We have tried to have the consultative process and deal with the drafting as expeditiously as possible.

There are some important transitional provisions in the legislation for the goldmining industry. An amendment was outlined by Senator Spindler and I will deal with that during the committee stage. It would be a waste of time to do so now.

There are some changes which relate to quarrying and zone rebates. In the first instance, those changes are substantially technical, and in the second, they are entirely beneficial to people. So, they are not matters of any controversy. The zone rate rebate changes are in response to a review by the Treasury.

I thank Senators Spindler and Watson for their comments about the Government's proposed amendment on substantiation. For the sake of the record, I will speak to that when it is introduced. That being the case, it would be a waste of valuable time to say more about it now. I thank honourable senators for their support for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4).

I also appreciate the unanimous support for the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill. I think everybody agrees that, whatever their views about the merits of particular sub-parts of the program, the overall program is beneficial and these amendments improve it. I can understand that constituents with concerns about the child support scheme come to my parliamentary colleagues in both Houses. All I can say is that there are 224 members of parliament. I think I get 223 times as many letters as anyone else-I get my own and I get everybody else's as well. So, I understand that a lot of individuals have difficulty. That is inevitable.

Two of the most volatile issues in Australian society are brought together under one scheme-that is, family law and taxation. This is a combustible combination. Each time there is any concern, that concern is magnified several times by the financial and emotional implications tied up in these matters. This certainly places enormous pressure on the staff of the Child Support Agency.

I have visited nearly all the Child Support Agency offices in Australia and I can assure honourable senators, other members of parliament and taxpayers that these people are very dedicated and are working under extreme pressure. We should be grateful for the work that they do. That does not put the staff, the Agency or the scheme beyond criticism but I want to put on the record my appreciation for what they do.

I thought I should try to put into context the nature of the benefits which flow from the scheme. I will do so very briefly-it is a subject about which one could talk at great length and that would be entirely inappropriate. First of all, I will try to put into context one thing which Senator Reid said. I will then make some general comments before concluding.

Senator Reid referred to some arbitrary $1,500 limit in respect of the collection of outstanding maintenance obligations. I know of no such limit. To the best of my knowledge-this was checked again today-there is no such limit. If it occurred in one case, I can only imagine this was generated by the time taken for the process. There is no such arbitrary process and there should not be. Sometimes there are such de facto limits on other debt management activities of the Australian Taxation Office but different arrangements apply to the Child Support Agency because every dollar counts to individuals.

But individual problems arise for taxpayers, citizens and non-custodial and custodial parents, both of whom can in different circumstances face difficulty. We need to acknowledge some of the facts that put the individual problems into context. Some $10m a month is being distributed by the Department of Social Security on behalf of 138,000 children.

That is an enormous task which puts the individual problems in context but does not make them any easier. It is a 100 per cent problem for the individual who faces it. I acknowledge that and, to the extent that we can help, the Government tries to facilitate assisting in the problems of those people, because sometimes people do have to face very harrowing individual circumstances. It is a small part of a very big successful operation. It is not even the tip of the iceberg; it is a smaller proportion than that.

We also find that there has been a much higher percentage of maintenance collection than was occurring prior to the scheme. The assessment is that prior to the start of the scheme only 30 per cent of court ordered maintenance payments were being paid, and these frequently at irregular intervals. The indication is that the Child Support Agency collects 71 per cent of liabilities registered with it. That is an enormous turnaround. It is still not perfect-and it will never be 100 per cent, for reasons that people understand. Seventy-one per cent is not a level that we are satisfied with but it is a tremendous leap forward. Average payments of maintenance have also increased substantially. The average amount of maintenance paid per child has gone from $27 to between $39 and $49. There are an enormous number of children in need in Australia whose circumstances have been very substantially enhanced by the child support scheme and by the work of the Agency.

The substantial delays in registration which Senator Alston referred to, and which Senator Richardson acknowledged in May, have been substantially overcome by a major increase in resources for the Agency, and there is no major backlog there now. However, due to the number of cases being dealt with individual cases will still be delayed, and sometimes there is difficulty in getting people to pay their entitlements. We not only inherit responsibilities but also we inherit the very distinct reluctance on the part of some people to meet their obligations. These people often go to extraordinary lengths to avoid their obligations. We will continue to pursue all such cases as assiduously as we can.

The child support Bill enhances a scheme that is performing a major social justice role in our society. However, there is room for further improvement. I am happy to continue to discuss the scheme with honourable senators from all sides of the Parliament and look at areas of improvement. I just wanted to put in context the tremendous benefits that are flowing, so that the criticisms that have been aired-and many of them involve real and tangible human problems for individuals-are also put in context. I thank honourable senators for their support for both Bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 4) 1990
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 7, page 2, insert the following new clause:
``7a. After section 82kza of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:
Relief from substantiation requirements in special circumstances
`82kzaa. (1) Where:
(a) a taxpayer claims to have incurred an expense during a year of income; and
(b) having regard to:
(i) the nature and quality of evidence that the taxpayer has available to substantiate the claim; and
(ii) special circumstances affecting the taxpayer, including, but not limited to, the following:
(a) the extent to which the taxpayer attempted to comply with the substantiation sections;
(b) whether the taxpayer's failure to comply with the substantiation sections was inadvertent or deliberate;
the Commissioner, in the course of reviewing the claim after the making of the assessment of the taxpayer's taxable income of the year of income, is satisfied that:
(iii) the expense was incurred by the taxpayer during the year of income; and

`(2) For the purposes of this section, the Commissioner is taken to have made an assessment of the taxpayer's taxable income of the year of income if the Commissioner has served notice in respect of the taxpayer to the effect that:

`(4) This section applies to an expense incurred before, at or after the commencement of this section.'.''.

The amendment answers the concern expressed by some members of the community that the substantiation provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 may, in certain circumstances, be too harsh in their application. Honourable senators will remember in an earlier second reading debate on a private member's Bill dealing with the substantial requirements I indicated that the Government was looking at possible measures to deal with any harshness that might arise in the application of the substantiation provisions. We feel that neither Senator Watson's amendment, nor another amendment put forward by the Australian Democrats, were appropriate answers.

The amendment I have moved should overcome any concern as to the harshness of the law that might arise in particular circumstances while maintaining the integrity of the substantiation provisions. The amendment proposes relief from the substantiation provisions in respect of an expense item on review of an assessment where the Commissioner of Taxation, having regard to certain matters, is satisfied that the taxpayer has incurred the expense, and also that it would be unreasonable for the provisions to apply to not allow a deduction for the expense.

There will be no relaxation of the substantiation requirements in anything other than exceptional individual circumstances. Taxpayers will be required to demonstrate that a genuine attempt has been made to comply with those requirements. As I have already indicated, the Government is concerned to ensure that the integrity of the substantiation provisions are not threatened.

The change to the income tax law will only apply in respect of assessments which are reviewed on or after the date the Bill receives royal assent. The rights of taxpayers who have sought an amendment or lodged a valid objection will be maintained. When lodging their returns, taxpayers will still be required to declare that they can substantiate all claims through employment related expenses. I present a supplementary memorandum and commend the amendment to the Committee.

I thank the Government for this amendment.

Question 5.1

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cattle Transaction Levy Bill 1990, the Beef Production Levy Bill 1990, the Cattle Export Charge Bill 1990, the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill 1990, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1990, the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1990 and the Cattle Industry Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990 will introduce a transaction levy to replace the existing slaughter levy in order to obtain the necessary finance for the running of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, the research and promotion activities for the cattle industry and any other finance that is necessary for this important Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills are intended to spread more evenly the burden of financing the operations of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation between the live stock producers, the meat processors and the exporters of Australian beef.

Currently, the slaughter levy is collected at the point of slaughter by the processor. It is the responsibility of the processor to forward all proceeds to the Government and then through to the industry. Although the slaughter levy will remain in place, we are moving away from a situation where a levy is applied at one stage of production.

The transaction levy will be payable on store, prime or stud sales of cattle. The transaction levy differs from the slaughter levy because the slaughter levy was imposed on all cattle that were processed at meatworks. The transaction levy will be payable on all store and prime cattle that are sold and all stud sales. In the past, none of these cattle has been subject to a levy, except in the case of prime cattle which are moved into the meatworks.

The background to these Bills dates back to 1987 when the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council recommended the transaction levy for cattle after the 1987 annual general meeting of the industry. These Bills have been the subject of some very lengthy debate throughout the beef and dairy industries for a number of years. In spite of the strong support for a change to the current system, mainly from the processing sector, the Bills coming before the Senate will be tested and reviewed at the end of three years. The levy on cattle sales can be altered at any time during the three years if the system does not work.

There will be three components to the new levy: a flat rate per head levy on all cattle sales and transfers of cattle from the production to the processing stage, which will be payable by the vendor or the owner at the time of transfer; a beef production levy on a cents per kilogram basis on beef and veal produced, which will be payable by the owner of the carcass; and a charge on live cattle exports on a cents per kilogram basis, payable by the exporter.

Dairy cattle traded for dairy purposes will be exempt from the transaction levy and export charge. The initial levy rates have been set so that the producer, the processor and export sectors share equally the costs of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation operations. The producer sector has accepted the responsibility for the funding of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign and the national residue survey which is currently collected with the inspection fees from export abattoirs.

Although this is a much more equitable way in which to spread the financing of the cattle industry, it is going to cause a few administrative changes to the collection of the levy. In the past the slaughter levy was very easy to administer. There were no leakages and sides of beef could be clearly identified and the levy collected. The new transaction levy will be much more difficult to identify and administer, as it will be necessary to collect at various stages of production.

There are concerns with these pieces of legislation, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, himself pointed out during debate on 7 November 1990 in the House of Representatives. He said:

The scheme is more expensive. It is more administratively cumbersome. There will be more leakage, less auditing and a lot more trouble with it. Rather than looking again in 12 months time, I can see quite clearly that there will be a need for amendments through these next three years.

As a representative of a large constituency of cattle stations spanning right throughout the Northern Territory, I should mention just how important this industry is to Australia. Looking at statistics provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics-the exports Australian monthly summary tables for June 1990-beef contributed $2.3m of foreign exchange earnings in 1989-90.

In terms of volume, a total of 672,000 tonnes of beef was exported: 328,000 tonnes, with an export value of $997m, to the United States of America and 181,000 tonnes, with a value of $803m, to Japan-Australia's main importer of beef. These figures indicate the importance of not only the industry but also the valuable exports Australia currently needs.

In conclusion, the industry has recommended these measures as a fairer way of collecting the levies needed to finance the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, to finance promotion, disease control and research and development. The Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill, the Beef Production Levy Bill, the Cattle Export Charge Bill, the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill, the Cattle Industry Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, because in essence Senator Tambling has comprehensively summarised the intent of the package and, for the edification of those who were listening, the history of the industry and its value to Australia. I hope that the Government and the coalition support that amendment. The Australian Democrats will support the other amendments which have been foreshadowed. Our industries will benefit greatly if this package of Bills is passed with our amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this package of Bills, especially the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill even though there are a multitude of others. This Bill came about as a result of a report of the AMLIPC, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Corporation, at the request of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, about the way slaughter levies for the AMLC are collected. Currently a flat rate exists at the point of slaughter and on export of live stock. At the time, processors of meat or livestock thought that the flat charge levies fell unfairly upon them. They wanted these charges to be spread more evenly across the industry. They were wrong in assuming that the burden fell on the processors. As I have said plenty of times before, processors pass all their costs back to the producers; the buck stops at the producer. So that concept was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The report recommended an excise on meat produced by the processing sector and then a flat transaction rate for cattle moving from production stage to the processing stage. It also recommended a form of slaughter levy for sheep, goat and buffalo meat. After further discussion between the industry and the AMLC, the AMLC recommended to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that only cattle be included, thus excluding sheep, goats, et cetera. We have finished up with a recommendation that there be an excise on meat produced by the processing sectors and a flat rate for the transaction to the producers. But the recommendation did not solely include the cattle going from the producers to the processing stage; it included every sale after stock is born. Each time they are sold from one farm to another, a levy is paid. That is a form of sales tax. We should not have this at all.

Under this system producers pay 75 per cent of all the levies collected while processors pay the 25 per cent excise. As I have said before, the whole bill finishes up with the producers. This is not good for the production side. As I have already said, there are quite a few sales from the person who breeds the stock right through to when the stock finally gets to the processor. There are various reasons for this: there is lack of feed and there are bush fires, especially this year with farm fires in New South Wales where the stock will have to be on sold a few more times before they get to the processing stage.

Unforeseen problems arose from those recommendations and this Bill. The main complaints that have come to me have been from the pastoral regions, where properties are sold only on a walk-in walk-out basis-lock stock and barrel; the whole lot. Of course, when one has a cattle station with about 20,000 head, there is an immediate bill of $120,000 that has to be paid by the vendor on the signing of the contract. This is contrary to the spirit of the original recommendation. The inquiry said that there was to be a levy on cattle as they passed from the production stage to the processing stage. In a walk-in walk-out transaction it has to be paid on every head of cattle immediately. It is slightly different in agricultural areas where if a farm is sold then cattle are sold at a clearing sale; they are scattered to the four winds. These people are not affected as much. But in a walk-in walk-out transaction there is a great burden on the vendor. This reflects on the price that someone else is prepared to pay.

We then have to look at the concept of this slaughter levy being paid by a vendor of a pastoral property. If someone has 20,000 head of cattle the bill totals $120,000. This will not help that vendor one iota as he is moving out of the industry. All levies on production or processing should be ongoing so that the ones paying can get some advantage in research, marketing or whatever. In a walk-in walk-out transaction, the buyer of the property will immediately start to pay on those cattle when he starts trading. If he starts selling in five or six weeks he will have to pay the levy again. As I have said, in agricultural areas matters are slightly different.

I now come to the finer points of the problems of implementation. The cost of collection and the cost of compliance have increased dramatically. In fact, they have increased by 250 per cent. The previous system cost $400,000 to operate; it is now estimated to cost $1m. The Cattle Council of Australia simply said, `Yes, it is 250 per cent. It is increasing from $400,000 to $1m. So what? It is only one per cent of the budget'. But these days one per cent makes a lot of difference in someone's turnover. The rate of return for cattle producers in the last three years is as follows: in 1987-88 the return on capital was 1.1 per cent; in 1988-89 it was 5.2 per cent; and in 1989-90 it was minus 0.02 per cent. So one per cent-although it is not right across the board-will make a difference. All these things have to be watched. So much for what the Cattle Council has had to say. As far as I am concerned it is about as irrelevant as the Wool Council of Australia and the Grains Council of Australia are in this debate.

This also creates uncertainty in the market. I have already mentioned the high cost of collection and the high cost of policing. I do not know how we will ever police it. Before the system could not be by passed, either at the point when stock went through slaughter or were exported, and the levy had to be paid. Now that the levy will even be paid on private sales between farmers I believe that many will slip through the net.

Briefly, in winding up, I reiterate what I have said about all these problems which have to be addressed, especially that relating to the walk-in walk-out transaction in cattle stations. There is no other way to do this. The other point I intend to mention briefly is the exemption allowed for cattle traded for dairy purposes. Dairy cattle are ultimately slaughtered for their carcass value.

I believe that, unless the exemptions are extended at least to the walk-in walk-out sales, the cattle industry will get slaughtered and it will be left open to rorting by people dodging the system of collection. That matter should be addressed. In conclusion, let me say that I support the Bill. Because this measure is being implemented on a three-year trial basis, some of us will be back here in three years time to debate this matter again, and I consider that we will then return to the original system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating cognately the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill 1990, the Beef Production Levy Bill 1990, the Cattle Export Charge Bill 1990, the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill 1990, the Cattle Industry Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1990, the Livestock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1990 and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill 1990. There seems to be very little confidence in the decision that the slaughter levy on cattle should be replaced by a transaction levy. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has left the slaughter levy Bill in place, but has reduced the slaughter levy to zero in case the new transaction Bill does not serve the industry as is intended.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that the industry, the Cattle Council of Australia and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) see some benefit in moving towards a transaction Bill because they believe that the costs will be spread more equitably across the whole industry. On a superficial look at the Bill, I suggest that ultimately the market will decide who pays the levy. Inevitably, the producer will end up footing the Bill irrespective of which way the levy is collected.

We are here to put this legislation through and, therefore, we give it support. The slaughter levy will be reduced from $13 to $5.83 and that latter amount will be paid by the vendor from purchase to purchase. The beef production levy will be 2.17c per kilogram at the abattoirs and the charge on live cattle will be 1.09c per kilogram. The purpose of the Bill is to involve the whole industry in the collection of the money to finance the AMLC in its promotion, disease eradication programs and overseas sales.

I believe that the AMLC has done a good job in the promotion of meat. It has done an excellent job in lifting sales of meat in Australia. This industry is worth $2.5 billion in export sales. It is one of the few industries in rural Australia that are showing some positive performance at the moment. I suppose we could say that the cotton industry and the beef industry are the only ones that are showing some light at the end of the tunnel.

There are a few problems for the Australian meat industry. One of the big problems facing the industry next year is the increase in quarantine inspection charges from $82m to $104m. That is an increase of about 60 per cent to recover the total inspection charge. The coalition's policy in that regard is for a 50 per cent recovery.

Although increased inspection services are to be provided by meat inspectors, the average wage for a meat inspector is $35,000 and the Government is to charge $65,000 for placing a meat inspector in an abattoir. That is a very considerable charge which will have to be placed on the industry and recovered by the industry. The industry can live with that as long as the meat inspectors provide services. That is not happening at the moment.

We have seen a whole range of industrial disputes by meat inspectors closing down abattoirs throughout the country. The Government seems to be inept in doing anything about this. If the industry is paying $104m, it would like some say about how these meat inspectors will be employed. The industry will pay the freight and, rightly, it wants some input as to how these meat inspectors will perform. There is an industrial dispute concerning long service leave entitlements following the transfer of some meat inspectors to the Commonwealth system. Strikes over long service leave entitlements are occurring in various abattoirs throughout the country. I hope that the Minister can come to terms with those people. As I said before this industry provides jobs for many thousands of people and at the moment it is one of the only performing rural industries.

I want to conclude by saying that Australia now produces the purest and most disease-free and chemical-free beef in the world. It is very important for Australia that the game is played fairly so that we can take advantage of the quality of our product. We are running into problems-and it is a feature of the world beef market-in that we are now finding subsidisation in many countries. These policies are hurting and are very harmful to the efficient producers in Australia who are not subsidised in any way to compete in the overseas beef market.

The European Community (EC) has distorted the beef trade. It is imposing quantitative import restrictions and import levies. It has intervention purchasing systems which maintain the producer prices at levels well above world prices and the producers have massive export subsidies. The result of those provisions has been that the EC now has become a major exporter of beef compared to 20 years ago when it imported beef. Figures just released yesterday from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics were disastrous for Australian rural industry. They show that we are in danger of losing some of our beef market to Korea and Japan if the EC continues to subsidise some of its overseas production. The Andriessen assurance has largely kept EC products out of Japan and Korea. I just hope that the EC continues to observe that Andriessen assurance.

The only hope that I see on the horizon is that the EC will be facing a subsidy bill next year of $41 billion to continue to provide subsidies for its rural producers. That $41 billion will have to be funded by the consumers in the EC. Those consumers are going to be paying excessively high prices for their staple food products. One would think that political pressure will be felt by the governments of the EC regarding their subsidies for farmers when their constituencies are faced with very high prices for food products when good quality, well-produced food from free market countries such as Australia can be obtained.

In the short time available to me, I wanted to point out the problems facing our rural producers as a whole. Now that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round is moving into its final days, we are all hoping, I believe, rather than expecting, that it will come up with some conclusions that will allow free trade in the world. I think that Australia has more than played its part. It has reduced tariffs; it has lifted the sugar embargo; it has done so much to lead the way in world trade, yet no other nation has followed Australia's lead. I believe the Government could be accused of giving away many of our bargaining chips in its negotiations with the EC, yet we have not had any assurances that our rural producers will receive fair treatment. If the GATT round fails, maybe we can look at what we have to do when we come back in the new year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill, the Beef Production Levy Bill, the Cattle Export Charge Bill, the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill, the Cattle Industry Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Live-stock Export Charge Amendment Bill, I think it is important that I outline the rationale behind the changes that are being made and how the money will actually be spent.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous speakers have outlined what is occurring in terms of the financial take on individual cattle. The $13.07 slaughter levy and a live cattle export levy have been taken away. In their place there will be a transaction levy of $5.83, which will be paid by the grower, and 2.17c per kilo which, in theory, will be paid by the processors. In looking at this matter and the rationale behind it-this has been negotiated between the various cattle industry organisations around Australia over the last 2 1/2 years-we see when we break it up that $63m of the total sum goes directly to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) to cover its running costs, promotions, et cetera, of which $31.5m will be paid by producers, and processors will pay $31.5m from the 2.17c per kilo levy.

As has been mentioned by other speakers-and Senator Boswell in particular-I think that it is very important in these times that the AMLC, in terms of its international promotion, be well funded so that it can maximise that promotion. I believe that Australian beef is one of the best red meat products in the world. As has been mentioned, Australia also has one of the cleanest industries in terms of chemicals, controls, et cetera. We have a very fortunate marketing opportunity in terms of promoting this around the world. It is worth noting here that the figure works out at $3.15 per transaction, and it is envisaged that there will be some 10 million transactions in total. This could well be a conservative figure in terms of likely developments in the future. Of course, if that happens we will see the potential for the levy to be even less because the fund is not designed to make a profit; it will just recover costs.

The next arm of this particular transaction levy is the research and development arm of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation, which will raise in excess of $9m, of which the producers will pay $4.6m and processors $4.6m. In looking at the figure of 10 million transactions, that equates to 46c per sale.

The brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign (BTEC), which I understand should be completed by 1992 or thereabouts, has an annual requirement of $21m, which equates to $2.10 per head. All of this portion of the expenditure will be raised from producers. Of course, this is directly related, as the benefit of having clean herds flows back to the producers. One of the principal reasons why the industry is deciding to change to an overall transaction levy which covers all animals at the point of sale, not just those at the point of slaughter or those being exported overseas, relates to particular aspects of the BTEC program. Senator Panizza and Senator Tambling quite rightly raised this aspect. I believe that this legislation will be back before us in due course, not because it will need major amendments, but because we can envisage some difficulties in terms of the walk-in walk-out sale provisions.

These provisions apply particularly to station sales of cattle, mainly in the north. Currently those in the north are the direct beneficiaries of the BTEC program, because southern Australia has been clean for a number of years. There is no suggestion that the whole industry should not pay for the BTEC program, but I think it is fair to say that in the past a disproportionate share of the cost has been paid by southern cattle producers, as opposed to northern cattle producers. If it works, this legislation will bring a little more equity to the whole equation.

The next part of the expenditure raised relates to the national revenue survey. This is a random survey in which all primary producers take part to provide feedback on the state of the industry. Once again, as with the BTEC program, all of this money will be provided by beef producers. This annual requirement amounts to $1.4m. This equates to 12c per transaction.

Presently, the total amount required for the slaughter levy is in the order of $93m. Of course, if the projections are that there are going to be about 12 to 13 million transactions, as it is proposed just to cover costs and not to make a profit, the $5.83 levy could be lowered in due course.

In the time remaining to me in this debate, I would also like to refer, as Senator Boswell did, to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) operation. Obviously, that will be subject to a different debate and a different speech. But there are some equity problems in terms of the administration of that Service, particularly with the move to what is called full cost recovery. In my view it has gone past full cost recovery because it is not just the producers who benefit from the AQIS operation. It has flow-on effects, and that is something that we will have to address in future debates.

While the $93m required is a lot of money, it is really a small ticket item in terms of total costs or the impediments on the industry now. We must overcome the industrial disruption that occurs in the meat industry. It has been very damaging to the industry and has not helped our export performance at all. Equally importantly, we need to address the current killing costs. Analysis consistently shows that in this country it costs up to double the amount that it costs our competitors to slaughter and process a beast. The real challenge facing this country's meat industry is to get our killing costs down so that we can become internationally competitive. This will make it so much easier for us to compete with subsidised beef from Europe and other countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is discussing seven Bills-I repeat: seven Bills-under a guillotine where we simply do not have time to debate them. They are all important Bills because they all relate to the cattle industry, and the cattle industry is one of the few successful industries left in Australia. The Bills involve increasing charges or imposing new charges on the cattle industry. They are well deserving of review by this House of review. But, as we have a government which cannot govern, it is not surprising it cannot run a parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a bankrupt government that has bankrupted the country. In my time as a senator-and I am now in my thirteenth year-I have never seen a government on the treasury bench with so little energy as the present Government. Not only is it bankrupt of energy, it is also totally bankrupt of ideas. We have got into the mess we are in with the guillotine because the Government simply could not run the program. Up to last week the Parliament had sat for about 13 out of 49 weeks this year, and now we are faced with the impossible situation of running through 52 Bills without any time for debate. The Bills were not debated in the other place because they were put through under the guillotine. The purpose of this chamber is to review Bills and get rid of the mistakes in them that this Government generates.

It would not have been possible to have had this guillotine dropped on us if the Australian Democrats had not changed their position. They gave the Australian public fervent promises the last time they helped to impose a guillotine. I have in my possession a letter from one of their senators to the Parliamentary Liaison Officer written in August 1988 promising they would never do it again, that that would be the last time. But now they have gone along with the Australian Labor Party in jackbooting this legislation through. The consequence is that we simply do not have time to discuss this very important legislation because we are all on about a five-minute speaking block. I could not attempt to move into what are technical Bills-seven of them-in that time.

At the outset I declare a personal interest in this subject. I am a beef producer and, sadly, the Australian Commissioner of Taxation takes some money from me every year as a consequence of that. The Bills change what was formerly a slaughter levy to a number of levies covering various parts of the cattle industry. The Bills are: the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill, the Beef Production Levy Bill, the Cattle Export Charge Bill, the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill, the Cattle Industry Legislation (Consequential Provisions) Bill, the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and the Livestock Export Charge Amendment Bill. Earlier speakers from the Liberal and National parties have outlined the general intent of the Bills.

One of the allegations made by all speakers is that the industry wants these Bills. I do not challenge the concept that some people in the industry want the Bills, because, formerly, beef producers who sold into abattoirs paid a slaughter levy but breeders who were selling store cattle to the industry did not. Obviously, not all, but a proportion, of the former category-those selling to abattoirs-would welcome a proposal to spread the load.

All I can say is that I have known a lot of people in the beef industry for a number of years and not one person that I know has raised with me the matter of supporting this legislation. I take with a grain of salt the universal claims that have been made in this chamber that the industry supports these Bills. I doubt very much, if a mandatory poll were held across the industry, that a majority position of support for the Bills would be found. Be that as it may, the legislation is before us.

What will happen is that there will be a flat rate per head on all cattle sales and transfer of cattle from production to processing stage, payable by the vendor or owner at the time of transfer; there will be a beef production levy on a cents per kilogram basis on beef and veal, payable by the owner of the carcass; and a charge on live cattle exports on a cents per kilogram basis, payable by the exporter. It could be argued that in one sense those taxes are regressive because the more successful the producer is at producing a heavier beast, the more he will have to pay in the levy. It might be argued that he has benefited more from the research programs that have enabled a heavier beast to be developed, but I think, on balance, one would come to the conclusion that in that sense it is a regressive tax.

It is interesting that a number of carcass producers are excluded, and they are the sheep, buffalo and goat producers. They may be the smart ones-they decided not to join the scheme, or persuaded the Government not to bring them in. I find it very interesting that some sections of the industry could be granted an exclusion, as well as the dairy cattle section that Senator Panizza referred to. I do not doubt that a case can be made for them, but I think if a case can be made for some it can be made for all.

One of the difficulties I see with these Bills is that they increase the number of levies. Whenever the number of charges is increased, administrative costs are always increased. It does not matter whether it is a statutory authority, a marketing board or a government department, once it gets its sticky fingers on money it gets involved in an empire building process and more and more money goes into administration. When, initially, one charge is split down to two or three, and those subsequent charges are at a lower level, it becomes that much easier for the authority to increase them and build them up. I have no doubt at all that the consequence of these Bills will be far higher costs to the beef industry.

There are a lot of other charges on the beef industry, as Senator Panizza and Senator Crane mentioned. It is not only these that we are paying; we are also paying a lot of other charges and they are going up time after time. It is very interesting to look at the graphs of who gets what nowadays out of a beast before it ends up on the table. In the last five years there has been a change and the beef producer-the cattleman-has gone into a minority position. Until about five years ago the producer got most of the price: probably over 45 per cent went to him and the rest went to the processors and the retailers. The ratios have now changed quite significantly. I do not expect that beef producers will ever go back to playing the dominant part in the price of a beast-the retailers and processors will end up getting quite a bit more out of the deal. That has consequences in the long term because the costs of producing keep going up. Pasture improvements, water retention schemes and all the rest of it impact very heavily on beef production and, if the profitability is not in the industry, the industry simply cannot grow and take up the export markets that we need.

While I am on the business of costs being loaded onto the cattle industry, I would like to mention the very regressive tax of the Queensland Government-another Labor socialist government-and what it has done in the last 12 months in hiking up the registration fees for farm trucks to quite astronomical levels. If the Commonwealth has its way with its road schemes, under its plan for semi-trailers the costs will go up again in years to come. This is important because truck transport is an essential part of the cattle industry. Very little droving is done these days and rail is not an alternative solution.

In the minutes left to me I would like to look ahead briefly to the future of the beef trade. I am very concerned that there is a degree of euphoria about the Japanese market which may not be realised in due course. When the Japanese liberalise their markets they are going to put a 70 per cent import duty on beef. That is an extraordinarily high tariff. As a consequence of that, there will be a great incentive on beef exporters to land beef as cheaply as possible into Japan.

Given the integration that is occurring with producers and abattoirs and the vertical integration in the Australian market, it is as well to be a little cautious about where we are going. I do not have time to develop this theme this afternoon, but I am very concerned that the Government is totally oblivious to the dangers we are facing with Japanese and overseas domination of the beef processing outlets in this country.

We have seen the number of abattoirs reduced to about half the number that they were 10 or 15 years ago. Abattoirs have the power of life and death over the industry. They set the price and they actually decide whether they will take producers' cattle. Formerly the abattoirs and the producers had a pretty good relationship in this country. When times were bad in drought conditions, the abattoirs accommodated people who wanted to reduce their stock numbers; and, conversely, producers made cattle available for abattoirs with an export order when they were not as far forward as they would have liked.

There are signs that that relationship is changing. The abattoirs have the power to set the price for the product and to decide whether they will take the cattle. They are the people who write the export orders and if they are facing a very high tariff penalty, like 70 per cent on their exports, there is very great pressure on them to keep the price to the Australian producer as low as possible. That is a matter I will develop here at a future time, but I would welcome some consciousness on the part of this lethargic Government of the dangers we are facing in the industry at that level.

The other great problem in this area was referred to by Senator Crane; that is, the archaic work practices in the industry and the difficulties of getting efficiencies into the abattoirs because of the meat workers unions. I do not need to mention here the great number of strikes we have had in Victoria recently.

To return to the Bills, other speakers have commented on the fact that there is a fall-back position whereby the pre-existing slaughter scheme could be reintroduced in three years. I have never seen that in a Bill before. We now have a special provision to come back to the original legislation. This indicates the Government's lack of confidence in this legislation. Nevertheless, the Opposition will not be opposing the legislation.

``12a (1) Before obtaining the consent of a person for the purposes of section 12, an authorised person shall inform the person that he or she may refuse to give his or her consent.

These amendments serve a common purpose of meeting the criticisms of the Bill which were published by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I am disappointed to receive an indication that neither the Government nor the Opposition intend to support these amendments. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee had several concerns about certain aspects of the Bill. Clause 13, for example, allows magistrates to issue search warrants. The `magistrates' so defined include justices of the peace. The Alert Digest published by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee suggested that an amendment to remove the definition which included JPs would be appropriate in order to safeguard the interests of people in rural areas who wanted a tighter definition of the person who would be capable of issuing a search warrant.

Further, clause 12 allows an authorised person to enter and search premises and to seize material. The Committee suggested a way to strengthen the consent mechanism. The Democrats want to follow the suggestion made by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in that regard, because we believe the civil liberties of people whose premises were about to be searched could be compromised unless some arrangement is made to strengthen the consent mechanism. I cannot see any problem with following the recommendations of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in that regard.

I do not think it would burden the legislation too much to accept our amendments. Having been given the information in the discussion, we will persist only with amendment No. 3, which is to clause 15. I express our disappointment that no support could be garnered for the other amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will oppose the Democrat amendment to omit the definition of `magistrate' from this legislation. The coalition believes that it is important to point out that the term `magistrate' should include a justice of the peace because so often in rural areas access to a magistrate-let alone a judicial officer, which would be the intent of the Democrats-is not possible. The coalition recognises the importance of that factor to the rural constituency and the effect that such a change may have.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrat amendment requiring consent to enter premises is also unnecessary to this piece of legislation. Inspections are hardly ever carried out and when they are the Department of Primary Industries and Energy needs to be fully convinced that someone is cheating the system. The money involved in the collection of the levy is money from producers rather than that of government. Therefore, the less money collected by way of levy, the more everyone in the industry is affected. Furthermore, this would be the first time that a levy was subject to such a clause, thereby proving to be a contradiction in relation to other levies which come under the umbrella of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Specifically the coalition opposes any amendment which stands in the way either of collecting money that rightfully belongs to producers or investigation where cheating is going on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I must do what I omitted to do when I spoke during the second reading debate, and that is declare my interest as a cattle producer.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking to the second amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, I support my colleague Senator Tambling. Honourable senators may recall that I spoke firmly against the imposition of a collection levy Bill. But if we are to have a levy-and we have a budget-we should collect as much of it as possible, if not 100 per cent. For everyone who cheats, somebody else will have to pay more. I do not understand the Democrats' wish to remove justices of the peace from the definition of persons who can sign search warrants. Justices of the peace are used for the simple reason that magistrates are not always available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let alone a judge.

—Yes, let alone a judge. In remote areas it is utterly impossible to get to a magistrate in reasonable time. Does one have to wait until a magistrate comes around once a month, and only 11 times a year at that, or does one have to travel to a magistrates court, which adds to the cost which will ultimately come out of the pool? I inform the Democrats that justices of the peace are reasonable people. If they were not, they would not have been appointed in the first place. For that reason, I support my colleague Senator Tambling and reject the amendments moved by the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly indicate that the Government also will not support these amendments, other than the one to which agreement had been previously indicated-that is, amendment No. 3. I am not sure that that is something we would have initiated. But we accept that that is an amendment with which the Government can comfortably live.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the question about the definition of `magistrate' and the inclusion of justices of the peace, there has been a lot of debate and controversy over a long time about the role of justices of the peace. It is proper and reasonable for members of Parliament, members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and others to be concerned about ensuring the integrity of things such as search warrants. However, one also has to live with the reality of life in remote areas of Australia. Although I now represent the Australian Capital Territory, where the problem does not arise-although justices of the peace still play an important role in this city, but not for the same reason-having come originally from Western Australia, I am familiar with the circumstances that can arise which make the availability of a magistrate either practically impossible or possible only at a financial burden that would make the whole thing unworkable.

We have to have a compromise. It is proper that we look at these concerns because over the years there has been debate about the role of justices. But this is an area where I think the appropriate balance is being struck and it is necessary that the working arrangement continue. For that reason and because we want to see the continuation of the reasonable and cooperative arrangement which field officers have established in the past in the operation of this very important function, we do not accept the other amendments. TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be pressing this issue with any great urgency. It is really a matter of definition. It is typical of the Australian Democrats that they involve themselves in this definitional nonsense. Clause 15(1) of the Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary may cause an identity card to be issued to an authorised person.
The Democrats are now seeking to change the word `may' to `must'. But if we read further down the same section relating to identity cards, we find that clause 15(5) reads:

Where an authorised person proposes to enter premises otherwise than in accordance with the warrant issued under section 13, the authorised person must produce his or her identity card to the occupier of the premises for the occupier's inspection and, if the authorised person fails to do so, the authorised person is not entitled to enter the premises under section 12.

Whilst the Democrats are inserting `must' as part of the first subclause to ensure that the Secretary to the Department now must issue an identity card to all public servants in such a situation, the public servants could not have carried out the task anyway. Therefore, I think the Democrats are purely playing with words.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTENNIAL ROADS DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — This afternoon we are debating the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill. It is interesting to note the words of the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Robert Brown. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there has never been a piece of legislation brought before this Parliament which is as important and significant in the development of an integrated land transport system as this piece of legislation.

Therefore, it is the belief of the Liberal and National parties that we must get this legislation right. In order to get it right, the Opposition will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage to ensure that a clear definition is given of the way the Government will spend this money. The Liberal and National parties believe that the legislation, as drafted, is too loose and leaves too much to the discretion of the Minister. As drafted, there is absolutely no guarantee that this Government will not attempt to establish a half billion dollar war chest to pork barrel marginal seats in the lead-up to an election campaign.

The legislation has been guillotined through the House of Representatives in the most cavalier and irresponsible fashion. I think it is worth noting that a piece of legislation described by the Minister as being the most important and significant for land transport in history is now being guillotined through the Senate by the Government with the connivance of the Australian Democrats. I wish to foreshadow that the Opposition will be moving substantive amendments to the Bill in the committee stage.

The Bill changes the name of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act 1988 to the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988. It will amend the Act so that a separate appropriation from Consolidated Revenue can be paid into a trust fund. It will also provide three new categories of assistance from 1 July 1990 from a separate appropriation from Consolidated Revenue. The three new programs of funding are for the three new categories of assistance announced during the last Federal election campaign and in the Budget, and they are as follows: provincial cities and rural highways projects; black spot projects and road safety measures; and urban public transport projects.

As drafted, the distribution of funds among the States under the three categories would be at the Minister's discretion in accordance with national priorities. There are no fixed State shares. It represents a policy change on the part of the Government towards targeting Commonwealth funding to nationally important projects. While a national approach is worth while, the Bill as it stands opens up a Pandora's box as far as the Government's whim to put funds where it sees fit is concerned, whether or not the States want that particular type of funding.

The Liberal and National parties believe it should be a matter for individual States rather than for the Federal Minister to decide which nationally significant roads receive attention. This was, I understand, an understanding reached at the recent Special Premiers Conference. This type of funding was to be by way of block grants rather than specific funding, and yet we are back to the old specific funding days. The States, of course, are in a much better position to judge, and there is absolutely no explanation for the present Government changing the rules unless it is leaving the way clear to embark on a giant pork-barrelling exercise.

The Liberal and National parties will move an amendment to guarantee each of the three new programs-in other words, a share of the additional funds promised by the Government at election time will be incorporated in the Bill, not just mentioned in the second reading speech. As I mentioned earlier, while the recent Premiers Conference looked towards the concept of general purpose funding, this piece of legislation points to the retention of road funding as a specific purpose grant.

During the election campaign, the Government promised to devote $100m a year for the next three years to the provincial cities and rural highways program, financed from the new 20 per cent sales tax on luxury cars or the $100m, whichever was the greater. Why is there no mention of this in the Bill? Does this indicate that the tax announcement was just an election gimmick or will the Government not make $100m on its sales tax? The Liberal and National parties wish to make sure that the funding is guaranteed whether or not the Federal Government reaches its target of $100m from the sales tax of luxury cars.

The Government also promised $120m over three years to the black spots program, where dangerous spots on the road would be fixed in return for the States or Territories accepting a 10-point safety plan. The Liberal-National parties view is that those black spots should be rectified regardless of whether the States or Territories comply with the Federal plans. Surely it is more important to fix dangerous black spots than worry about a few points not being agreed to by a State or Territory.

The Minister said in his second reading speech that total land transport assistance would be increased by 13 per cent in real terms in 1990-91, but funding for roads goes up only 1.9 per cent in real terms. As capital investment in State rail has not been funded by the Commonwealth for a number of years, it is misleading to talk of such an increase, especially given the progressive fall in land transport funding since the Hawke Labor Government came to power. Road funding has fallen by over 27 per cent in real terms in that time and is set to continue to fall over the next 10 years. At the same time, hypothecated fuel excise as a proportion of total fuel tax has fallen from well over 50 per cent to under 25 per cent.

The Liberal-National parties believe that a share of total trust fund moneys should be guaranteed to roads. The way the Bill is drafted at present, the Minister could slash the amount of money that goes into roads entirely at his discretion.

Federal allocation to the States for rail investment, excluding Australian National, has fallen from $65m in 1982-83 to zero in 1989-90. It is estimated to be only $50m in 1990-91, a fall of over 60 per cent in real terms-hardly what one would call a land transport program.

The question is: who should be paying for improvements in the railways? This is supposed to be a road funding Bill, but the Government has moved an amendment to change it to a land transport Bill. It is clever footwork, but who will pay? The Government has discovered overnight that it is time to start spending more and more money that basically comes from the motorist, and in a very limited respect from rail, on urban transportation and railways. We will move an amendment at the committee stage to restrict the amount of money that will be allocated from the trust fund to the railways so that our deteriorating roads are provided for. We will restrict the Government to undertakings given in the Minister's second reading speech. That is really the basis of our amendments-to restrict the Government to its own undertakings.

Our second amendment also refers to amounts allocated from the trust fund and specifies in percentage terms expenditure on capital railway projects, urban public transport projects and approved organisations. We do not wish to see a disproportionate amount of funding steered towards one area, such as urban transport projects, at the expense of other necessary work.

The Bill announces that $50m will go to the National Rail Freight Corporation (NRFC). We support the principle of the NRFC, but its establishment should be looked at in perspective. Improvements to interstate rail freight are appallingly overdue and any improvements are not before time. The fact is that interstate rail freight accounts for only 15 per cent of the total freight carried by rail and losses on interstate rail freight are currently running in the order of about $300m per annum. Railways in Australia are now losing close to $3 billion annually. This move is a step in the right direction, but a palliative.

The coalition is very much in favour of reform of the rail network. We see it as one of the key priorities in Australia's micro-economic rehabilitation. Not only should there be substantial safety and environmental benefits from reducing the amount of projected traffic-especially heavy vehicles-on our major corridors, but there is magnificent scope to increase efficiency. When transportation costs are reduced, it follows that there will be significant gains for our agriculture and manufacturing export industries.

As with waterfront reform, there is no room for featherbedding of unions or prevarication where tough decisions must be made. We shall move amendments to clause 12 of the Bill which relate to the power of the Federal Minister. As I mentioned earlier, we believe that the decisions about these funds are best made by the States, which are much closer to understanding their own needs and priorities.

Finally, I refer to the matter of road tolls. Section 32 (1)(m) requires the States to seek the Minister's written permission before a toll can be applied to any road that has been wholly or partially funded out of the trust fund. We believe that this allows too much discretion to the Minister and we consider that the States should be able to apply a toll on a road in proportion to use of State funds. We shall be moving an amendment at the committee stage accordingly.

As foreshadowed, the Opposition will be moving amendments to the Bill in committee. When these amendments were moved in the House of Representatives the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) made the extraordinary comment that while there was nothing inherently wrong with those proposed amendments, the Government opposed them because they were not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill 1990, which amends the Australian Centennial Roads Development Act 1988. It is more than a Bill to fund road development; it is more a land transport Bill because it covers railways as well. The Government is obviously now moving towards catering for land transport. The Government fully admits that it is attempting to help railways and says that it wants to put railways on an equal footing with road transport. I do not quite know what it means by that. If rail transport is not on an equal footing with road transport at present, then I believe it is the fault of this Government and previous governments, which have let it fall down over the years. I believe that taxing road transport is quite an unusual way to fix up the problems besetting rail transport.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) said in his second reading speech that he wanted a land transport sector in which both road and rail undertake the task to which each is suited. I totally agree with that concept. He went on to say that we need a rail system that is more efficient and competitive. I have no disagreement with that proposition whatsoever, but there is no way in the world that trucks would be able to compete with rail on the long haul between capital cities.

However, road transport is able to compete with rail transport. Trucks can compete because of the inefficiency of the rail system. I believe that the Government has a long way to go in tackling that problem, but I do not believe that it is going the right way. It will kill off road transport by charging it out of competition under the ruse of removing distortions in State revenues.

I will mention a few facts about road transport. Firstly, it is predominantly a local industry. Road transport's biggest employer is the domestic freight market; it is close to home. It carries 78 per cent of the total domestic freight of 1.5 billion tonnes. The average length of haul is 70 kilometres. How can the Minister tell me that it is a more efficient method to move that amount of freight by rail?

Generally, the loading of freight starts at the producer's door. Not all factory yards have a rail link. Basically, freight would be loaded onto road transport, hauled to a rail yard and then shifted to rail transport. At the end of that process the situation would be reversed. That cannot be done as it just does not work. Road transport carries 78 per cent of total domestic freight on an average of 70 kilometres, which is one-third of the task in tonnes per kilometre rather than volume or tonnage.

In addition, interstate freight amounts to only 4 per cent of the total freight. So how much can we move to rail? The estimate of inter-capital road freight, as distinct from interstate rail freight, in Australia is only 10 million tonnes per annum. Inter-capital freight is only 0.66 per cent of the total domestic freight of 1.5 billion tonnes. So there is very little potential for the overlapping of the two systems. Those calling for wholesale conversion from road to rail do not know the facts. Their idea is that, as the Government and others have been preaching, freight should be taken off the road and onto rail and that that will solve the problems of road accidents and so on. That is a simplistic solution which does not heed the facts.

It is estimated that around Australia at present 10,000 trucks are on the road interstate every day. If no changes occur to general expansion, by the year 2000 there will be 20,000 trucks per day on the roads. The best estimate of the additional volume of traffic carried by rail is the equivalent of approximately 3,000 trucks per day, which is an 80 per cent increase on the present figure. On those figures, we will still be 20 per cent short on the projected tonnages that have to be moved by the year 2000. So there will be a bigger demand on roads even if rail transport carries what it is intended to carry.

We cannot blindly say that all will be well if we get freight off the roads and onto rail; any society needs both systems. Certain commodities are better suited to certain modes of transport: for example, bulk freight should be carried by rail and general freight on road, rail and, no doubt, air. In remote and sparsely populated areas, road is the only choice that we have.

What worries me is the way that the Government has let the rail system go down the tube. The rail system has been starved of funding and has outdated work practices. Of course, we still have the three different gauges that we had 70 years ago or thereabouts, different safe working systems and different awards, which all add up to a maze of inefficiencies.

Not only has there been a lack of funding for rail but also a massive reduction in real terms in road funding. To illustrate that, I refer to a chart of the Federal allocations to the States for rail investment for the years 1969-70 to 1989-90. In Fraser's last Budget of 1982-83, $65m was allocated to rail. In the first year of the Hawke Government, 1983-84, the allocation was cut to $11m, and in 1984-85 to $7m. By 1988-89, the Federal Budget made no allocation to rail. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, has seen a copy of the chart. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

Road funding by this Government in 1988-89 is 7 per cent less in real terms than under the Fraser Government in 1982-83, even though the fuel levy is 132 per cent more than in 1982-83. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr O'Keefe sought to know why 2,000 trucks per night use the Hume Highway when a standard gauge railway line is running alongside it. I believe I have already given that answer. We must ensure that rail is run by private enterprise and get away from the work practices that this Government perpetuates in eternity in this and other places.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to the section of the Bill on roads, the Bill sets up three new transport funding programs-the provincial cities and rural highways program, the road safety black spots program and public transport projects. These programs are, of course, in addition to the existing programs for national highways, national arterial roads and State arterial roads.

What concerns me is that under this Bill funding for State arterials will cease, yet the category is to be left in place. I am sure that the position is left open for any Minister during an election to use that as a lollipop jar. I believe that the black spots program, which is worth $120m, was an off-the-cuff decision made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) leading up to the Federal election campaign. That program was announced as a result of the big vehicle accidents on the eastern seaboard. Honourable senators will remember that the program was opposed by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at the time, and we know what has happened to it since. Of course, that brought in the `jealousy tax' that I have mentioned before on vehicles worth over $43,000 retail.

This Bill allows ministerial discretion on top of ministerial discretion on top of ministerial discretion. The Bill simply allows the Minister to do virtually what he likes when he likes, especially at election time. I believe this Bill will play havoc with the transport industry and that those ministerial discretions ought to be eliminated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by saying through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to Senator Panizza, that the opportunity for ministerial discretion is not confined simply to Federal Ministers, and examples of pork-barrelling are also not confined to activities of Federal Ministers. As the name suggests, the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill 1990 is primarily a roads Bill. However, this Bill also makes provision for urban public transport and for rail development.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats feel that the areas of public transport and rail require significantly greater support from the Federal Government and believe that these areas should, in the not too distant future, be the subject of separate legislation. Since 1950 the total length of Australian roads has remained relatively constant at about 800,000 kilometres. Over that same period, however, the number of vehicles on our roads has steadily risen from fewer than 800,000 to over nine million, at the time of the last Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of motor vehicle usage in September 1988.

In addition, there has been a marked increase in the number of articulated trucks on our roads over the last two decades with their freight task growing fourfold between 1971 and 1988. Trucks have also been allowed to increase their gross vehicle masses and therefore increase axle loads. This has led to sharp increases in the wear and tear of Australia's roads, many of which were never designed to carry an all-up weight of 42.5 tonnes-a limit introduced in the eastern States at the bidding of the Federal Government in 1988.

During the 1980s there has also been a marked increase in long distance coach travel. The build-up of heavy vehicles over recent years operating on our inadequate road system contributed to the two tragedies that occurred late last year on the Pacific Highway claiming no fewer than 55 lives. At the same time as increasing calls on the Federal Government to make more of the funds collected from fuel taxes available to road works, there are pressures to contract fuel levies. We have seen calls for the Federal Government to reduce its fuel tax in the wake of increased oil prices following the present Middle East crisis. As world oil prices go up and our own domestic supplies of oil go down, it will become increasingly harder for the Federal Government to maintain its taxation of oil relative to its cost price.

This will make it more important to look to other forms of revenue for road maintenance and construction. In the future, this may include some form of congestion pricing for cars in the central areas of our major cities. Alternative funding mechanisms should most certainly include mass distance charges for heavy trucks and buses. But to blame all of our road problems on trucks, however, would be to miss the point. We must also be looking at demand management for car use in cities and this will require significantly improved urban public transport.

A further reason for improved public transport and rail networks is the need to both conserve liquid fuels and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Work by Dr Peter Newman and others at Murdoch University shows that our major cities are wasteful by world standards in the fuel usage per capita. Added to this problem are reports that despite some improvements in recent years, the fuel usage of the average Australian car of about 9 litres per 100 kilometres is higher than the average American car which uses only 8 litres. We have too many cars moving drivers simply to and from work in congested cities where the cars are being left to sit in car parks all day. This is clearly when people should be using public transport which is far more energy efficient at peak loadings than cars carrying one person only, but in order to do that we have to have efficient public transport systems.

The old policies enshrined both in the Australian centennial roads development legislation and the amendment Bill before us today place an overemphasis on roads, provide inadequate funding for urban public transport and rail and need to be reassessed. Despite the overwhelming importance of the need for improved public transport and the Government's claim to recognise this need, the Bill we are debating has limited provisions with only $55m for 1990-91 and a mere $200m over three years for the urban public transport program. These amounts compare poorly with previous allocations made in the 1970s, and Senator Panizza used a similar comparison. I have a table detailing these allocations under the Urban Public Transport Agreement 1973-78 and the States Grants (Urban Public Transport) Act 1978. I seek leave to have this table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
