TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. While the Government boasts of its commitment to public transport we can see from this table that the allocation of the $55m for the coming year is, in real terms, only one-half and, in some cases, only one-third of the allocations to public transport made between 1974 and 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: The value of the large grants given in the 1970s was clearly demonstrated by its inducement to the Queensland Government to electrify Brisbane's suburban railways. When the first line was electrified in 1979, patronage of the Brisbane rail system had fallen to a low 29 million passengers. By the time of completion of electrification in 1988, patronage had risen to 45 million people a year and it is now approaching 50 million. This shows that people will use modern reliable public transport if it is available.

This figure of $230m, which the Democrats proposed in their alternative Budget, is insignificant when compared with the total Australian investment in motor vehicles estimated by the Inter-State Commission (ISC) of some $14 billion. Because of the level of imports in the motor vehicle industry, much of this enormous expenditure is a charge against our balance of payments. Added to this expenditure on motor vehicles is a further $5 billion a year on roadworks, $6 billion for road crash trauma, $2 billion for road congestion and an ISC estimate of $1.3 billion for noise and air pollution. Where such enormous costs are involved, more economically and environmentally efficient alternatives do need to be considered.

I believe that the provisions in the current Bill for main line rail upgrading, like the Government's past record in the area of rail, are totally inadequate. There is a need for a commitment from all parties for ongoing Federal support to bring our rail system up to modern standards which is capable of efficiently supporting both export oriented industry and interstate freight and passenger movements. As a former Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam, recently said in connection with Federal initiatives, the 1980s were a lost decade for rail.

When discussing rail matters, too often we find emphasis on deficits, poor management and work practices. Senator Parer, like the shadow land transport Minister in the lower House, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), referred to a $3 billion rail deficit. Our understanding is that the deficit over all rail for 1987-88 was just $16m, according to the Industries Assistance Commission in its report last year on Government non-tax charges. While there is scope for smaller deficits, it needs to be noted that productivity has improved.

In a recent report the Rail Industry Council noted that the work force had fallen from 114,000 in 1979 to 79,000 in 1990. But, during this same period of time, the rail freight task increased over 30 per cent. We need to take combined action to remove some of the real problems that limit rail efficiency. These problems include: five different rail systems operating interstate passenger trains as well as freight trains; three different gauges; a multiplicity of unions and awards; main line interstate tracks in New South Wales with steep grades, sharp curves and tight clearances; and last, but certainly not least, a heavily subsidised interstate road freight industry.

To run freight trains with modern intermodal capability of double stacked containers, one needs a good track with gentle grades, easy curves and good clearances. The only interstate links in Australia meeting these requirements are Adelaide to Perth, and Adelaide to Alice Springs. Coupled with good management on the part of Australian National and Westrail, rail has a high modal share on these corridors. It is essential that the other corridors linking Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane are upgraded to what is now called fast freight train (FFT) standards.

The most recent example of upgrading in Australia to FFT standard was that by Queensland Railways between Brisbane and Rockhampton. The result is that freight trains formerly of only 750 tonnes and taking 15 hours or more to travel between these cities are now of 1,250 tonnes and take just 12 hours. These savings make rail freight more competitive and the benefits to rail passengers are also obvious.

The cost of this rail track alignment upgrading was about $90m. Most of this cost was in the four major deviations, one of which was at Eumundi north of Nambour near the Sunshine Coast. Here a section with steep grades and sharp curves was replaced by 10 kilometres of track with a gentle gradient and easy curves for a cost of about $20.5m. That is roughly $2m per kilometre through difficult country. Compare this with $151m for a 32-kilometre deviation of the Hume Highway over the Cullerin ranges between Goulburn and Yass at an average of $4.7m per kilometre.

The new train services between Brisbane and Rockhampton have attracted more passengers. Operating costs are held down with modern equipment and driver-only operation. Even though new day services were introduced, passengers still have the option of overnight trains with sleeping cars. We now see the Federal Government and Australian National, despite this evidence from the Queensland situation, trying to withdraw trains linking Adelaide to Whyalla, Broken Hill and Mount Gambier. Rather than doing this, Australian National should be getting direction and financial support from both the Commonwealth and South Australian governments to buy new trains and to run them efficiently.

Whilst the formation of the National Rail Freight Corporation by 1 July 1991, with the support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premiers, is most welcome, as I have already said, infrastructure investment is also needed. This was identified by the national freight initiative (NFI) as costing at a very minimum $178m, being $80m for freight terminals in our five mainland State capitals, plus $98m for very basic track work. NFI also gave cost estimates for Adelaide to Melbourne gauge standardisation at $250m and for bringing Sydney-Melbourne to modern FFT standards at an extra $210m. The Democrats regard these two major works as absolutely essential and note the total NFI capital works package as costing $630m.

The cost effectiveness of this total package is clear when one considers that it would, with efficient operations, eliminate a $300m a year deficit on interstate rail freight operations. In doing that it would also lead to reduced road wear and tear, reduced road trauma, savings in liquid fuel and less pollution. The savings in total transport costs that can result from having more freight on rail have been noted by many authorities.
Senator Panizza interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Panizza that I am using my share of the two hours; it is being divided only between myself and Senator Spindler. These costs were examined for the Melbourne-Sydney corridor in the Centre for Resource and Environmental Studies working paper of Dr Phillip Laird, published in May 1990 by the Australian National University. Dr Laird's paper stated that no fewer than 37 lives were lost in road crashes involving articulated trucks on the Hume Highway in 1988-89 for the movement between Sydney and Melbourne of about five million tonnes of road freight. The paper noted that rail freight is now at a level of about two million tonnes a year and it states that, if rail were upgraded and won the right to carry five million tonnes a year, still leaving two million tonnes for road transport, there would be a saving in total transport costs of about $100m a year. That is a $100m saving between Sydney and Melbourne alone. Further, there would be savings in liquid fuel of about 70 million litres a year.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst these are initial estimates only, they clearly show potential gains far too important to ignore. The Democrats see a need for the Government to indicate and legislate for ongoing main line upgrading. Such upgrading should not be restricted to interstate main lines, but should also allow for export main lines such as the completion of the Maldon-Port Kembla railway.

Other rail-related matters in need of Government commitment include a need for an evaluation of rail infrastructure and the establishment of a land transport research centre, as noted in the September 1990 communique of the Australian Transport Advisory Council. Finally, the Federal Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics needs to increase its research output on rail and rail-related matters.

I do not agree with Senator Panizza that it is wrong to take things off roads and put them on to rail. I agree that there is a place for both. But I also make the point that this Government-and we have had eight years of previous Labor governments-has not shown a genuine commitment to improving the fate of rail in this country.

I would like to foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to require an annual report to be tabled each year on the Australian Land Transport Development Trust Fund. I will speak to that, I hope, in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues have said, the Liberal and National parties generally support the thrust of the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill 1990, in particular the part to increase Commonwealth Government funding of road transport programs throughout the nation. For some time there has been an enormous realisation throughout the community of the rip-offs that the Government gets from excise levies on fuel. There has been a wish that some of this be ploughed back into the roads that so badly need it.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years the fuel excise has increased from around 6.155c per litre when this Government came into power to about 24.9c per litre now. In that time, with the tax rip-off rising by almost 18c, the amount that the Commonwealth has used to fund road construction has only risen from about 4.5c per litre in Fraser's day to about 5.8c per litre now.

A major campaign was launched prior to the last election by the Local Government Association of Queensland and its counterparts in other States, and also by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland and its counterparts in other States, calling upon all political parties to increase funding by something in the order of 2c per litre to bring it up to about 7.8c per litre. The Liberal and National parties promised in their election campaigns to increase funding by 2c, but it was not matched by the Government. The Government was, however, moved by this pressure from these organisations and from the Liberal Party to make some commitment. Halfway through the campaign the Australian Labor Party (ALP) changed its policy, because of public pressure, and promised $500m over the next three years. The Liberal Party's policy would have given $1 billion over the next three years for road funding.

It should be pointed out that it is probably fair that those people who use the roads the most-that is, the ones who buy all the petrol-should pay an extra amount for the roads they use, but so little of the fuel excess going back into roads simply means that those of us who live in areas far removed from the capital cities where we must have road transport are paying more tax to the general revenue. We buy so much more petrol and we pay so much more tax. That is not too bad if that tax goes back into road funding, but unfortunately it does not; it goes into the general coffers. This means that the people of rural and regional Australia are ripped off again-and this Government, I suggest, does that with relish.

The provisions of this Bill incorporate three new road funding programs, but a fourth major measure of the Bill is to abolish the allocation of funds to the State arterial roads category. That can mean horrific cuts in funding for many State arterial roads throughout this nation. I am particularly concerned that in Queensland a large number of kilometres of very major roads that fell into the State arterial category used to be funded by the Federal Government. Following the adoption of this Bill, that will no longer be the case because I understand that all those roads which used to be funded by the State arterial roads program will now have to be funded from general State revenue without any increase to the States in the form of general grants for State arterial roads.

I am very concerned that in north Queensland, where I come from, many of the major roads will no longer be funded under the State arterial roads program. I will mention just a few of them. They are: the Gregory development road from Charters Towers to The Lynd; many roads in the Thuringowa area: the Herveys Range road which runs from Townsville to the west; and the Bowen to Collinsville road, which is a very major road and has received a lot of Commonwealth funding under the State arterial roads program. All of those projects now will not be getting this sort of funding and will have to be funded from State funds. But the States, unfortunately, will not be getting any increased road funding in this general category to fund those programs.

The three new categories are the provincial cities and rural highways program, which will apply to roads that are not national highways, but which do offer potentially large returns in terms of transport efficiency. I am aware that the road between Richmond and Hughenden on the Flinders Highway is being put up for that program, and I certainly hope it does receive the nod for funding under that program. There are a lot of other roads in north Queensland that well deserve funding from that provincial cities and rural highways program, but I understand that they are not going to get the nod. They include the very important Kararamanga road which bypasses Cairns and, as I have mentioned, the road from Charters Towers to The Lynd; the Bowen-Collinsville road; and the Herveys Range road.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very important roads.

—They are very important roads and they in fact mean a lot to the wealth of this country because they bring cattle and other products to the ports. They should be funded but they will not be because, of course, the Minister has the discretion and one wonders how he is going to use that discretion. Following the election promises of the Australian Labor Party, a new program is being introduced to fund the black spots-the roads with bad safety records. The third program, which I will not even touch on, is the one relating to capital expenditure for urban public transport. But the $505m being provided over the three years is in addition to existing payments to that fund.

SPEECH.PARA: I have very grave reservations about certain aspects of this Bill. The first is about the discretion of the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown). Senator Parer and Senator Panizza have mentioned that discretion. We are left with the Federal Minister to use his discretion on where these funds are to be spent. But I think that is the same Minister who, just before the last election, decided to have the maritime surveillance centre put into his electorate so that he might retain his seat. That was done purely for political pork-barrelling. Is this the same Minister who is now going to exercise his discretion on where funds are to be spent throughout Australia? It seems to me that he is just going to use it to prop up the oncers who got into the other House in the last election. It is probably fortunate that there is a oncer in Kennedy, because maybe we will get some funding out in that seat to try to prop him up. Of course, he will only be there for three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't need propping up.

—Of course he does. By the same token, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), who has been around for a little while, will not be there after the next election. But one of the good things, I suppose, is that this Minister will try to put some funds into Leichhardt, into Herbert, which the current honourable member (Mr Lindsay) will lose, into Kennedy and even into Capricornia, that is, if the ALP still has a member there, because I think he is fiddling around with the factions and will probably end up with Australian Democrats by the time the next election comes around. But at least we might get some funding there. However, it is rather horrific to think that this Minister is going to have the discretion to do all of these sorts of things.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to say a lot of things on this Bill, but the Government's guillotining is just atrocious. I can understand why it does not want full discussion on these Bills. It does not want the people of Australia to know how it has stuffed things up in the past and how it will, we believe, not do it properly in the future. I did just briefly wish to recommend the amendments that Senator Parer will be moving on our behalf.

I also just wanted to briefly touch on another aspect of the Bill which requires the Minister's permission for toll roads to be built throughout Australia. Talking of toll roads reminds me of the Sunshine Coast toll road in Queensland. The Labor Party, before the last Queensland election, promised to abolish the toll that the previous Government had imposed on that road. It promised it and promised it. It won the election, and what did it do? It continued it immediately. It just shows that, when the ALP starts talking about road funding, it cannot be believed at all. I understand that Senator Spindler is going to move an amendment so that $250m will be spent on some Victorian road. I suggest that money should not be spent in Victoria, but should be put into the Queensland tollway. An amount of $100m is all that is needed, and the Labor Government up there could take it all.
Senator Kernot interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I must inform Senator Kernot that he has cribbed about $80m. Senator Kernot, as a good Queenslander, will not support that ridiculous amendment from Senator Spindler. I do know that the ALP will do anything to try to prop up that Government in Victoria because, boy, does it need propping up. What did the ALP get in Victoria-24 per cent! The Government will have to spend all of the road funds in Victoria just to try to buy the Victorian voters off. But it will not work, of course. The Victorian voters have the Government's measure, and it will go out. Why Senator Spindler and the fourth wing of the Labor Party here want to try to help the Government buy off the Victorian voters is beyond me.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, in the very restricted time that I have because of the Government's guillotining, can I just say how terrible it is that, in this new federalism that was spoken about at the Special Premiers Conference, the Federal Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) is now trying to give himself the power to direct where all the funds are spent. That will mean setting up yet another Commonwealth Government bureaucracy. The infrastructure is already there. All of the States have it. They have their engineers; they have their programs; they have their officers; and they have their planning organisations. Now we are going to set up yet another one, increase the bureaucracy here and increase the number of people in Canberra earning these huge moneys down here in this ivory tower. That does not need to be done because it is already in place in the States, and it is a matter of some regret that that has happened. The idea of the Bill giving more money to road funding is good, but the way it is being done is typical of this Government's administration of all of the things that it tries to administer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald's speech will be a hard act to follow and I offer him my congratulations. As has been said by previous speakers, this Bill comes here into the Senate under the guillotine. But it also was pushed through under the guillotine in the House of Representatives. I think that the Minister for Land Transport, Mr Brown, should have been prepared to discuss this Bill. Indeed, he should have been prepared to stand up in the lower House and defend the Federal Government's performance or lack of performance in relation to road and rail funding. But this was not the case and perhaps, when we look at the Government's disgraceful record, it is easy to understand why it is not so keen to be subjected to the sort of scrutiny that it would have been subjected to in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the Labor Government use the petrol bowsers of this country as a milking cow for its election promises. Obviously, Labor has not given the same priority to road funding which the coalition has. As has been said by previous speakers-I think Senator Parer mentioned this, but it bears repeating-since Labor has come to power road funding has fallen by over 27 per cent in real terms. This is a fact which the Government cannot hide. At the same time, hypothecated fuel excise as a proportion of total fuel taxes has fallen from well over 50 per cent to under 25 per cent and petrol excise has risen to nearly 25c per litre. This situation has had a crippling effect upon petrol prices and upon goods and services which must be transported by rail.

Recently, the General Manager of the Royal Automobile Club of Tasmania, Mr Dennis Nation, was prompted to call upon the Government to reduce the amount of excise on fuel as a counter to balance the Government's recent windfall gains. Mr Nation argued that in 1986-87 when world oil prices were at a low level this Government had a Budget shortfall in revenue from petrol excise. It therefore decided to increase the level of excise to bring its Budget into line. Unfortunately, however, the situation has not been reversed and the Government has thereby benefited from unreasonably high fuel tax rates whilst the world parity price for oil is artificially high. This effect doubles when the consumer price index (CPI) formula is applied to the excise component on petrol, thereby ensuring that the Federal Government simply cannot lose.

We must also remember that there is a resource tax on crude oil which is paid for by the oil producer and every time the price of crude oil increases by $1 per barrel this Federal Government benefits to the tune of an extra $60m to $100m. When the Budget was prepared in August the expectation was that the price of a barrel of oil would be about $23, but since then it has been as high as $40. So the windfall to the Government would be about $1 billion to $1.7 billion during a full 12-month period.

In 1986, petrol excise was a mere 10c a litre and, as I mentioned earlier, it is now approaching 27c a litre. These costs have all been passed on to the motorist. In my own capital city of Hobart the maximum wholesale price of petrol rose by almost 20c a litre over the three month period to October.

It is an inescapable fact that higher petrol prices add to inflation and that their contribution to a rising CPI forces workers to demand wage increases which exacerbate that spiral. The coalition has always believed that more of the fuel taxes paid by motorists should be returned to road users in the form of better roads and during the 1990 election campaign the coalition pledged to increase road funding by $1,000m. This was to be funded by directly increasing the amount of fuel excise hypothecated to roads.

Other people in our community are very concerned about this matter. I took the trouble to look at the annual address by the President of the Australian Automobile Association, Professor Peter Scott-a very distinguished Tasmanian. He talked about the price of fuel and the windfall gains it has provided for this Government. He said:

Unfortunately, the Government has since displayed a disappointing reluctance to take further action to ease the burden, steadfastly refusing to surrender the substantial windfall tax gains it stands to make from higher oil prices.
I happened to notice in that document an advertisement that was placed by the Australian Automobile Association during the last election campaign. It states:
LABOR POLICY
Over the next three years they promise to spend an extra $420 million.
COALITION POLICY
Over the next three years they promise to spend an extra $1,035 million.

We on this side of politics have got the message as to just how important roads are. When people were surveyed during the last election campaign the results showed that roads rated higher than health and environment issues. But as far as this Government is concerned the roads issue sits down at the bottom of the barrel. It has taken a series of catastrophic bus accidents to prompt this Government to take the issue of road funding seriously. Over the years it has been prepared to stand idly by and watch our road networks slowly deteriorate. For the first time motoring organisations are able to ensure that roads are placed high in the priorities of the political agendas of all major parties, as I have just demonstrated.

As previous speakers have said, we do not have a lot of time to talk about these issues, but the coalition quite willingly supports a number of areas in this Bill. In particular, we are pleased to see some increases in the funding of our transport system. However, we do have some genuine concerns about the manner in which this Bill, in its present form, allows the Minister considerable discretion. That has been pointed out by previous speakers in no uncertain terms. We believe there should be a better definition of the way in which money is allocated. As an example of this, funding for State arterials will cease at the end of the year, as Senator Macdonald said, but the category is to remain, which will enable the Minister to transfer funds on a discretionary basis from other categories to State arterials where individual States are judged to have needs in this area. There is no doubt that this situation politicises the whole area, and that is a major concern.

The Government's record on road funding is disgraceful. In summary, I repeat what I mentioned earlier: the coalition does not disagree with the broad thrust of this Bill, but we have placed before the Senate a number of very clear amendments which will reduce the power of the Minister to determine road funding purely at his own discretion and which will also ensure that any State which wishes to apply a toll on a road where there is some Federal funding should be able to do so on the basis that a proportion of that toll is returned to the Federal Government. These amendments and the other measures which will be advanced by my colleague Senator Parer will go some way towards negating the Federal Government's neglect of our land transport system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill 1990. I believe there is no doubt that road funding is becoming increasingly critical to Australia as the consequences of the Government's continual cutbacks become more and more apparent. These consequences do not show up in the short term. They occur progressively as a result of lower maintenance standards and an inability to increase the capacity of the road system to meet growing demand. Ultimately, they produce higher vehicle operating costs, less efficient industries and more road deaths and injuries, I regret to say. It is the roads which support the industries that generate the nation's wealth. Australia is a nation on wheels with a road network that is vital to all Australians. Indeed, it is the vital basis of our economy. Road funding should reflect this and it deserves our support.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill is being introduced under circumstances where funding has seriously declined. Never before has any government been so short-sighted as to continually reduce expenditure levels on road funding over a number of years. I am pleased to see that the Government has come to recognise its lack of foresight and is trying to correct this disastrous situation.

I was interested to read in the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) that transport reform in Australia would mean an increase of approximately 3 per cent in the gross domestic product. I am sure that this is very important for the greater efficiency of the economy, and anything that will improve our productivity will of course be welcomed by all Australians. I am sure that this sudden change of heart is also because the public has been demanding that something be done. It is demanding it because of the high cost of freight, the damage that is caused to vehicles, the loss of life upon the roads, and the deplorable state of our roads. Unprecedented publicity campaigns have shown the seriousness of the situation at a grassroots level. I want to quote from a number of articles about the state of the roads in rural Queensland. The first article states:
Lack of road funding is an insult to every travelling motorist. It is an insult to our intelligence to get so little back from our fuel tax for our roads.
The second article states:
It is unfair that people in the most productive areas of Australia have to put up with deteriorating roads while money for roads is lavished on Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra.
The third article states:
Australian motorists have been duped for paying high fuel taxes with only a small percentage being returned to road funding.

Cuts have had a major impact, particularly in country areas. A State-wide survey by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland found that country roads are so rough that motorists are often forced to drive on the shoulders rather than on the potholed bitumen. It found that many roads become impassable when it rains and that they are deteriorating more rapidly than city and shire councils can repair them. Declining road standards have resulted in a high cost of wear and tear on transport vehicles which is then passed on to consumers in the form of higher prices. This is highly ridiculous when one realises that much of Australia's export and financial income is created outside the cities.

As fewer road works are commenced, fewer jobs become available in road construction and maintenance. This has had a particularly detrimental effect on employment opportunities in many provincial and rural centres. I have been reading about this quite recently in our local paper in South Burnett about the number of people in the councils in South Burnett who have had to be put off because of the lack of road funding. A safe, reliable road network is of fundamental importance to our nation's economy. Poor roads serve only to isolate communities, increase fuel consumption, damage vehicles and increase the cost of goods and services.

If the Government is really serious about making industry more efficient, improving road safety and easing traffic congestion, it has no option but to increase funding. That is why it is interesting to hear for the first time the Minister acknowledging the impact of road funding on our productivity. Yet it is a fact that there have been reductions in real expenditure on road funding by Canberra in every year this Government has been in office. In real terms, the amount of money going into roads has fallen by something like 27 per cent since 1984. It is not a very pretty record.

The introduction of the Australian centennial roads development program and the Australian land transport program by the Government was a smokescreen as road funding was reduced again and again at Federal level. That is why I say that we have reached the period when, for the development of Australia, we have to look to better ways to approach our general transport system throughout the countryside. While there is no doubt some very useful things are provided for in this Bill-I support especially an increase in funding for our transport system and, in particular, our roads-the fact is that this Bill, as it is written, gives the Minister an enormous amount of discretion in the way that he spends this money.

I am concerned about whether this is the most efficient way to tackle the reform of our transport system. The Commonwealth Minister-whoever he might be-upon the advice of his department will select certain jobs to be done, certain black spots or certain national arterial roads, as we used to term them; the Minister himself will actually select the jobs. This concerns me greatly because I believe that State departments of main roads, or whatever they call themselves, are pretty efficient organisations. I worked for a main roads department for 13 or more years before I married, and I know quite a deal about it. They have their finger on the pulse as to where the bad roads are; they have a regular assessment of the needs of their particular States, whether they be for transport to port works or to industries in major towns, rural areas or the capital of the State. My concern about the legislation is whether the States will have their say.

Referring to this, the Minister for transport in the Northern Territory said that Commonwealth discretionary powers in relation to road funding should be lessened rather than strengthened. I think this is a very important approach. He also said:

It should be the Federal Minister's preserve to approve such program details as those for the black spot program. It is not appropriate that a Federal minister should place himself in the position of approving small projects to the value of around $200,000.
This is but one example of what is inhibiting Australia's progress in the 1990s.

Finally, I say to this Government that it is well past the time when it should indulge in some forward planning in the transport industry. The band-aid approach to problems as they arise is not good enough. It is not possible to speak in this debate, where the guillotine has been applied, to all the proposals mentioned in the Bill by the Government. I support the Opposition's amendments, which will help to improve the Bill as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time allotted for me to speak on the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill, I will not be able to go through all the matters that I would like to mention, and much of this has been covered by previous speakers. Therefore, I will concentrate on two issues that are of great concern to me. The first matter is the introduction, in terms of our transport system, of cross-subsidisation. I find it incredible that by implementing cross-subsidisation, this Government will keep the featherbedding which has existed in our transport industries for many years. Nobody argues about the necessity to improve our transport systems; nobody argues about the need for more funding into our rail or road systems, but the Government has adopted a position which defies all economic logic by basing its policy primarily on cross-subsidisation. For many years the rail systems in this country have paid fuel excise which has gone into general revenue or into road building. We now have a ludicrous situation where we are doing just the opposite; it is going to do nothing to address the fundamental problems which exist there.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking about the road system, the first thing one has to do is to look at the allocation in terms of the moneys that have been raised from the fuel levy. It has been outlined by other speakers that with the Hawke Government the amount going back into roads has dropped from 50 per cent to approximately 25 per cent. That in itself really tells the story of the problem that we have so far as the funding for roads is concerned. That is a particular area that should be addressed as far as funding is concerned.

If we take that a little further and examine the whole issue of road funding charges, we have to acknowledge that the transport industries, road and rail, are really the communication of industry in Australia and they are one of the most important things in terms of getting costs down to make us competitive.

To begin with, we have an enormous cross-subsidisation into general revenue from road users which militates against efficiency. Now we are going to see that being exacerbated by a cross-subsidy to the rail system. The answer in terms of the rail system is not to cross-subsidise it but to take some of the burdens it has off its back, as I mentioned, by first removing the fuel excise that rail pays. We have to look very carefully at the lack of funding that has occurred there to allow the rail system to be a modern rail system in comparison with the rest of the world.

We have got to look at the industrial encumbrances which exist in the rail system and have held it back. I am sure Senator McKiernan will agree with me that the changes that have been made in the rail system in Western Australia have created a much more efficient rail system than we had a few years ago.

We are now seeing the benefit of those changes to the Western Australian rail system where, for example, road and rail grain freight charges have dropped significantly over the last seven to 10 years. Those benefits have also been brought about by the introduction of competition between road and rail transport on the fringes and competitive charges.

This debate concerns what has been described as the war chest or the slush fund or whatever else we may call it. The Opposition is to move amendments to this legislation. I challenge the honourable senators opposite and the Australian Democrats to support these amendments, which are all about disciplining government spending and imposing some rules in that regard. In Victoria and Western Australia, for example, such discipline has not applied. Some very shameful and corrupt expenditure decisions have been made in those States.
I am absolutely amazed that the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill seeks to give one Minister discretion over the spending of $500m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—I agree with Senator Macdonald. I find that absolutely disgraceful. Such a discretion could be exercised in all sorts of ways, but the thing that concerns me most is that it is a real infringement of State rights, of the balance between States and of the total structure and efficiency in terms of where funds should be spent. This debate is a real test, particularly for the Australian Democrats. It will give them the opportunity to stand by that great principle that their founder, Don Chipp, espoused in this place when he said that the Democrats would `keep the bastards honest'.
—Can we go one day without hearing about Don Chipp?
—I will keep reminding the Democrats of it at every opportunity, as will everyone else.
—What about John Gorton?

—I get the message and I am about to conclude. This is a most shameful measure that will lead to corruption and to discrimination between States, between electorates, between shires and between cities. It is one aspect of this Bill which, unfortunately, detracts significantly from it. As I said in my opening remarks, one cannot argue against the necessity to address the inefficiencies and problems in the transport system in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak on the Australian Centennial Roads Development Bill 1990. It was about two years ago that I rose to speak on the same topic and, again, the legislation was rushed through under a guillotine. It is important to address this issue as a senator because as we travel around our own States we see the appalling state of the infrastructure of our transport system, especially in Victoria, and we see the damage that is causing. We are constantly being told by farmers and small manufacturers in rural and regional areas the problems they have and the costs that they are incurring as a result of transporting their goods and services on poor roads.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the three new programs which are included in this Bill and which were announced in the last Budget have merit, as we have come to expect with this Government's legislation they have problems-problems which I want to outline. Funding for these new projects will not necessarily be tied to fixed State shares. The Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) will determine eligible projects. The Minister has sole discretion to decide which State gets the funding and for what purpose. What a handy little pot of money that will be when we come to the next election. It amounts to some $505m of road funds available to the Minister to be used at his discretion.

The provincial cities and rural cities highways program was originally intended to be funded from the sales tax on luxury cars or $100m, whichever was greater. However, we see no mention of this in the Bill. This was obviously another election gimmick, or the Government will not make $100m on its sales tax. Funds from the provincial cities and rural cities highways program may also be used for priority improvements to maintain rail systems. There is no mention in the Bill of how much money can be allocated from the trust to the railways. Again, it is left to ministerial discretion.

The Opposition has no objection to a greater amount of funding being allocated to this area but we believe that this should be a matter for a separate piece of legislation. If we look at micro-economic reform in the area of transport we find that the Government could have gone a lot further. Only two weeks ago the Bureau of Industry Economics released a detailed account of the cost benefits accruing from micro-reform for the six years from 1989 to 1995. The Bureau said in the report that it expected rail transport to produce the biggest gains, amid overall reforms in transport. But here we have the Government committing some small amount of money to a partial reform of the rail system, instead of introducing a separate piece of legislation that could have made some significant changes to that system. The Government has again squandered the opportunity of gaining some of the$6 billion boost to gross domestic product as outlined by the Bureau.

The announcement of the road safety black spots program should be supported. But why has the Government taken so long to act? Better roads are safer roads. The Government's own Office of Road Safety has consistently outlined ways in which improvements to the road system can contribute to a reduction in road crashes. It is a pity that the Government has neglected its responsibilities in this area for so long.

The urban public transport program will increase the scope and level of assistance for urban public transport. For so long the residents of Australia's expanding outer metropolitan areas have been neglected. It did not come as a surprise to me that the Minister said that these areas have been neglected. I visit many shires throughout Victoria and I will give an example of a couple.

When I visited the Shire of Sherbrooke in the picturesque Dandenongs on the outskirts of Melbourne, I was told that the municipality had a severe lack of public transport. Census data for 1986 showed that 77 per cent of the Sherbrooke work force relied on car travel to the workplace. Many of the shire's main roads are being placed under great pressure due to the lack of alternative transport. An added problem is that a significant proportion of the main road system in the shire was constructed in the 1960s and 1970s when traffic loads and volumes were much lower than their present level.

The majority of these roads require strengthening to cater for their increased loadings. The level of concern about the standard of some of the roads has meant that these roads have been ripped up and returned to gravel, which makes them much safer than the pothole ridden roads. But this is not going to create viable and sustainable infrastructure in those developing areas. This situation is not confined to the Shire of Sherbrooke.

In the City of Werribee, which I have visited a number of times-and I am mentioning both these areas because they are the two fastest expanding local government areas in our State-an extensive transport plan has been undertaken to indicate the possible future direction when planning for the development of one of the municipality's major infrastructures, that of transport. The chief engineer and some of the councillors spent half the day driving me around some of the treacherous roads in that locality. One of the most notable things in the plan that they put forward and talked to me about on that visit was the size of the gap between the funds available to the shire and the funds required to undertake the projects identified. There is an enormous gap between the traditional sources of funding available to local government and the funds required to keep pace with the needs of a rapidly developing outer metropolitan municipality.

I believe that it is necessary to set the record straight as to the coalition's record on road funding. The Fraser Government introduced the Australian bicentennial road development program in 1982. The full effects of this program were not felt in 1982-83, since the program operated for only a little over 10 months of that year. Road funding was boosted by around $440m per year as a result of this initiative, and this represented about a 50 per cent increase in road funding. I repeat that this increase was brought about by a coalition government. All the empty rhetoric that we hear from the Government benches about the boost that the Hawke Government gave to road funding in 1984 is utter nonsense. It was the effect of the initiative of the bicentennial road funding program.

In comparison, let us look at the Hawke Government's record. The introduction of the Australian land transport program was designed to index the hypothecated amount of excise to the consumer price index. However, the legislation was twice amended to reduce the hypothecated amount of the excise. The effect was to maintain the level of road funding in money terms only. Since then there has been a massive reduction in real levels of road funding. One only has to go to those shires to see the effect of that reduction in real levels of road funding.

Under this Government money going to roads has fallen by some 27 per cent. At the same time, we find the Government collecting massive amounts of revenue from petrol excise. In fact, Victorians are repaying in petrol excise for a promise, a commitment, that the then Premier made about the viability of Pyramid Building Society. On top of this exercise that the Federal Government is putting on, we are paying for an error made by Mr Cain.

Australians are pretty used to the taxing exploits of the world's greatest recession inventor. Fuel excise as a proportion of total fuel taxes has fallen from well over 50 per cent to under 25 per cent and petrol excise has risen from about 6c per litre to nearly 25c per litre. In this Bill, the Government has failed to continue its commitment to index Australian centennial roads development (ACRD) funds to inflation. As fuel excise is automatically indexed, ACRD funds should be too. There should be a guaranteed level of funding in real terms for the next three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with every other speech I have made this week, I am under the very serious constraints of the guillotine. This Government has two blunt instruments. It bludgeons one either with a blunt guillotine or with high interest rates. They are the two instruments it uses to--
—You are not going to make a totally predictable speech, are you?

—No, I shall not; I shall make a speech which is altruistic in character and objective in nature. The Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill 1990 really summarises all the worst features of this Government. It reminds me very much of what Paul Keating, the Treasurer, said the other day. I am one of the few people who actually believes most of what he says. What he said about the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is absolutely true. What he said about the lack of leadership and the failure of this Government to inspire is absolutely true.
—Roads?

—One can look at roads. There is no vision. There is no understanding that if we had a proper road funding program-if we have capital investment rather than recurring non-capital funding-we would be at least investing our dollars for some reward. But we are not. The Budget figures show that capital funding as a percentage is declining every year under this Government. But in terms of recurrent non-capital expenditure and outlays, it is increasing. In other words, we are spending more consumer dollars and investing less in capital.

SPEECH.PARA: For a modest example one only has to look at Western Australia back in the 1960s. We had a State Government that had the vision to open up the Kimberleys of Western Australia with those magnificent beef roads. It started a whole new industry. There were roads that went into the iron ore towns. Those roads created towns, societies and industries. This Government is so myopic, so blinkered, so lacking in vision, that it does not understand the great virtues of government expenditure in capital outlays. The Government squanders taxpayers' money in line with the whim and the wish of minority groups that dictate its political direction, which changes ever so quickly.

That contrasts very sharply with the Liberal Party's commitment prior to the last election. Senator Collins will say what I say privately to some of our people- `If it was such a good promise, why didn't you win?'. Let me say this: it is one of those outstanding commitments that was perhaps buried in the rhetoric of the campaign. We made a commitment not to spend but to invest a billion dollars on Australian roads over a three-year period. That was to revitalise land transportation and to create efficiencies in the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about rail?

—I am asked about rail. If I did not have 180 seconds left I would give some details about that also. Perhaps the saddest thing about this legislation is that it shows this Government's socialist centralist mentality.
—If only they were socialist.
—Is it not interesting, Mr Acting Deputy President? I have to acknowledge Senator Vallentine's interjection because it is the second time I have--
—Well you cannot; she did not interject from her chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order on Senator Vallentine's behaviour. It is the second occasion in recent weeks that the honourable senator has chosen to interject whilst walking through the chamber. It really is very unparliamentary behaviour. On the previous occasion she was spoken to. I take the point of order in order to record the incident and not in any way to eat into Senator Crichton-Browne's time.
—There was nothing I could do about it as the honourable senator was out the door.
—It is the second time and it makes me wonder whether the Standing Committee on Procedures ought not look at provisions to have the Black Rod bring back these--
—It has been done. I was in the chamber at the time.

—Yes, I remember. These wayward delinquent senators that storm out of the Parliament because they are exhausted of intellect and unable to make a contribution except babble as they storm through the door should be brought back. My comment was that this is a centralist socialist government. Senator Vallentine's reply was, `If only they were'. It is a great pity that the voters of Western Australia do not know more about Senator Vallentine. However, that is a matter for another time.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation provides a great deal of not only discretion for the Federal Minister but also a measure of blackmail wherein funding is provided under certain circumstances, as if to say that the States and the local governments do not have the intellectual capacity, the competence or the intrinsic natural understanding of what is wanted of them by their own constituents; as if they do not understand what is best for the people in their State or in their shire. That perhaps is the best example of why this Government is really so rudderless and lacking in leadership, understanding and sensitivity as to what the Australian people want and expect of it.

In the second I have left, I conclude by noting that the Australian Labor Party has reduced road funding by over 30 per cent in real terms since it came to office. Yet, as I think Senator Patterson said, the revenue from excise has risen dramatically. It has gone into the Government's coffers to be distributed under general revenue in a totally non-accountable way.

TALK.START.PARA: —While our infrastructure goes down.

—As I said earlier, that infrastructure is dropping dramatically. Of course, we are seeing the effects of that. Some excellent work has been done which demonstrates the number of lives that can be saved in respect of the number of dollars required to be invested in roads. Yet this Government totally ignores that. This legislation is but another nail in the coffin of this Government, which will inexorably be driven out of office at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — In rising to speak to the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill 1990, I wish to confine my remarks to the amendment which I have circulated about one particular aspect of the Bill. The Bill seeks to switch $250m from the construction of a freeway, which funds I understand have been earmarked, to the construction of a railway through the Koonung and Mullum Mullum valleys instead. In doing so, I need to advert briefly to what Senator Macdonald has said. As usual, he was rather strong on abuse and weak on facts. He tried to imply that the amendment was designed to take money away from Queensland. In fact, it does nothing of the sort. It simply seeks to switch funds from one purpose to another, funds which have been earmarked for the State of Victoria for a given area.

SPEECH.PARA: I am speaking tonight for three organisations: the Public Transport Users Association, the Koonung Mullum Forestway Association and the Conservation Council of Victoria. They are merely the spearheads for about half a million people across the south-eastern corridor of metropolitan and suburban Melbourne, half a million people who are concerned to retain within their neighbourhood the last bit of original wilderness instead of having it buried under hundreds of tonnes of concrete. It has been demonstrated in numerous reports that there are at least 150 varieties of birds and over 100 varieties of shrubs and trees in that area. That is what people are concerned about.

There is also the fact that we are contrasting public transport with road transport, with all its attendant congestion, ill effects on health, the greenhouse effect, et cetera. I know that people on the Opposition side do not care about those matters. In answer to some earlier comments, I wish to say that when Don Chipp admonished us to keep the bastards honest, he meant the bastards on both sides of the chamber. Judging by recent performances, it will take a lot more for us to keep those on the opposition side honest than those on the other side. We shall be impartial on that, and we shall do our best for both sides.

In foreshadowing that I would move my amendment, I was pleased to get support from Mr Spyker, the Transport Minister in Victoria who thought it was a good move to put it on the table for the Federal Government to consider. I was also pleased to hear from the Federal Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) that he was prepared to consider that issue. I know that the amendment will be rejected but, if nothing else, it has put the issue on the table for further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will be very brief indeed in concluding the second reading debate. I simply want to take up one issue and one issue only as the substantive matters raised by the Opposition in the debate are covered by an Opposition amendment. I will deal with those matters during the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a consistent claim made throughout the entire debate by successive Opposition speakers, including the last speaker for the Opposition, Senator Crichton-Browne, that Government funding has fallen in real terms by 30 per cent since this Government came to power. The facts are that the 1990-91 allocation for funding is 10 per cent higher in real terms than in 1982-83; it is 20 per cent higher than any other year of the previous coalition Government; and the average of current Government annual expenditure on roads is about 25 per cent higher in real terms than that of the previous coalition Government. In conclusion, I simply thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate.

I have canvassed the reasons for this amendment in the second reading debate. I know that we are constrained by time. Very briefly, this amendment fixes each State's share of funding along the lines suggested in Minister Beazley's second reading speech. It gives effect to commitments made by the Federal Government prior to and during the last election to introduce three new land transport funding programs, but it goes further by spelling out a formula for distribution of that funding.

This amendment will ensure that the additional amounts paid into the funds are applied to the program for which they were intended. Whilst permitting a degree of flexibility, it removes the Federal Mini- ster's absolute power to move funds between various land transport programs. If the Government is honest, it will agree to this amendment. It is totally in accordance with the spirit of the legislation and is moved by the Opposition because we believe that the Government is very likely in the lead-up to an election to target the funding in an inequitable fashion to help its mates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, the claim is nonsense. That has been demonstrated by the record of this Government over the last two years. I might add that there is no point in repeating the same argument in respect of most of the other amendments that will be moved because they are all directed to the same end. These points were made at length during the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the concept of this type of funding is not new. It was successfully employed with the national arterial roads category when the legislation was first introduced. The arguments are not new either. The Hansard will reveal that the Opposition raised the same pork-barrelling charges against the legislation to which the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill is an adjunct when it was first introduced two years ago.

The fact is-and the State Ministers and Premiers know it-that that has not been the reality of the way in which this program has been administered. What is being directed by these proposals is a far more efficient and rational national system of transportation. There is a growing acceptance-thank goodness-by State leaders across the board, Labor and non-Labor, that this is the way to go. There are very tight guidelines attached to administering these programs. The programs are-again, thank goodness-being developed on a three-year basis by agreement and negotiation with the States. That is a very rational way of doing it, rather than handing out fixed shares allocated by legislation from year to year. It is precisely the way good government should be going. For that reason we oppose this amendment and indicate at this stage of the debate that we will be opposing the other Opposition amendments on the same grounds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate that the Australian Democrats will be opposing this amendment. We see one problem with it. Although it is designed to prevent the transfer of funds across programs, we believe that it would also prevent the augmentation of projects from other areas. I concur with the response of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) in that it is highly desirable for Australia to come to grips at last with the need for a national, integrated, co- operative land transport plan for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Liberal Party and National Party will be opposing the Australian Democrats' amendment. It appears from the amendment and from the Australian Centennial Roads Development Amendment Bill that the Australian Labor Party wants the Federal Government to run everything and that the Liberal and the National parties want the administration to go back to the State governments. Senator Vallentine, who just gave a disgustingly discourteous display as she left the chamber, along with Bob Brown will get their people to join the Democrats-there are about 100 throughout Australia-and they will flood the Democrats and take them over. The Democrats are going to be run by Vallentine and Brown. Senator Vallentine is trying to divert the debate by getting a bit of green credibility.
