SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on the adjournment tonight. I rise on the most fundamental of principles, and that is to defend a friend who has been maligned unfairly. I refer to recent events in the Parliament of New South Wales in Macquarie Street and specifically to allegations made by the New South Wales National Party to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC).

SPEECH.PARA: These allegations concern Mr Barry Toomey, QC, who is an outstanding lawyer and is recognised as such at the Sydney Bar and, indeed, nationally. He is a great contributor to the legal profession. He is an individual of integrity and honour. For his pains, he also happens to be my senior counsel. He has successfully represented me on a number of occasions and I believe he will again in some matters pending. Mr Toomey also happens to be my friend, which causes me to rise tonight.

There are a series of realities that apparently have caused some concerns within the New South Wales National Party. These concerns have boiled over into some outrageous allegations that Mr Toomey, in his capacity as counsel assisting the ICAC on the North Coast land deals, was unprincipled and biased. I have been critical of the ICAC and its methods on civil liberties grounds and where I believe those concerns are justified I will continue to express them, but no criticism ought to have been levelled at Mr Toomey. In my view, and I think in the view of all those who have observed, Mr Toomey, during the inquiry, behaved with absolute propriety. He certainly acted consistently with the principles laid down by the New South Wales Bar Association.

The New South Wales National Party really has a problem with the outcome of the inquiry. It did emerge stained from it and the inquiry report was politically negative. There were some severe electoral consequences. There is no excuse for this outrageous personal attack made by the Chairman of the New South Wales National Party, Mr Doug Moppett, under the privilege of the New South Wales Parliament. This attack was made without checking any of the facts, made without courtesy and made without regard to accuracy. Certainly as a consequence, it was made without having regard to reputation. Mr Toomey has replied to this attack in a letter to the Sydney Morning Herald and I seek leave to incorporate that letter into Hansard tonight.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
12th December, 1990
The Editor,
Sydney Morning Herald
Dear Sir,

In the SMH of 12.12.90 you reported that the chairman of the NSW National Party, Mr Doug Moppett, had claimed ``there was a view that the counsel assisting the ICAC during the [North Coast] hearings, Mr Barry Toomey, Q.C., was biased because he was a member of the Society of Labor Lawyers.''

In his written submission on behalf of the National Party to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ICAC, Mr Moppett used the words ``there have even been suggestions that Mr Toomey is or was at one time a member of the Society of Labor Lawyers . . . .''
In the manner of his kind he did not, of course, name those who had pointed the dagger at my professional integrity.
The facts are that I am not and never have been a member of the Society of Labor Lawyers; nor have I ever been a member of any political party.

Further, I have been a vocal and public critic of the existence of such a body as the Society of Labor Lawyers because I believe it is impossible to reconcile the stringent ethical rules which govern practice at the Bar with the partiality and subjective standards necessarily involved in public support of a political party.

Indeed Mr Moppett's behaviour provides an object lesson in the way that truth is subverted for political ends. Because the National Party suffered, in his perception, at the hands of ICAC he is anxious to advance reasons why ICAC should be discredited. In a democratic society he is free to do so-the pity is that he chooses to use, under Parliamentary privilege, the methods of those who despise democracy.

The attack on me which you reported was not the only one directed at me by Mr Moppett. However the other attack was based not only on misstatement of fact but on obvious ignorance of the rules of the NSW Bar Association.

Perhaps the most piquant feature of Mr Moppett's behaviour is that the attack was made without any attempt to check the facts with me. It would have been inconvenient, of course, for Mr Moppett to have been made aware that he was promulgating lies-that is, until after he had done so.
Yours faithfully,
Barry Toomey

TALK.START.PARA: —In that letter Mr Toomey rebutted claims point by point. The most absurd allegation levelled at Mr Toomey was that he was a member of the Society for Labor Lawyers. Not only was Mr Toomey not a member of the Society; he has in fact been a critic of that body. In his view, politics ought not to intrude upon professional responsibilities. He has acted consistent with the strictures of the Bar Association. Mr Toomey is certainly entitled to his politics but he has kept them quite separate from his professionalism.

SPEECH.PARA: During the inquiry, I think it is fair to say that he was professional and fair. He stood down from the inquiry where there could be a suggestion of a conflict of interest, but he did his job and that was perhaps uncomfortable for some. He demonstrated beyond doubt during the course of the inquiry that there had been questionable conduct by certain Ministers in the New South Wales Government.

The absurdity of the claims is best illustrated by simple anecdote. My lawyers, McClellands, in Sydney were approached by the Secretary of the New South Wales National Party, Ms Jenny Gardiner, for a copy of the judgment in which I was exonerated on the Harris-Daishowa matter. I was represented in that matter successfully by Mr Toomey. As a courtesy and an act of decency we gave that judgment to Ms Gardiner. The response has been, frankly, indecent. Increasingly, every elector in New South Wales has come to realise that. I agree with His Honour Mr Justice Adrian Roden's comments, which are eloquent and appropriate, on some of the remarks made by the Nationals over the past week or so. If there is any respect due an organisation, perhaps an apology would be called for. It is not appropriate in this circumstance. No respect may be afforded the organisation concerned.
I conclude by saying that Barry Toomey is a fine Australian and his detractors should be judged for the malice and hypocrisy with which they have acted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I raise tonight is of considerable importance to public life in Western Australia and to our good name abroad. I refer to the continuation in office of Mr Brian Burke as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See and the propriety of his original appointment. It is also a concern that members of the Hawke Labor Government have shown far greater determination to safeguard the reputation of their Party than that of Australian public affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I make it clear that I am not making allegations of criminal behaviour. I agree that guilt in these matters should, if necessary, be determined in the courts. That is not the core of the problem. The issue at stake is one of propriety. The media have reported clear factual evidence, not mere allegations as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) keeps stating in his refusal to answer questions, that Brian Burke, as Premier of Western Australia, was a key player in a campaign of dirty tricks against political opponents and in the deception, which is slowly unravelling, of WA Inc-that adventure of which he is the clear, undisputed political patron.

I am stating firmly that the weight of evidence is such that a responsible government would review the suitability of such a person holding a diplomatic post. It is also fair to ask why such action has not been taken, given the knowledge of Ministers about the dirty tricks campaign and the duty of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to seek assurances from an ambassadorial appointee about his reputation and actions in public life. It has become a practice of the Hawke Labor Government not to follow the convention of standing people aside when a cloud hangs over their heads or for Ministers to resign when motions of censure have been carried by the Parliament. Accountability is not a word readily understood by this Government.

This is not a matter of the coalition criticising a diplomat because he is a former senior Labor figure. Former members of Federal Parliament have held and are holding diplomatic posts. While we might on some occasions have queried whether they were the best person for the job, we do not criticise them for doing a job as an Australian representative.

I am talking about a person-namely, Brian Burke-who has actually been identified by name in diaries seized by the Australian Federal Police (AFP). This is not innuendo; this is fact. Mr Burke did not simply take an overseas appointment prior to retiring. Aged 40 when he stood down as Premier, it was reported as recently as 2 November this year that`Labor sources' in Western Australia had reaffirmed that he still plans to make a bid for Federal politics. The Prime Minister may be non-committal today about the prospect, but the 1988 appointment of Mr Burke to Dublin can be seen as an advancement of this exact goal. After all, it was the Prime Minister-Mr Robert James Lee Hawke-who insisted that his friend Brian be given the job in the first place.

On 8 November Senator Tate, in ans- wer to my earlier questions, stated that he had been briefed no fewer than six times by the Australian Federal Police about the contents of the blue file marked `Govt', which was seized on 6 December 1988 from private investigator Robert Smith, who was subsequently tried and convicted of phone-tapping-not once, but twice. If those six briefings occurred `during 1988', the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) would have received concentrated information about the content of this material over a maximum period of the 25 days remaining in 1988-or was it in the six days before the Australian Federal Police charged Mr Smith? What could have been so devastating that the Minister had to be briefed six times in such a short period? It is also relevant to ask, given that Senator Tate as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs was given this information, what was known by the then Federal Attorney-General, Mr Bowen. Was he informed of the contents of the file? It would be surprising if he had not been informed.

Surely Senator Evans as Foreign Minister should have been informed of evidence that implicated an ambassador in past surveillance of political opponents. From his reactions in the Senate over recent weeks, he certainly gives the impression that he knows far more than he is prepared to say and he has not sought to deny that he knows much more. It does not mean very much for the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to state that there was no reference to an actual breach of Federal legislation. I repeat: a person need not have been guilty of criminal conduct to have so debased his office of Premier as to be unfit to represent Australia overseas. It does not say very much for the concern of this Government for honest and open government generally that, when the Minister knew that the file had been passed on to the Commissioner of Police in Western Australia, he presumably never followed up the matter to find out why no action was taken. He would say that action had been taken with regard to breaches of Federal legislation, and that is true. However, are we to believe that absolutely no mention was made to him during his six briefings over a matter of days that the file contained politically explosive mat- erial detrimental to the State Labor Government?

Senator Tate has refused to answer my question about why all the documents seized by the Australian Federal Police in the raid on Mr Smith were not on the property seizure record. Probably what is worse is that Senator Tate also refused to obtain an answer. Why? Are we therefore to presume that it is now to become standard procedure for the AFP or is the Minister willing to give the Senate an answer in an effort to uphold the good name and reputation of the AFP? Successive Premiers and an array of Labor politicians have, until recently when the pressure became too great, refused pointblank to hold a royal commission into these and other allegations surrounding Mr Burke and WA Inc. Never mind the damage to the political and corporate reputation of Western Australia: just cover up Labor dirty tricks and linen at all costs.

The evidence which has arisen since the conviction of Robert Smith is damning. During 1987, the last year of Brian Burke's premiership, diaries show that Mr Burke, his brother Terry-a former Cabinet Secretary-and Brian Burke's driver and personal assistant, Vince Shervington, were actively involved in a campaign of surveillance of political opponents. The same Premier who on 15 March 1987 wrongly accused the State Leader of the Opposition of keeping him under surveillance was later that same month, according to the Smith diaries-I repeat: this is not innuendo; it is fact-to order an investigation of the business dealings of Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly Ross Lightfoot. Such was the punishment to be meted out to those daring to unmask WA Inc.

It says something for the integrity of those so investigated that Mr Burke was unable to do more than make generalised and unfounded allegations in Parliament about `bottom of the harbour' scams. This is the guy who will sue anyone if there is a buck in it. Indeed, all efforts to smear Mr Lightfoot came unstuck when it was revealed in the Smith diary on 9 April 1987 that `NO JOY' had been found in respect of the investigations of Ross Lightfoot. It is equally apparent that the operation was a determined exercise to attempt to destroy the reputations of Mr Lightfoot and the former Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Ian Laurence. Smith was even asked to check on all known associates of the two gentlemen in question in a vain attempt to besmirch their names. The sleazy, clandestine nature of the `BB' investigations is made obvious by the fact that this work was paid for independently of the $133,600 that Smith formally received under his supposed security contract with the Department of the Premier and Cabinet from March 1987 to December 1988. The coincidence of dates for both operations should not go unnoticed.

Western Australians would like to know-and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade should make it his business to find out-exactly who paid Robert Smith for his dirty tricks spying at $45 per hour for sometimes as long as 15 hours a day. One may well ask how Smith had the time to do the tasks for which he was officially being paid. The money trail on 26 May 1987 points to Darcy Farrell, who just happened to be Mr Burke's media consultant. Another coincidence? Not likely.

The diaries reveal that on 22 May Smith met with an employee of the accounting firm which was the official auditor of the Western Australian Liberal Party and paid a person $400 for confidential information. Who paid for that? Surely it was not Smith personally. The diary entry for 27 May indicates that this stolen information was passed to Vince Shervington, Mr Burke's driver and personal assistant. One can only assume that it was not just paper to light his barbecue and, as he worked for Mr Burke, the connection could be deemed to be obvious.

Political opponents were not the only object of surveillance. Police officers involved in the inquiry into Len Brush, who happened to be superannuation board chairman, husband of Mr Burke's private secretary and longstanding ally of Mr Burke, were subject to investigation by Smith. One detective, Colin Pace, was among several policemen whose promotions were held up in July 1987.

I remind the Senate that the real reason why Richard Nixon was driven from office was not that some underlings committed a burglary but that Watergate revealed an ugly, cheap vindictiveness against political opponents that weakens democracy. It is reasonable to suggest that, when such evidence points at a serving ambassador, his continuation should be seriously questioned and should have been investigated by this Labor Government long before today.

Just as Ministers cannot disregard the catalogue of dirty tricks, of which I have only given a brief outline, neither can they dismiss as mere allegations the role of Mr Burke in concealing the affairs of Rothwells from scrutiny in the closing months of his premiership. The existing evidence from the McCusker inquiry points to at least five questions that should be asked of Mr Burke to determine his fitness to serve Australia.

With the appointment of senior public servants and long time mates, Tony Lloyd and Kevin Edwards, to the board of Rothwells, was Mr Burke indeed a de facto director of that same shady concern for his last three months as Premier? We do not know and the question remains unanswered. Was the memorandum of13 November 1987 by the Director of Rothwells, David Hurley, stating that a $150m National Australia Bank guarantee was almost exhausted and that therefore Rothwells was again insolvent, conveyed to Mr Burke? We do not know, but the question needs to be answered.

Did Mr Burke, as stated, take to Cabinet the share deal of 16 November 1987, whereby the purchase of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd shares by the State Government Insurance Corporation injected another $50m into Rothwells? We do not know, but the question needs to be ans- wered. Why did Mr Burke supply a character reference to the new Chairman of Rothwells, a close associate of Laurie Connell named Bill Burgess? Was it part of an exercise to allay any suspicions of the National Companies and Security Commission as to the $500m worth of non-performing loans in Rothwells? We do not know, but the questions need to be answered. Also in mid-December 1987, Mr Burke induced David Hurley not to resign as the one director of Rothwells with banking credibility with the offer of an eventual senior position in a government instrumentality to `protect his career path'. These questions are not vague scuttlebutt. They have been posed in black and white in the McCusker inquiry report. They lead us back to many of the central questions that I am posing in the Senate tonight.

One of the other questions of possible impropriety by Mr Burke is his involvement in or awareness of the payment of a bribe to Stirling City councillors to allow a beach front development to proceed. It is almost inconceivable to believe, even if one wished to, that, as it was Mr Burke's brother, Terry, who taped a conversation with another person about the bribe, Mr Brian Burke was not subsequently informed.

One current Labor member of the House of Representatives has said that he was aware of the bribe and had at the time considered that it was his public duty to pass on the information. However, he decided to remain quiet. Who was this member of parliament? Was it the local member who nearly lost his preselection in the same year? Why did he not exercise his public duty? Was pressure put on him by Mr Burke and Mr Burke's brother to stay silent or else?

Apart from all the close advisers, friends or relatives associated with Mr Burke whom I have already mentioned, it has also been revealed that another former Burke adviser and lifelong friend, the late Mr Jack Walsh, was involved in the bribery affair. Is one expected to think that he too did not advise his lifelong friend, Mr Burke, of what was going on?

Mr Burke was obviously very sensitive to what people knew long before he was dispatched to Ireland. While he has a reputation of slapping a writ on anything that moves, he was keen to suppress a petition circulated by a Western Australian citizen in 1988 which simply sought to have any allegations against Mr Burke cleared prior to his going to Ireland. Mr Burke issued the gentleman with a defamation writ and, in typical style, bullied him out of continuing to obtain signatures. Now, over two years later, the whole jigsaw is being pieced together.

The stonewalling by this Government, and Minister Tate and in particular, is a disgrace of enormous proportions. Mr Burke was sent to Ireland by this Government for the benefit of the Labor Party and, for the same reason, Ministers of this Government are stonewalling as to why he should not give an account as to the propriety of his behaviour as an elected official prior to his appointment.

Many questions that have been raised in the Senate over many weeks as of tonight remain unanswered. Unless the evidence that I have tried to summarise here can be refuted, such a person as Mr Burke is not fit to represent Australia in Ireland or anywhere else for that matter. How long can this Government and its Ministers go on defending a situation that clearly in the national interest should be settled once and for all one way or the other?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the adjournment this evening because of a number of comparisons that Senator Cook has made between the economic results of the Thatcher Government and the Hawke Government. I prefix my remarks by concurring with the observations made by many eminent observers that Mrs Thatcher was probably the greatest peacetime Prime Minister of England this century. She gave her country and indeed the Western world strong and purposeful leadership. There are far more lessons to emulate than examples to avoid in the Thatcher years.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook has argued that the Hawke model is far superior to the model developed by Margaret Thatcher and has suggested that there are striking similarities between what the Opposition is proposing and the policies of the Thatcher Government. In support of his observations, he quoted a number of statistics in answer to a dorothy dixer from Senator Childs last Thursday.

Senator Ray reminded us in this chamber recently that we should be very cautious about the use of statistics. He said, `There are lies, damn lies and statistics'. He did not actually quite say that; in fact, he got the quotation wrong, but that is what he meant to say. Perhaps his staff could ensure that the weekly Hansard is corrected.

Comparative statistics between countries are affected by a vast range of local and international factors which suggest that caution is the best policy in discussing comparative statistics between countries. Senator Cook in his answers in comparing the Thatcher years and the Hawke years shows no such caution. He sustained his case by arguing that growth in the Australian economy under Mr Hawke was faster than that in the United Kingdom (UK) under Thatcher in relation to gross domestic product, employment and exports.

Certainly using these statistics alone without qualification or context Senator Cook appears to have a point, but when we put the statistics into the context of the world economy the picture becomes somewhat different. Two years after the advent of the Thatcher Government there was a world recession from 1981 to 1982. This had the effect of depressing growth rates, and certainly that of the British economy.

Another way of measuring the relative performances of the two economies is to look at how key aggregates performed from the advent of the Hawke Government-that is, from 1983 onwards. This at least ensures that we are measuring key statistics over the same international economic environment. When we look at this period we find that the growth rates of the Australian and UK economies are, in fact, very similar. If anything, the UK economy grew faster from 1983 at 3.2 per cent per annum compared with 3 per cent per annum in Australia. Inflation in the UK over this period averaged 4.8 per cent compared with Australia's 7.5 per cent.

As Senator Ray might say to Senator Cook, reflecting on the selective statistics that Senator Cook gave to the Senate, there are lies, damned lies and statistics. Given the Labor Party's oft-stated concern for the conditions of working men and women-an appropriate concern which is shared by all parties, I trust-it was surprising that Senator Childs did not ask Senator Cook in the dorothy dixer last Thursday what happened to wages and salaries under the Thatcher Government. Even granting this oversight, why did Senator Cook not use statistics on incomes to demonstrate the alleged superiority of Labor's much vaunted accord? After all, as Senator Cook tells the Opposition, the Opposition has-and I quote:

. . . created in their industrial relations meanderings a bastard child of industrial relations, ill-conceived, unformed, impractical, without precedent and, more importantly, dangerous if the Thatcher model is something close to what they seek.

We shall see. I will try to fill in this oversight by Senator Cook. What happened to the incomes of British workers under Margaret Thatcher? Were incomes ground down, as Senator Cook seems to imply? Real wages under Margaret Thatcher actually increased very substantially over the 10 years of her stewardship. In fact, they rose by an impressive 2.6 per cent per annum in real terms. We might ask how real wages have progressed under the Hawke Government, which in recent times has had Senator Cook as its Minister for Industrial Relations.

In an adjournment speech last week, I outlined in some detail the disgraceful record of the accord in protecting the incomes of Australian workers. Senator Cook, hardly surprisingly, has chosen not to debate these figures, despite Senator Ray's riposte that evening that a devastating reply would be forthcoming from Senator Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —A devastating silence.

—A devastating silence, as Senator O'Chee has said. Real wages under the accord-which was developed by the Hawke Government-have actually declined, not risen, as has happened under the Thatcher model, which has been so savagely attacked by Senator Cook.

SPEECH.PARA: The Thatcher record becomes even better if we compare growth in real wages from 1983-the time when the Hawke Government assumed office. In this case, Mrs Thatcher delivered average growth in wages of 3.1 per cent annually. The question we should ask ourselves is this: did Senator Cook omit these figures through oversight, or did he deliberately hide these statistics because he knew the comparisons would damn his accord? I leave it to honourable senators to judge. We might ask who has the best record in delivering real increases in living standards to working men and women. If these statistics provide the guide, the answer must be Mrs Thatcher, not Mr Hawke. So Senator Cook's accord fails on the critical test of living standards.

It is worth recalling that Mrs Thatcher did not have to adopt the very high interest rate policies which have marked the Hawke era and so damaged the effective disposable incomes of workers. While the Hawke Government was making it difficult for young people to buy homes through record mortgage rates, Mrs Thatcher's Government was encouraging working men and women to own homes through selling local authority housing.

Senator Cook has spent some time lecturing the Senate on how Mrs Thatcher allegedly created havoc in British industrial relations. We again ask: what do the comparative statistics show? In 1989, the last year for which comparative statistics are available, which government was more successful in delivering industrial peace-the Hawke Government or the Thatcher Government? Those of us who have been in this chamber in the last three weeks would have assumed as a result of Senator Cook's efforts that the Hawke Government was more successful. What do the statistics show? It was fortunate that Senator Cook did not compare strike rate statistics in the latest year. In 1989, under Senator Cook's accord, Australia lost 190 working days per thousand employees. Mrs Thatcher's Government recorded a loss of 180 working days per thousand employees-a better record than that of Senator Cook and his accord.

It is true that industrial disputes in the United Kingdom over the period of the Thatcher Government, measured in terms of working days lost, are higher than in Australia under the Hawke Government. Certainly, there was the enormously difficult period of the miners strike which enabled Mrs Thatcher to transform industrial relations in the UK and break union privileges. It is important to make the point that in five of the last seven years the Thatcher Government has had a lower strike rate than that which was achieved by Senator Cook's precious accord. As we know, the Thatcher Government achieved this excellent record in comparison with Australia by not doing what Senator Cook and his colleagues have done, in agreeing to every demand of Bill Kelty and the Australian Council of Trade Unions bosses and giving trade unions a privileged position in Australian society. In contrast to Senator Cook, Mrs Thatcher believes that trade unions should not have a privileged position in our society. Her success in restoring the union movement to its proper role is certainly one of her great achievements.

Further, if Mrs Thatcher beats Senator Cook-and it is hardly a competitive race, let us face it-in the vital area of delivering real increases in living standards to workers, and generally having a better industrial relations record in five of the last seven years, how did Mrs Thatcher and her Government rate in the area of unemployment statistics? The latest figures show that unemployment in the United Kingdom is about 6 per cent. In Australia, the figure is 8.2 per cent and rising. Over the term of the Thatcher Government, unemployment was somewhat higher than over the term of the Hawke Government, but how high the overall average of the Hawke Government will go is not known. We know that Hawke, Keating, Cook and company have engineered--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp, when you are referring to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, you should address them by their correct titles.

—We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) have engineered a recession; no one argues with that. I note that Senator Cook has never denied that this recession, which is creating large scale unemployment, has been deliberately engineered by his Government. Of course, he cannot deny it. But the Government will not tell us how high unemployment is planned to go in the engineered recession that we had to have, according to Paul Keating. The jury is still out on the unemployment record of the Hawke Government.
—It will go higher.

—But it will go higher, as Senator O'Chee says. Senator Cook omitted one other vital statistic from his comparative treatment of the Thatcher and Hawke years. That statistic is productivity. With the Prime Minister's boasting about his unparalleled record in micro reform, why did Senator Cook not tell us how productivity had grown in the Australian economy in contrast with the Thatcher years? After all, if we are considering the capacity of an economy to deliver rising living standards, productivity is arguably a vital statistic, is it not?

SPEECH.PARA: The reason Senator Cook did not talk about productivity is that the Thatcher Government, according to the latest Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) statistics, was able to achieve a productivity growth in the British economy of around 1.8 per cent per annum during the 1980s. What did Senator Cook do? What magnificent effect on Australian industry did all that restructuring and micro-reform carried out by the Hawke Government have on productivity? What was the bottom line? The answer, according to the OECD, was an annual growth of 0.5 per cent, one of the worst among OECD countries. No wonder Senator Cook did not enlighten Senator Childs about the productivity comparisons between the Hawke and Thatcher governments.

I do not pretend that there are no serious problems in the British economy. Of course there are. Inflation is far too high and there are balance of payments problems-although, it has to be said, they are not as serious as Australia's balance of payments crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on, what about the three million unemployed?

—Senator Collins asks, `What about unemployment?'. If he had been listening, I said that the unemployment rate in the United Kingdom is 6 per cent. The unemployment rate under the Hawke Government is 8.2 per cent. If one asked the average Australian worker which country he would prefer to be in, where his job prospects lay, I suggest that the Thatcher Government would come out ahead.
—Ask the average Pom where he would rather be and he will tell you Australia.

—The Minister should ask them, and he should ask them as the unemployment queues continue to lengthen because of the engineered recession, which the Minister was undoubtedly part of bringing about. I know he is sensitive about it, and so he should be. The Hawke Government is the only government in Australian history which has engineered a recession and felt good enough to boast about it. Mrs Thatcher, whom members of the Government always bag, never went around boasting as a badge of honour about causing a recession. The Minister is a disgrace and his Government is a disgrace.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to take note of his language. I ask him to withdraw the statement that he made to the Minister.
—What statement was that?

SPEECH.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT You called him a disgrace. That is unparliamentary language. Will you withdraw?

TALK.START.PARA: —If it was applied to the Minister I will certainly withdraw it. Nevertheless, on measures which should be of concern to Labor-living standards, productivity and unemployment-could we say that, in comparison to the Hawke Government, Mrs Thatcher has `brought home the bacon', to use a Keatingism? I think we can.
—If she is so wonderful, why is she not still there?

—Just wait. That will also be answered. I am saying that the ridiculously simplistic and selective view that Senator Cook gives us of the Thatcher years-and undoubtedly gives his colleagues such as Senator Collins, who knows nothing about proper comparisons--
—Nobody is listening out there.

—Senator Collins is listening because he is getting very sensitive about it. He is certainly listening; there is no question about that. Senator Cook's simplistic view does not make any contribution to understanding complex phenomena and is not a credit to the Minister. It is clear that the Thatcher experience in the UK has in some areas had an influence on the Hawke Government-and a beneficial influence. Let it not be denied. Senator Collins can tell us whether the Hawke Government would have been prepared to adopt privatisation policies, in total contradiction of its own platform and election promises, had it not been for the manifest success of most privatisations in the UK and a strong support for privatisations from the coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook and Senator Collins should at least give some credit to Margaret Thatcher for influencing the Australian Labor Party (ALP) to adopt privatisation as a policy. I do not recall that privatisation occurred in any ALP election manifesto; I do recall that it was Mrs Thatcher who showed the benefits of privatisation. Senator Collins may like to answer why the Hawke Government adopted the rhetoric of smaller government and deregulation. I say `rhetoric' because in many areas the Hawke Government has simply failed to deliver. Certainly it borrowed the smaller government and deregulation policy approach from the Liberal Party. The success of the Thatcher Government also had an influence on the rhetoric of Hawke Ministers.

In another area of experience, the Thatcher years had an unfavourable influence on the Hawke Government. In both countries-Australia and the UK-the money supply expanded at far too great a rate during the 1980s. A consequence of this policy has been massive inflation of asset prices, debt and ultimately deflation. That was an unfavourable influence of the Thatcher Government on the Hawke Government. The Economist, the well-known British weekly, in a not uncritical editorial said of Mrs Thatcher:

Where five generations of political leaders had watched Britain's economic decline, she was ready to say no, enough-and do something about it. These were massive achievements and they will give her a stature that time will not erode.

Will any newspaper write similar lines about Senator Collins, Mr Hawke or Mr Keating? Certainly the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has let us know in no uncertain terms what he thinks of the Prime Minister's stature. We go back to his now notorious off the record briefing of the press. It is clear that the Hawke Government has failed to pick up some of the positive aspects of the Thatcher years.

Let me mention just one final aspect. No-one would argue that Mrs Thatcher did not have a clear set of philosophical beliefs which were endorsed by her Party. No-one would argue that she did not provide strong consistent leadership or deny that she attempted to put her philosophy into practical policies. There were no U-turns with Mrs Thatcher. There were no special conferences to revise party philosophy and platform. No-one ever called Mrs Thatcher a jellyback, from what I can recall, let alone one of her own Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is too busy listening to his radio. You should repeat it.

—He is listening. Finally-and this is the point I asked Senator Collins to wait for, and he may care to give even an impression of listening to this-when Mrs Thatcher judged that the time had come for her to bow out of public life there would be no-one who would not argue that she made a dignified exit. Senator Cook, Senator Collins and their colleagues may find it of value to reflect on that lesson of the Thatcher years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic for my adjournment speech this evening is the crisis in the Gulf. Now we have a breathing space before the 15 January deadline and a chance to initiate a negotiation process to avoid war, it seems useful to consider what possibilities exist for an agreement that would be acceptable to all parties concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would first like to refute the allegation by Senator Richardson on 4 December that I represent the views of only a few people in Australia. According to the latest Saulwick poll in the Sydney Morning Herald-and taking into account the correction that appeared tucked away on page 2 the day after the original headline, which claimed that 80 per cent of Australians support sending warships to the Gulf to remove the Iraqis by force-the reality is that 56 per cent of Australians are in favour of force being used in the Gulf and Australia being involved in that force, divided between 68 per cent of men and 43 per cent of women. In fact, the Australian Democrats and I, from the Greens WA, represent the 41 per cent of the population that is definitely opposed to the Australian involvement in the Gulf, and that number will probably grow.

So it is far from only a few; it is a significant and growing number of the Australian population. Curiously, far more Americans are opposed to the use of military force in the Gulf, indicating that Australians still tend to be gung ho before a military adventure and then rapidly swing away once the body bags start coming home from some foreign field where Australia has been fighting another nation's war yet again.

However we may interpret United Nations resolution 678, it is erroneous to assume that there is ample legal justification in the United Nations (UN) charter for unilateral military action by the United States. White House officials, apparently supported by the Australian Government, take the position that article 51 of the United Nations charter, which affirms the right of individual and collective self-defence, allows the United States to liberate Kuwait by armed force. But this argument ignores the specific language of the article. It permits:
Individual or collective self-defence until the Security Council has taken measures necessary to maintain international peace and security.

Once the Security Council has adopted collective security measures under chapter 7 of the charter, as it has done by imposing air and sea embargoes against Iraq, member nations are constrained by the charter from acting unilaterally or multilaterally to launch an attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about resolution 678?

—That is the exact one I am talking about. The key to a well-governed world is not the endowment of the United Nations with the coercive capacity of a planetary police force but the power of the credible threat of collective action to create conditions for seeking peaceful and diplomatic solutions to international disputes. Such action is embodied in the purposes and principles of the UN charter.

SPEECH.PARA: After the slaughter of more than 60 million people in two world wars, the United Nations was established to put an end to fighting, not to authorise a Third World War. International armed force has proved to be effective when used in a peacekeeping capacity; that is, to disengage warring factions in cases of civil war or to contain further aggression when hostilities across international borders are involved. The use of armed force to restore the status quo ante is, as the Korean conflict demonstrated, a far more perilous means of achieving the high purposes to which the UN is dedicated. Of course, the notion of liberating Kuwait is highly unlikely-it would be more like a total demolition job, finishing off the destruction that the Iraqis began.

The paradox of world peace is that, in a world lacking the consensual foundations for international peace and security, there can be no negotiations with aggressor nations without the credible threat of collective force, but the risks of global conflict are so great that collective force should not be used without first exhausting all the channels of diplomacy. The challenge facing the UN today is to combine the techniques of diplomacy, peacekeeping and collective security by constructive devotion to those features of international organisation that make reliance upon consent, rather than carnage, at once so necessary and so precarious. The kind of public peacekeeping resolution proposed here would preserve the unprecedented international solidarity and threat of force against Iraq's aggression while providing time for economic sanctions and serious diplomatic efforts to achieve a peaceful settlement. I believe that there are points for negotiation which could lead to a settlement without rewarding Iraq for its aggression.

Two major Iraqi grievances concern the uninhabited islands of Bubiyan and Warbah, which restrict Iraq's access to the open sea, and the disputed Al-Rumeilah oilfield that straddles the border drawn by the British 70 years ago, before anyone knew about the oil deposit, as a straight line between Kuwait and Iraq. It is also worth recalling that when Iraq was created out of the remains of the Ottoman Empire it was deliberately given virtually no access to the sea in order to ensure that it did not become too powerful.

After the First World War there was a dispute between Sweden and Finland over the Aland Islands, which lay close to Finland but the inhabitants of which spoke Swedish. Finland had once been part of Sweden but in 1809 it became part of tsarist Russia. This is a useful example of the kind of proposition I am putting forward. In 1918 the Bolsheviks announced that Finland could become independent. In 1917, 96 per cent of the inhabitants of the Aland Islands had signed a petition in favour of a reunion of Aland with Sweden, but Finland said that the islands were nearer Finland than Sweden and should remain part of Finland.

The islands had historically been of strategic importance in the Baltic Sea and, after the Russians started building a fort there in 1820s, the British and French bombarded and destroyed it during the Crimean War in 1854. Fortunately, the question was referred to the newly formed League of Nations in Geneva, and the League Council delivered its decision in June 1921. Sovereignty over Aland was rewarded to Finland as a result of this League of Nations consultation. However, the Council stated:

. . . peace, future cordial relations between Finland and Sweden and the prosperity and happiness of the islands themselves can only be consolidated through measures envisaging (a) new guarantees for the population of the islands and (b) the neutralisation and non-fortification of the archipelago.

The decision of the Council was supplemented by a treaty between Finland and Sweden, the so-called Aland Agreement, which was contracted three days later. In it both countries made an agreement on how to effect the guarantees envisaged by the Council of the League of Nations. This kind of approach, applied to the disputed islands at the head of the Gulf, which are in fact uninhabited, could act as a model for a solution which, while not rewarding Iraq, would-with regional Arab guarantees-remove its fear of interdiction.

Contested oilfields have also been the subject of past disputes and can be resolved through patient negotiation, or countries can go to war over them, which invariably resolves nothing in the long run. Australia's negotiations with Indonesia over the oilfields in the Timor Sea are a good example of successful diplomacy, although unfortunately we were negotiating with the wrong partner-Indonesia, rather than an independent East Timor-in the settlement of that oil dispute. It is, of course, ironic that Australia should now be supporting the small state of Kuwait after it was occupied by its large neighbour while Indonesia's occupation of East Timor in 1975 can apparently be overlooked-a very hypocritical and increasingly embarrassing situation for the Government to contemplate and to deal with. It is this selective indignation that so infuriates the Arabs when they look at the voting record of the Western democracies of Israel and Palestine as well as other examples nearer home, such as East Timor.

Some commentators have also suggested a regional conference to consider some of the other conflicts in the Middle East. Critics of this idea have argued that this would be far too ambitious an undertaking. However, there is an historical parallel in the nineteenth century. At the end of the Napoleonic Wars all the interested nations met at Vienna in 1814 and 1815 to deal with a vast array of political, economic, geographical and military disputes. Out of that Congress of Vienna emerged a new structure for peace and stability in Europe that lasted for a century until it was shattered by World War I.

Some of those arrangements ignored pressing social and political injustices, but the conference provided a practical forum dealing with a host of immediate problems. Many of the problems in the Middle East today arise from the arrangements made for the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire after 1918. A similar conference to the Congress of Vienna could be held in New York and perhaps conducted in three stages. Stage 1 could focus on an end to the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, taking into consideration arrangements over Iraqi access to the sea and a settlement over the disputed Al-Rumeilah oilfield. Stage 2 could focus on the long-festering Palestinian issue and the relationship of Israel to the Arab nations. If these issues can be negotiated, a UN peacekeeping force could safeguard the settlement.

With adequate security guarantees, Israel might be willing to relinquish the occupied territories, including the Golan Heights. The alternative for Israel would be to live under a constant state of siege for the unforeseeable future, and I am sure that that is not a situation that is acceptable either to Israel or to her neighbours.

Syria would be asked to yield its claim on Lebanon and fully accept the right of Israel to live within secure borders as an independent state. Stage 3 of such a conference might focus on Lebanon and the desperate need for a stable and effective Lebanese government guaranteed by the United Nations.

The urgency of addressing the various Middle East issues in a comprehensive conference is underscored by the huge new arms explosion threatening the region. The Pentagon, in response to the Iraqi threat, has proposed a transfer of planes, tanks and artillery to Saudi Arabia over the next few years that may cost more than $US20 billion. President Bush has recommended cancelling Egypt's $US7 1/2 billion debt to the United States for earlier arms and other aid. These moves have frightened the Israelis, who are now asking for debt cancellation and military aid as a counter to the arms build-up and the continuing danger from Baghdad.

In short, the United States is fostering a costly, much expanded Arab-Israeli arms competition, supposedly aimed at Iraq but actually fed by the protracted Arab-Israeli conflict. This problem cries out for solution within the context of an overall peace and security arrangement. Whilst Saddam Hussein is being presented by the popular press as an monster or latter-day Hitler, we must remember that those countries which condemn him now are the same countries which armed him between 1980 and 1988 to fight Iran, the then bogeyman of the decade.
As Hans-Heino Kopietz, Middle East analyst with the control risks group in London, observed:
This is a Frankenstein monster that the West created. We closed our eyes because some businesses wanted to make money and because Saddam was a useful tool against Iran.

Everyone, it seems, took a slice of the Iraqi arms pie. The Soviet Union, France, China and Chile sold the Baghdad regime much of its off-the-shelf weaponry. West Germany, France, Britain, the United States, Belgium, Austria, Switzerland and Brazil all sold the components, machines and tools, much of it material with civilian as well as military application, that are the building blocks of the modern Iraqi war machine.

For the record, by 1985 Iraq was the world's leading importer of arms with a military budget of $1 billion a month. The United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency estimated that during 1981 to 1985 Iraq imported $US24 billion worth of military equipment. This exceeded the $15 billion worth bought by Saudi Arabia, traditionally the world's biggest arms spender. It was also nearly four times the $6.4 billion spent over the same period by Iran.

The respected French paper Le Monde has estimated French arms sales to Iraq during the Gulf War at $5.6 billion plus an additional $4.7 billion on civilian and commercial contracts. It is worth noting that the French company Aerospatiale, which supplied Exocet missiles to Iraq, was a leading participant in the AIDEX 89 arms bazaar held in Canberra in November 1989.

As a result of all these sales, military and intelligence analysts say that Iraq can make some of its own chemical weapons, has a fledgling nuclear weapons program that could produce a bomb in five years or less and is working on a long-range missile that would enable it to deliver such a bomb to Tel Aviv, Tehran or Riyadh. For the record, that comment comes from the Washington Post. I think it is worth taking seriously if we are to avoid an even greater conflict in the Middle East in the years ahead, whatever the outcome of the current crisis in the Gulf.

The Washington Post also ran another article by Haines Johnson on 16 September 1990 in which he said that the Gulf crisis is not only about oil but also about arms. He warned that any genuine new world order will be jeopardised if the United States wants to go on being the world arms merchant. I would add that the same applies to Australia, given the Government's expressed desire to double military exports over the next few years. In this light, it is worthy of note not only that Australia was prepared to lift its arms export embargo to Iraq after the Gulf war but also that much of our current efforts to export military hardware are now being directed towards another unstable part of the world, South East Asia, currently the market's second in importance to the Middle East.

Australian Defence Industries' latest advertisement at the Asian Defence Services exhibition and conference in Bangkok this month was for a mortar that was apparently dirtier than ever before, promising `a 25 per cent increase in lethality'.

There are proposals to try to limit global arms transfers. Some of them were discussed at the third United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in New York, so I will not canvass them further here. However, the point has to be reiterated that if we are to avoid the errors that we have made in the Middle East over the last 30 years through pouring arms into such a volatile region, government policies have to change.

What this crisis a largely about is control of oil resources in the Middle East. Once the OPEC countries got their act together, warning bells rang for the United States oil companies. It was no accident that the United States rapid deployment force was engineered in the mid-1970s after OPEC countries first wielded their economic power. The rapid deployment force, which was designed specifically for quick United States intervention where its interests were threatened anywhere in the world, had a specific and stated focus to be ready for engagement in the Middle East.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In regard to the estimated growth of three-quarters of one per cent in the real value of gross farm product in 1990-91 contained in Statement 2 of Budget Paper No. 1, what underlying assumptions about production, consumption and average prices were made to calculate the gross value of production in 1990-91 of: (a) wool; (b) wheat; (c) rice; (d) sugar; and (e) milk.
(2) What revisions to the forecasts for these commodities, particularly with respect to prices, have been necessitated by developments since they were first made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The farm product forecast appearing in Statement 2 of Budget Paper No 1 was based on Treasury analysis of commodity production forecasts by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE), as well as information received from other statutory agencies (such as marketing authorities) and from rural industry groups. Disaggregation of the Budget forecasts is not made public. The disaggregated ABARE forecasts were published in the June 1990 issue of the `Agriculture and Resources Quarterly'. More recent ABARE forecasts appeared in the September 1990 issue of the same publication.
(2) Through the course of the fiscal year, Treasury monitors the state of the farm sector, though official revisions to Budgettime forecasts are not usually made.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the potential health hazards arising from the importation of over 700,000 second-hand tyres and tyre casings per annum which may not have been properly disinfected and may carry soil or bacterial contamination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the potential health hazards presented by the importation of second-hand tyres in regard to the introduction of exotic mosquitoes known to be disease vectors.

(2) Guidelines for the handling and treatment of imported tyres were drafted by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and endorsed by the Department of Community Services and Health in early 1988. QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has Australia become a dumping ground for over 700 000 second-hand tyres and tyre casings per annum from countries such as the USA and Japan which have serious scrap tyre disposal problems and are now transferring their disposal problems to Australia, and does this not contradict the Government's environment policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986-87, 156 000 used tyres were imported into Australia. According to the Australian Tyre Manufacturers Association imports of used tyres have increased to 700 000 in 1989-90, and are exported mainly from the USA and Japan.

Imported used tyres are either utilised for retreading or sold at the retail level as second-hand tyres. They are therefore essentially a commercial import. However, used tyres have a naturally shorter life and therefore will be ready for disposal more quickly than new tyres. To the extent that the import adds to Australia's waste disposal problem, this is a matter of environmental concern.

The import of products that pose a waste disposal problem for Australia is being examined as part of the Commonwealth Government's development of a national waste minimisation and recycling strategy, which is expected to be finalised by mid 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 14 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the Government's supposed commitment to road safety, how can the Government justify the importation of over 700 000 second-hand tyres and tyre casings per annum which are not necessarily manufactured to internationally recognised standards and have an unknown service history, and that could result in future potentially dangerous service problems.

(2) Can this problem be partially solved by restricting the importation to tyres that have a predetermined tread depth so that they last longer and do not have to be disposed of as quickly as those secondhand imported tyres that have inadequate tread depth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Federal Government is responsible for the standards of tyres for new vehicles which are set out in the various Australian Design Rules. In addition to specifying an Australian Standard, these Rules also allow, in the case of commercial vehicle tyres, a number of alternative standards, specifically the Economic Commission for Europe, Japan and the United States. These alternative standards were included on the advice of industry, after an appropriate comment process, on the grounds that they provided equivalent safety requirements to Australian Standards.

The standards for tyres fitted to vehicles in service are the responsibility of State and Territory authorities. These requirements, I am advised, are generally based on the Design Rules. The Minister for Land Transport has advised his State and Territory colleagues of the concerns regarding the safety of imported used tyres.

The Federal Government is concerned about road safety and devotes considerable effort to ensure that vehicles have a high level of safety. The Federal Office of Road Safety has arrangements for investigating safety defects in the context of the various recall codes in support of the Trade Practices Act. The industry has been asked to bring forward factual evidence that the used tyres being imported and offered to the market present a safety hazard.

I have been advised that the majority of the tyres concerned are imported from Japan, Europe and America. The standards for tyres in those countries are generally equivalent to Australian requirements. Interestingly, a large number of commercial vehicle casings are imported by major companies in Australia to meet a shortfall of casings for remoulding purposes.
(2) The Australian Customs Service has advised that import controls which specify an end use are very difficult to administer, impede commerce and are readily circumvented.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 26 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister have any information about the problems being experienced by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) concerning that organisation's work among Burmese refugees living in Thailand.
(2) Is the Minister able to confirm media reports which suggest that Burmese refugees living in Thailand under the protection of the UNHCR have recently been arrested by Thai police.
(3) What reasons has the Thailand Government given for threatening to expel from the country officials of the UNHCR and other international aid agencies working among Burmese refugees.
(4) Have any officials of the UNHCR and other international aid agencies been expelled from Thailand.

(5) Have any officials of the Australian Government been in contact with Thai authorities specifically in relation to the activities of the aid agencies in Thailand and the treatment of Burmese refugees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that it has recently become increasingly difficult for the UNHCR to provide protection and assistance to Burmese students in Thailand, particularly since the hijacking of a Thai Airways aircraft by Burmese students in November. On 16 November, a Deputy Permanent Secretary of the Thai Ministry of the Interior publicly warned international agencies, including the UNHCR, to stop providing assistance to Burmese students or face arrest and possible deportation.

(2) An official of the UNHCR has confirmed that there have been some arrests of Burmese students by the Thai authorities but that all have subsequently been released. The sole exception is the person charged with the hijacking of a Thai Airways aircraft.

(3) The Thai Government's warning to UNHCR and other aid agencies resulted from the inquiry into the hijacking of the Thai Airways flight to Rangoon by two Burmese students. Ministry of Interior officials in Thailand have claimed that one of the hijackers was receiving maintenance funding from UNHCR. In addition, it has been pointed out that Thailand is not bound by any international agreement concerning Burmese asylum seekers and that the UNHCR has no formal mandate to assist Burmese in Thailand.
(4) No officials of the UNHCR have been expelled from Thailand, nor am I aware of any officials from other aid agencies being expelled.

(5) The Australian Embassy in Bangkok has registered Australia's concerns to the Thai authorities over the treatment of Burmese refugees. It has expressed the hope that Burmese displaced persons in Thailand, including students, will continue to be treated in accordance with accepted standards applying to the treatment of asylum seekers and should not be subject to refoulement. The Embassy has also emphasised Australia's expectation that Burmese asylum seekers should be given normal UNHCR protection and assistance and that relief agencies and international organisations should have access to the holding centres in order to provide humanitarian assistance and, where applicable, to fulfil their protection function.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 26 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Broken Hill Proprietary Company (BHP) paid US $5 million to the military regime in Burma in return for oil exploration rights in that country; if so, what has been the involvement of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in this arrangement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that, in November 1989, BHP Petroleum entered into a production sharing agreement with Myanmar Oil and Gas Enterprise to undertake work in an area in Burma known as Block H. The onshore bid round in Burma was highly competitive; more than forty international oil companies participated. Each of the nine successful bidders entered into a production sharing contract. As is ordinary commercial practice worldwide in such agreements, the production sharing contracts each required exploration work and payment of a signature bonus. In the case of Block H, the signature bonus paid to Myanmar Oil and Gas Enterprise was the minimum bid amount of US $5 million.

The signature bonus was paid by BHP in consideration of the right to work in the area and the purchase of geologic, geophysical and well data over Block H. Throughout the world, the amount of the signature bonus will vary widely based upon prospectivity, competitive interest and the data purchased. The amount paid in the present case is well within the usual parameters.

The Australian Embassy in Rangoon facilitated contacts between BHP representatives and Burmese ministers and officials and briefed BHP representatives on political and economic developments in Burma. The Embassy was not involved in the substance of negotiations between BHP Petroleum and the Burmese government nor in the eventual agreement. However, the Australian Ambassador did attend the ceremonies associated with the signing of the agreement.

The Embassy's assistance to BHP Petroleum was no more and no less than that which it provides to representatives from other Australian companies who have visited Burma to examine or negotiate commercial opportunities. These activities are consistent with the Government's directives that embassies should give full support to Australian commercial activities overseas.
